Book: Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik (Paths and Kingdoms)
Author: Abu al-Qasim Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah known as Ibn Khordadbeh (died approx. 280 AH)
Year of Publication: 1889 AD

Book: Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik
Author: Abu al-Qasim Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah known as Ibn Khordadbeh (died approx. 280 AH)
Year of Publication: 1889 AD

Author: Abu al-Qasim Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah known as Ibn Khordadbeh (died approx. 280 AH)
Year of Publication: 1889 AD

Year of Publication: 1889 AD

Year of Publication: 1889 AD


[Book numbering matches the printed version]

Abu al-Qasim Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah ibn Khordadbeh, died around 300 AH. A historian and geographer of the third Islamic century. It is said that he was of Iranian origin and was a follower of Zoroastrianism, then embraced the religion of Islam at the hands of the Barmakids; it appears from this that he was from the people of Khorasan. Historians differed regarding the year of his birth and death, mentioning two dates for his birth: 205 and 211 AH. Ibn Khordadbeh immigrated early in his life to Baghdad and began receiving knowledge from his father; he also learned the art of music from the famous musician of that era, Ishaq al-Mawsili. During the caliphate of Al-Wathiq Billah (227 - 232 AH), he was entrusted with the position of "Chief of Post and Intelligence." It seems that this work led to the expansion of his knowledge regarding road conditions, tax rates, and the geographic and administrative situations in Iran and both Islamic and non-Islamic countries, which was the reason for his authoring of this book. His closeness to the Abbasid Caliph Al-Mu'tamid and his attendance at his literary and artistic gatherings caused him to delve into fields other than geography, such as literature, music, cooking, and others, through reading and writing. His Works: Ibn al-Nadim listed eight books for the biographer in his index: 'Adab al-Sama' (Etiquette of Listening), 'Jamharat Ansab al-Furs wa al-Nawafil' (Collection of Persian Genealogies and Supererogatory Acts), 'Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik' (Paths and Kingdoms), 'Al-Tabikh' (Cooking), 'Al-Lahw wa al-Malahi' (Entertainment and Instruments), 'Al-Sharab' (Drink), 'Al-Anwa'' (Weather Stars), 'Al-Nudam wa al-Julasa'' (Boon-companions and Sitters). Other sources mentioned two other books: 'Al-Kabir fi al-Tarikh' (The Great History) and 'Akhbar Ibn Khordadbeh' (News of Ibn Khordadbeh). However, nothing remains of these ten works except two books: 'Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik' and a selection from the book 'Al-Lahw wa al-Malahi'. Reliance of Geographers on Ibn Khordadbeh: Many subsequent geographers relied on Ibn Khordadbeh in his geographical methodology, such as Al-Yaqubi, Ibn al-Faqih, Ibn Rusta, Ibn Hawqal, Al-Maqdisi, Al-Jayhani, and Al-Masudi.

[Preface of the Book] In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. May Allah Almighty prolong your life, O son of the chosen masters and the righteous Imams, the beacon of religion and Allah's choice from all creation. May Allah perpetuate happiness for you, increase all good things for you, guide you to the path of righteous deeds, and make you among those whose actions He is pleased with and whose conditions He adorns. I understood what you asked—may Allah make you understand all good things, grant you happiness until death, make your share successful in both abodes, and make your portion plentiful in them—regarding the description of clarifying the paths of the earth, its kingdoms, its descriptions, its distances (far and near), its populated and unpopulated areas, and the travel between them through their deserts and distant lands, and the diagrams of their roads and sub-districts (Tassujs) according to what the predecessors have drawn. I found that Ptolemy had clarified the borders and made the argument clear in describing them in a foreign language, so I translated it from his language into the correct language so that you may understand it. I have drawn a diagram for you containing the attainment of truth in all your hopes and requests, which I hope will encompass what you sought and fulfill your will, like an eyewitness to what is far and news of what is near. I made it into a book (2) which I opened with praise to Allah, Possessor of unconquerable might and abundant blessing, Who originated creation as He willed and clarified the path of truth for the servants. Neither imagined opinions nor the conjectures of narrations shared with Him in His creation; Exalted is Allah above what they associate with Him. May Allah send peace and blessings upon Muhammad, His Prophet, and upon the chosen ones of his family, and grant them abundant peace.

[Description of the Earth] This is a book containing the description of the Earth, the structure of creation upon it, the Qibla (direction of prayer) of the people of every land, and the kingdoms and paths to the regions of the Earth. Authored by Abu al-Qasim Ubayd Allah ibn Abd Allah ibn Khordadbeh, the client of the Commander of the Faithful. Abu al-Qasim said: The description of the Earth is that it is round like the roundness of a sphere, placed in the hollow of the celestial sphere like a yolk inside an egg. The breeze (ether/atmosphere) is around the Earth, attracting it from all its sides towards the celestial sphere. The structure of creation on Earth is such that the breeze attracts the lightness in their bodies, and the Earth attracts the heaviness in their bodies, for the Earth is like a lodestone that attracts iron. The Earth is divided into two halves, with the Equator between them, running from East to West. This is the length of the Earth, and it is (3) the longest line on the sphere of the Earth, just as the Zodiac belt is the longest line in the celestial sphere. The width of the Earth is from the South Pole, around which Canopus revolves, to the North Pole, around which the constellation of Ursa Major revolves. The circumference of the Earth at the Equator is three hundred and sixty degrees. A degree is twenty-five parasangs (farsakh). A parasang is twelve thousand cubits. A cubit is twenty-four fingers. A finger is six barley grains lined up belly to belly. This totals nine thousand parasangs. Between the Equator and each of the two poles is ninety astrolabe degrees, and its circumference in width is the same, except that the habitable land on Earth after the Equator is twenty-four

degrees, then the rest is submerged by the Great Sea. So, we are in the Northern Quarter of the Earth, and the Southern Quarter is desolate due to the intense heat there, and the half that is beneath us has no inhabitants. Each of the Northern and Southern quarters has seven climes. Ptolemy mentioned in his book that the cities of the Earth during his time were four thousand and two hundred cities. Qibla of the People of Every Land: The Qibla of the people of Armenia, Azerbaijan, Baghdad, Wasit, (4) Kufa, Al-Mada'in, Basra, Hulwan, Dinawar, Nihawand, Hamadan, Isfahan, Rayy, Tabaristan, all of Khorasan, the lands of the Khazars, and Kashmir in India is towards the wall of the Kaaba that contains its door, which is from the North Pole on its left to the middle of the East. As for Tibet, the lands of the Turks, China, and Al-Mansurah, they are behind the middle of the East by eight parts because their Qibla is near the Black Stone. As for the Qibla of the people of Yemen, their prayer is towards the Yemeni Corner, and their faces are towards the faces of the people of Armenia when they pray. As for the Qibla of the people of the Maghreb, Ifriqiya, Egypt, the Levant (Sham), and Al-Jazira, it is the middle of the West, and their prayer is towards the Levantine Corner, and their faces when they pray are towards the faces of the people of Al-Mansurah when they pray. These are the Qiblas of the people and the direction they pray towards. Al-Sawad: Then I begin by mentioning Al-Sawad (Iraq), as the Persian kings used to call it *Dil Eranshahr*, meaning the Heart of Iraq. Al-Sawad consists of twelve Kuras (provinces); each Kura is an Astan (district) and its sub-districts (Tassujs)

are sixty Tassujs. The translation of Astan is 'Hayyiz' (domain/district) and the translation of Tassuj is 'Nahiyah' (side/sub-district). (5) Kura Astan Shadh Fayruz, which is Hulwan, has five Tassujs: Tassuj Fayruz Qubadh, Tassuj Al-Jabal, Tassuj Tamarra, Tassuj Arbil, and Tassuj Khaniqin. The Eastern Side, watered by the Tigris and Tamarra: Kura Astan Shadh Hormuz has seven Tassujs: Tassuj Buzurjsabur, Tassuj Nahr Buq, Tassuj Kalwadha and Nahr Bin, Tassuj Jazir, Tassuj Al-Madinah Al-Atiqah (The Old City), Tassuj Upper Radhan, and Tassuj Lower Radhan. Kura Astan Shadh Qubadh has eight Tassujs: Tassuj Rustaqubadh, Tassuj Mahrudh, Tassuj Salsal, Tassuj Jalula and Jalalta, Tassuj Al-Dhibin, Tassuj Al-Bandanijin, Tassuj Baraz Al-Ruz, Tassuj Al-Daskarah and Al-Rustaqayn. Kura Astan Bazijan Khusraw has five Tassujs: Tassuj Upper Nahrawan, Tassuj Middle Nahrawan, Tassuj Lower Nahrawan, Iskaf

Bani Junayd Jarjaraya and its surroundings, Tassuj Badaraya, Tassuj Bakisaya. (6) Watered by the Tigris and Euphrates: Kura Astan Shadh Sabur, which is Kaskar, has four Tassujs: Tassuj Al-Zandaward, Tassuj Al-Tharthur, Tassuj Al-Astan, Tassuj Al-Jawazir. Kura Astan Shadh Bahman, which is the Kura of Dijlah (Tigris), has four Tassujs: Tassuj Bahman Ardashir, Tassuj Maysan which is Milwa, Tassuj Dast Maysan which is Al-Ubulla—Ghaylan bin Salamah Al-Thaqafi said: 'She kept shying away from the poultry and its sound, And the squeaking of a door in Al-Ubulla being closed'—and Tassuj Abazqubadh. The land tax (Kharaj) of Dijlah is eight million five hundred thousand dirhams. Watered by the Euphrates and Dujayl from west of the Tigris: Kura Astan Al-Ali has four Tassujs: Tassuj Fayruz Sabur which is Al-Anbar, Tassuj Maskin—Ibn Al-Ruqayyat said: 'Indeed the calamity was the day of Maskin, The misfortune and the tragedy'—Tassuj Qatrabbul, and Tassuj Baduraya. Kura Astan Ardashir Babakan has five Tassujs: Tassuj Bahurasir, Tassuj Al-Rumagan, Tassuj Kutha, (7) Tassuj Nahr Darqit, Tassuj Nahr Jubar.

Kura Astan Bih-Dhi-Masfan, which is Al-Zawabi, has three Tassujs: Tassuj Upper Zab, Tassuj Middle Zab, Tassuj Lower Zab. Kura Astan Bihqubadh Upper has six Tassujs: Tassuj Babil, Tassuj Khatarniyah, Tassuj Upper Fallujah, Tassuj Lower Fallujah, Tassuj Al-Nahrayn, Tassuj Ayn Al-Tamr. Kura Astan Bihqubadh Middle has four Tassujs: Tassuj Al-Jabbah and Al-Bidah, Tassuj Sura and Barbisma, Tassuj Barusma, Tassuj Nahr Al-Malik—and it is said that they are one Tassuj and the fourth Tassuj is Al-Sibayn and Al-Wuquf, then shifted to the estates (Diya'). Kura Astan Bihqubadh Lower has five Tassujs: Tassuj Furat Badaqla, Tassuj Al-Saylahin, Tassuj Nastar, Tassuj Rudhmastan, Tassuj Hormuzjard—and it is said that Rudhmastan and Hormuzjard are scattered estates from several Tassujs. Estimation of Al-Sawad: The Western Side watered by Euphrates and Dujayl: Tassuj Al-Anbar (8) has five Rustaqs (rural districts) and two hundred and fifty threshing floors. Wheat: two thousand three hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand four hundred Kurr. Silver (money): one hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Qatrabbul has ten Rustaqs, two hundred twenty threshing floors. Wheat: two thousand Kurr. Barley: one thousand Kurr. Silver: three hundred thousand dirhams.

Tassuj Maskin has six Rustaqs, one hundred fifty threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand Kurr. Barley: two thousand Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand [dirhams]. Tassuj Baduraya has fourteen Rustaqs, four hundred twenty threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand five hundred Kurr. Barley: two thousand Kurr. Silver: two million dirhams. Tassuj Bahurasir has ten Rustaqs, two hundred forty threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand nine hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand seven hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Al-Rumagan has ten Rustaqs, (9) two hundred forty threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand three hundred Kurr. Barley: three thousand and fifty Kurr. Silver: two hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Kutha has nine Rustaqs, two hundred ten threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand Kurr. Barley: two thousand Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Nahr Darqit has eight Rustaqs, one hundred twenty-five threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley: one thousand Kurr. Silver: two hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Nahr Jubar has ten Rustaqs, two hundred twenty-seven threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand seven hundred Kurr. Barley: six thousand Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Kura Al-Zawabi has three Tassujs, twelve Rustaqs,

two hundred forty-four threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand four hundred Kurr. Barley: seven thousand two hundred Kurr. Silver: two hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassujs Babil and Khatarniyah: sixteen Rustaqs, three hundred seventy-eight threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand Kurr. (10) Barley: five thousand Kurr. Silver: three hundred fifty thousand. Tassuj Upper Fallujah: fifteen Rustaqs, two hundred forty threshing floors. Wheat: five hundred Kurr. Barley: five hundred Kurr. Silver: seventy thousand dirhams. Tassuj Lower Fallujah: six Rustaqs, seventy-two threshing floors. Wheat: five hundred Kurr. Barley: five hundred Kurr. Silver: seventy thousand dirhams. Tassuj Lower Fallujah [repeated/correction implied]: six Rustaqs, seventy-two threshing floors. Wheat: two thousand Kurr. Barley: three thousand Kurr. Silver: two hundred eighty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Al-Nahrayn: three Rustaqs, one hundred eighty-one threshing floors. Wheat: three hundred Kurr. Barley: four hundred Kurr. Silver: forty-five thousand. Tassuj Ayn Al-Tamr: three Rustaqs, fourteen threshing floors. Wheat: three hundred Kurr. Barley: four hundred Kurr. Silver: forty-five thousand. Tassuj Al-Jabbah and Al-Bidah: eight Rustaqs, seventy-one threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand two hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand six hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand dirhams. Tassuj Sura and Barbisma: ten Rustaqs, two hundred sixty-five threshing floors. Wheat: seven hundred Kurr. (11) Barley and Rice: two thousand four hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred thousand dirhams.

Tassuj Barusma and Nahr Al-Malik: ten Rustaqs, six hundred sixty-four threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand five hundred Kurr. Barley: four thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: two hundred fifty thousand. Al-Sibayn and Al-Wuquf are estates gathered from several Tassujs and made into a single estate, so it is greater in value than two Tassujs. The estimate of the tithe from it is: Wheat: five hundred Kurr. Barley: five thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand. Tassuj Furat Badaqla: sixteen Rustaqs, two hundred seventy-one threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley and Rice: two thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: nine hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Al-Saylahin (containing Al-Khawarnaq and Tiznabadh): thirty-four threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley: one thousand seven hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred forty thousand. Tassujs Rudhmastan and Hormuzjard: Wheat: five hundred Kurr. Barley: five hundred (12) Kurr. Silver: ten thousand dirhams. Tassuj Nastar: seven Rustaqs, one hundred seventy-three threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand two hundred fifty Kurr. Barley and Rice: two thousand Kurr. Silver: three hundred thousand dirhams. Ighar Yaqtin (Yaqtin's Exemption) from several Tassujs, its estimate in silver is two hundred four thousand eight hundred forty dirhams due to the treasury. Watered by Tigris and Euphrates:

Kura Kaskar, containing Nahr Al-Silah, Barqah, and Al-Rayyan. The revenue from its land tax and other sources of wealth used to reach seventy million dirhams. Its estimate in Wheat: three thousand Kurr. Barley and Rice: twenty thousand Kurr. Silver: two hundred thousand dirhams. The Eastern Side: Tassuj Buzurjsabur: nine Rustaqs, two hundred sixty-three threshing floors. Wheat: two thousand five hundred Kurr. Barley: two thousand two hundred Kurr. Silver: three hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Al-Radhanayn (The Two Radhans): sixteen Rustaqs, (13) three hundred sixty-two threshing floors. Wheat: four thousand eight hundred Kurr. Barley: four thousand eight hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred twenty thousand. Tassuj Nahr Buq: Wheat: two hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand Kurr. Silver: one hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Kalwadha and Nahr Bin: three Rustaqs, thirty-four threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand six hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: three hundred thirty thousand dirhams. Tassujs Jazir and Al-Madinah Al-Atiqah: seven Rustaqs, one hundred sixteen threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley: one thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred forty thousand.

Tassuj Rustaqubadh: Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley and Millet: one thousand four hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred seventy thousand. Tassujs Mahrudh and Salsal: Wheat: two thousand Kurr. Barley: two thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: two hundred fifty thousand. Tassujs Jalula and Jalalta: five Rustaqs, seventy-six threshing floors. Wheat: one thousand Kurr. (14) Barley: one thousand Kurr. Silver: one hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Al-Dhibin: four Rustaqs, two hundred thirty threshing floors. Wheat: seven hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand three hundred Kurr. Silver: forty thousand. Tassuj Al-Daskarah and Al-Rustaqayn: seven Rustaqs, forty-four threshing floors. Wheat: two thousand Kurr. Barley: two thousand Kurr. Silver: seventy thousand. Tassuj Baraz Al-Ruz: seven Rustaqs, eighty-six threshing floors. Wheat: three thousand Kurr. Barley: five thousand five hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred twenty thousand. Tassuj Al-Bandanijin: five Rustaqs, fifty-four threshing floors. Wheat: six hundred Kurr. Barley: five hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred thousand dirhams. Tassujs of Al-Nahrawanat: twenty-one Rustaqs, three hundred eighty threshing floors. Tassuj Upper Nahrawan: Wheat: two thousand seven hundred Kurr. Barley: one thousand eight hundred Kurr. Silver: three hundred fifty thousand.

Tassuj Middle Nahrawan: Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley: five hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred thousand dirhams. Tassuj Lower Nahrawan: Wheat: one thousand Kurr. Barley: one thousand two hundred Kurr. Silver: one hundred fifty thousand. Tassuj Badaraya and Bakisaya: seven Rustaqs, two hundred seven threshing floors. Wheat: four thousand seven hundred Kurr. Barley: five thousand Kurr. Silver: three hundred thirty thousand. Kura Astan Shadh Fayruz, which is Hulwan: The levy of Hulwan along with Al-Jabariqah and the Kurds in silver is one million eight hundred thousand. Total Revenue of Al-Sawad: As for the amount of revenue of Al-Sawad in ancient times, one hundred fifty million dirhams (weight in mithqals) were collected for King Qubadh son of Fayruz. Umar ibn al-Khattab ordered the surveying of Al-Sawad. Its length is from Al-Alth and Harba to Abadan, which is one hundred twenty-five parasangs, and its width is from Aqabat Hulwan to Al-Udhayb, which is eighty parasangs. Its area reached (16) thirty-six million Jaribs. He placed on every Jarib of wheat four dirhams, on a Jarib of barley two dirhams, on a Jarib of palms eight dirhams, on a Jarib of vines six dirhams, and on a Jarib of clover six dirhams. He sealed five hundred thousand people for the Jizya (poll tax) according to classes. Umar ibn al-Khattab collected from Al-Sawad one hundred twenty-eight million dirhams. Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz collected one hundred twenty-four million dirhams. Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf collected eighteen

million dirhams, confusing it for one hundred million, due to his oppression, clumsiness, and injustice. He advanced them two million dirhams, so he ended up with sixteen million dirhams. He forbade the people of Al-Sawad from slaughtering cows to increase tillage and agriculture. The poet said regarding that: 'We complained to him about the ruin of Al-Sawad * But he ignorantly forbade the meat of cows.' The revenue of the kingdom collected for Khosrow Parviz in the eighteenth year of his reign was four hundred twenty million mithqals, (17) which is the weight of seven [dinars being ten dirhams] six hundred million. Then the revenue of his kingdom reached six hundred million mithqals after that. Kings of the Earth in the Beginning of Time and Their Kingdoms: Feridun divided the earth among his three sons. He made Salm (Sharm) king over the West, so the kings of Rome and Sogdia are from his descendants. He made Tush (Tuj) king over the East, so the kings of the Turks and China are from his descendants. He made Iran (Iraj) king over Iranshahr, which is Iraq, so the Chosroes (Sasanians), kings of Iraq, are from his descendants. Their poet said:

'And we divided our kingdom in our time * Like the division of meat upon a butcher's block. We made the Levant and Rome unto * The setting of the sun, to the noble Salm. And to Tuj, He assigned the Turks to him * And the lands of China, possessed by a cousin. And to Iran, we assigned by force * Persia, the Kingship, and we won the blessings.' Titles of the Kings of the Earth: The King of Iraq, whom the common people call Kisra, is Shahanshah. The King of Rome, whom the common people call Caesar, is Basil. The Kings of the Turks, (18) Tibet, and the Khazars are all [called] Khaqan, except the King of the Karluks, for they call them Jabghuya. The King of China is Baghbur; these are the children of Feridun. The Greatest King of India is Ballahra, meaning King of Kings. Among the kings of India are Jaba, the King of Al-Tafan, the King of Al-Jurz, Ghaba, Rahma, and the King of Qamarun. The King of Zabaj is Al-Fatajab.

The King of Nubia is Kabil. The King of Abyssinia is Al-Najashi. The King of the islands of the Eastern Sea is Al-Mahraj. The King of the Slavs is Qinaz. The Kings Named by Ardashir: Buzurg Kushan Shah, Gilan Shah, Budh Ardashiran Shah (meaning Mosul), Maysan Shah, Buzurg Arminiyan Shah, Adhurbadhagan Shah, Sijistan Shah, Marw Shah, Kirman Shah, Badishwar Garshah, Yaman Shah, Taziyan Shah, Kadhish Shah, Barjan Shah, Amukan Shah, Sabiyan Shah, MashkZdan Shah (in Khorasan), Al-Lan Shah (Muqan), Barashkan Shah (in Azerbaijan), Qufs Shah (in Kirman), Makran Shah (in Sindh), Turan Shah (in Turk lands), Hinduwan Shah, Kabilan Shah, Shiriyan

Shah (in Azerbaijan), Rayhan Shah (from India), Qayqan Shah (in Sindh), Balashjan Shah, Dawran Shah (Lands of Dawar), Nakhshban Shah, Qashmiran Shah, Bakardan Shah, Kadhaft Shah. These are the names of the kings. News of the East: Then we begin with the East, which is a quarter of the kingdom. We begin by mentioning Khorasan. It was under the authority of its Spahbed (army chief), Badhusban, and four Marzbans (border wardens). To every Marzban was a quarter of Khorasan. (19) So, a quarter was for the Marzban of Marw al-Shahijan and its works. A quarter for the Marzban of Balkh and Tukharistan. A quarter for the Marzban of Herat, Bushanj, Badhghis, and Sijistan—Ibn Mufarrigh said: 'And the day of Herat, the caller made you hear * You went left, while he called right.' And a quarter for the Marzban of Transoxiana. The Road from the City of Peace (Baghdad) to the Farthest Ends of Khorasan: From Baghdad to Al-Nahrawan is four parasangs. Then to Dayr Bazma, four parasangs. Then to Al-Daskarah, eight parasangs. Then to Jalula, seven parasangs. The poet said:

'The day of Jalula and the day of Rustam ... And the day the advance King marched.' Then to Khaniqin, seven parasangs. Then to Qasr Shirin, six parasangs. Hammad Ajrad said: 'May Allah make the two lote trees of Qasr Shirin * A ransom for the two palms of Hulwan.' Whoever wants Shahrazur travels from Qasr Shirin to Dizkaran, two parasangs. And from Dizkaran to Shahrazur, eighteen parasangs. Its city is Nim-Az-Rah, meaning half the way from Al-Mada'in to the Fire Temple of Shiz. From Qasr Shirin to Hulwan, five parasangs. Then the Aqaba (Pass) of Hulwan. From Hulwan to Madhruwastan (20) four parasangs. Then to Marj al-Qal'ah, six parasangs. Then to Qasr Yazid, four parasangs. Then to Al-Zubaydiyah, six parasangs. Then to Khushkarish, three parasangs. Then to Qasr Amr, four parasangs. Then to Qirmisin, three parasangs. Shabduz is less than two parasangs from it to the left while you are heading on the road to Khorasan. Then to Al-Dukkan, nine parasangs. Whoever wants Nihawand and Isfahan takes from Al-Dukkan to the right to Madharan, then to Nihawand, which is one of the districts of Al-Jibal.

The districts of Al-Jibal are Masabadhan, Mihrajanqadhaq, Mah al-Kufa which is Dinawar, Mah al-Basra which is Nihawand, Hamadan, and Qom. The land tax of Dinawar is three million eight hundred thousand dirhams. The Persians had assessed the tax on Al-Jibal, Azerbaijan, Rayy, Hamadan, the two Mahs, Tabaristan, Dunbawand, Masabadhan, Mihrajanqadhaq, Hulwan, and Qumis at thirty million dirhams. The districts of Isfahan are eighty parasangs by eighty parasangs. It has seventeen Rustaqs (rural districts); in every Rustaq there are three hundred sixty-five ancient villages, excluding the newly created ones. Its land tax is seven million dirhams. It is vast in land, with many buildings and good air. Mention of the Rustaqs of Isfahan: Rustaq Marbin, which contains a fortress built by Tahmures containing a fire temple. Rustaq Karwan. Rustaq Barkhwar. Rustaq Awan. Rustaq Anar. (21) Rustaq Al-Jay. Rustaq Al-Badh. Rustaq Quhistan. Rustaq Al-Qumidhan. Rustaq Bara'an. Rustaq Al-Rudh. Rustaq Ruydasht, in which Zarrin-Rudh (Zayandeh Rud) sinks and comes out in Kirman, and between them is ninety parasangs. Rustaq...

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Arvand, Rustaq (district) of Ardestan, Rustaq of Sard Qasan, Rustaq of Jarm Qasan, Rustaq of Qumm, Rustaq of Saveh, Rustaq of Taymarah the Lesser, Rustaq of Taymarah the Greater, Rustaq of Qayq, Rustaq of Jabulqa, Rustaq of Barq al-Rudh, Rustaq of Waranqan, Rustaq of Faridhin, Rustaq of Wardah. Al-Fadl bin Marwan informed me that he accepted the contract for Isfahan and Qumm for sixteen million dirhams as a sufficient sum, on the condition that there would be no burden on the Sultan. Kai Kavus had made Gudarz king over it. From Al-Dukkan to Qasr al-Lusus (Castle of Thieves) is seven farsakhs; then to Khandadh is seven farsakhs; then the Aqabat (Pass) of Hamadan to Qaryat al-Asal (Village of Honey) is three farsakhs; then to Hamadan is five farsakhs. From Hamadan to Qazvin: From Hamadan via the Rustaq of Kharraqan to Qazvin is forty farsakhs. From Hamadan to Durnawa is five farsakhs; then to Buznajard is five farsakhs; then to Zarah is four farsakhs; then to? Zarah is four farsakhs,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Then to Al-Asawirah is four farsakhs; then to Bustah and Rudhah is three farsakhs; then to Dawud-abad is four farsakhs; then to Susinqin is three farsakhs; then to Darudh is four farsakhs; (22) then to Saveh is five farsakhs; then to Mushkuyah is nine farsakhs; then to Qastanah is eight farsakhs; then to Rayy is seven farsakhs. The total is one hundred and sixty-seven farsakhs. Abu al-Atahiya said: 'For Rayy and its regions to prosper, and for goodness to rain upon it from his hand.' The land tax (Kharaj) of Rayy is ten million dirhams. From Rayy to Qazvin, bearing left, is twenty-seven farsakhs. From Qazvin to Abhar is twelve farsakhs. From Abhar to Zanjan is fifteen farsakhs. From Rayy to Mufaddal-abad is four farsakhs; then to Kasib is six farsakhs; then to Afridhin is eight farsakhs; then to Al-Khuwar is six farsakhs; then to Qasr al-Milh (Castle of Salt) is seven farsakhs; then to Ra's al-Kalb (Dog's Head)

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is seven farsakhs; then to Semnan is eight farsakhs; then to Akharin is nine farsakhs; then to Qumis is eight farsakhs. So from Rayy to it is sixty-three farsakhs. Then to Al-Haddadah is seven farsakhs; then to Badhash is seven farsakhs; then to Maymad is twelve farsakhs; then to Haftkand is seven farsakhs; then to Asadabad is seven farsakhs; then to Bahman-abad is six farsakhs; then to Al-Nawq is six farsakhs; then to Khosrowjerd is six farsakhs; then to Husayn-abad is six farsakhs; then to Sankardar is five farsakhs; (23) then to Biskand is five farsakhs; then to Nishapur is five farsakhs. Nishapur has a citadel (Quhandiz). So, from Baghdad to Nishapur

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is three hundred and five farsakhs. Its cities include Zam, Bakharz, Jowayin, and Bayhaq. Then to Baghis is four farsakhs; then to Al-Hamra is six farsakhs; then to Al-Muthaqqab of Tus is five farsakhs; then to Al-Nawqan is five farsakhs; then to Mazdavaran is six farsakhs; then to Abkinah is eight farsakhs; then to Sarakhs is six farsakhs. The total is three hundred and forty-five farsakhs. Then to Qasr al-Najjar is three farsakhs; then to Ashtarmaghak is five farsakhs; then to Talistanah is six farsakhs; then to Al-Dandanqan is six farsakhs; then to Yanujard is five farsakhs; then to Merv al-Shahijan is five farsakhs. The total is three hundred and seventy-five farsakhs.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Merv has a citadel. The poet said: 'Merv turned the head of Abu al-Saraya, and left a lesson for those who pass by.' From Merv there are two roads: one to Shash and the lands of the Turks, and the other to Balkh and Tokharistan. (24) As for the road to Shash and the Turks: From Merv to Kushmahan is five farsakhs; then to Al-Diwab is six farsakhs; then to Al-Munsaf is six farsakhs; then to Al-Ahsa is eight farsakhs; then to Bir Uthman (Well of Uthman) is three farsakhs; then to Amul is eight farsakhs. So from Merv to Amul is thirty-six farsakhs. From Amul to the bank of the river of Balkh is one farsakh, and one crosses to Farbr, which is one farsakh; then to the Fortress of Umm Ja'far, a desert journey of six farsakhs; from there to Baykand is six farsakhs; then to the gate of the wall of Bukhara is two farsakhs; then to Mastin is one and a half farsakhs; then to Bukhara is one and a half farsakhs. So from Amul to Bukhara is nineteen farsakhs. Bukhara has a citadel, and its cities include Karminiyah, Tawawis, Bamjkath, Wardanah, Baykand (the city of merchants), and Farbr. From Bukhara to Shargh is four farsakhs; then to Tawawis is three

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: farsakhs; then to Kuk-Shibaghan is six farsakhs, and to the south of this place are the mountains of China. From Kuk-Shibaghan to Karminiyah is four farsakhs; then to Al-Dabbusiyah is five farsakhs; then to Arbanjan is five farsakhs; then to Zarman is five farsakhs; then to Qasr Alqamah is five farsakhs; then to Samarkand is two farsakhs. (25) So from Bukhara to it is thirty-nine farsakhs. Abu al-Taqi al-Abbas bin Tarkhan said: 'Samarkand kand mand, bazinat kay afkand, az Shash nah bihi, hami shah nah jahi' [Persian verse]. Samarkand has a citadel, and its cities include Al-Dabbusiyah, Arbanjan, Kushaniyah, Ishtikhan, Kish, Nasaf, and Khujandah. From Samarkand to Barkath is four farsakhs; then to Khushufaghan, a desert journey of four farsakhs; then to Burnamadh is five farsakhs; then to Zamin

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is four farsakhs of desert. Zamin is the junction of two roads: to Shash and the Turks, and to Fergana. The road to Shash: From Zamin to Khawas is seven farsakhs of desert; then to the bank of the River of Shash (Syr Darya) at the bridge is nine farsakhs. One crosses to Banakat. From there to the River of the Turks is four farsakhs; then one crosses the River of the Turks to Shuturkath, then to Banunkath is three farsakhs; then to Shash is two farsakhs. So from Samarkand to Shash is forty-two farsakhs. From Shash to the Silver Mine is seven farsakhs, which is Ilaq and Balankank; then to Bab al-Hadid (Iron Gate) is two miles; then to Kabal is two farsakhs; then to Gharkard is six farsakhs; then to Isfijab, a desert journey of four farsakhs. So from Shash to it is thirteen farsakhs.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Then to Sharab (26) is four farsakhs; then to Badukhkat is five farsakhs; then to Tamtaj is four farsakhs; then to Abarjaj is four farsakhs; then to a station on the river is six farsakhs. At Abarjaj there is a hill surrounded by a thousand springs flowing to the east called Barkub, meaning the Inverted Water; its game consists of black pheasants. Then one crosses to Jawikath, which is five farsakhs; then to Taraz is three farsakhs. So from Isfijab to it is twenty-six farsakhs. Then to Kuwikath is seven farsakhs; and from there to the location of the King of Kimak is a journey of eighty days, during which food is carried. From Taraz to Lower Nushajan is three farsakhs; then to Kasri Bas is two farsakhs, which is a warm place where the Kharlukhs winter, and near it is the wintering ground of the Khalaj. Then to Kul Shub is four farsakhs; then to Jal Shub is four farsakhs; then to Kulan, a lush village, is four farsakhs; then

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to Barki, a great village, is four farsakhs; then to Asbarah is four farsakhs; then to Nuzkat, a great village, is eight farsakhs; then to Kharanjuwan, a great village, is four farsakhs; then to Jul is four farsakhs; then to Saragh, a great village, is seven farsakhs; then to the city of the Khagan of the Turkesh is four farsakhs; then to Nawakat is four farsakhs; then to Kabal is three farsakhs; then to Upper Nushajan, which is the border of China (27), is a journey of fifteen days for caravans regarding pasture; but for the Turkish post (Barid), it is a journey of three days. The Road from Zamin to Fergana: From Zamin to Sabat is two farsakhs; then to Usrushana is seven farsakhs, of which two farsakhs are in a plain and five farsakhs are facing flowing water from the direction of the city. So from Samarkand to Usrushana is twenty-six farsakhs. From Sabat to Ghaluk is six farsakhs; then to Khujandah is four

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: farsakhs; then to Samghar is five farsakhs; then to Khajistan is four farsakhs; then to Tarmuqan is seven farsakhs; then to the city of Bab is three farsakhs; then to Fergana is four farsakhs. So from Samarkand to Fergana is fifty-three farsakhs. Anushirvan had built it and transferred people from every household to it, naming it Azhar-khana, meaning 'from every house.' Khujandah is part of Fergana. Then to the city of Quba is ten farsakhs; then to the city of Ush is ten farsakhs; then to Uzgend, the city of Khurtakin, is seven farsakhs; then to the Pass is a journey of a day; then to Atbash is a journey of a day; then to Upper Nushajan is a journey of six days with no villages. This Atbash is a city on a high pass between Tibet and Fergana. Upper Nushajan and Tibet are in the middle of the East (28). From Upper Nushajan to the city of the Khagan of the Toghuzghuz is a journey of three

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: months through large and fertile villages. Its inhabitants are Turks among whom are Zoroastrians who worship fire, and among them are Manichaeans (Zanadiqah). The King is in a great city that has twelve gates of iron, and its people are Manichaeans. To its left is Kimak, and in front of it is China at a distance of three hundred farsakhs. The King of the Toghuzghuz has a tent of gold on top of his palace that holds nine hundred men and can be seen from five farsakhs away. As for the King of Kimak, he is in tents following the pasture. Between Taraz and his location is a journey of eighty-one days through deserts. The lands of the Turks: The Toghuzghuz, and their country is the widest of the Turkic lands, bordered by China, Tibet, and the Kharlukh; the Kimak, the Ghuz, the Jafar, the Bajanak (Pechenegs), the Turkesh, the Adhkish, the Khifshakh, the Kharkhiz, and ? Ha Misk, the Kharlukh, and the Khalaj, which are on this side of the river. As for the city of Farab, there is a garrison for the Muslims and a garrison for the Kharlukh Turks. The total number of Turkic cities is sixteen cities.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The Road from Merv al-Shahijan to Tokharistan: From Merv to Faz is seven farsakhs; then to Mahdi-abad is six farsakhs; then to Yahya-abad is seven farsakhs; then to Al-Quraynayn is five farsakhs; then to Asadabad is seven farsakhs on the river; then to Hawzan is six farsakhs on the river; then to Qasr al-Ahnaf bin Qais is four farsakhs on the river; then to Merv al-Rudh is five farsakhs; then to Araskin is five farsakhs; then to Al-Asrab is seven farsakhs; then to (29) Kunjabadh is six farsakhs; then to Al-Taligan is six farsakhs; then to Kas-hab is five farsakhs; then to Arghin is five farsakhs; then to Qasr Khut is five farsakhs; then to Al-Faryab is five farsakhs; then to Al-Qa' in the district of Juzjan is nine farsakhs; then to Al-Shaburqan is nine farsakhs; then to Al-Sidrah in Balkh is six farsakhs; then to Dastkard is five farsakhs; then to Al-Ghur is four farsakhs; then to Balkh is three farsakhs. So from Merv to Balkh is one hundred and twenty-six farsakhs. Al-Ahwas said:

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: 'Balkh and the entire Tigris are collected for him... and for him is the Euphrates and what the Nile waters.' Then to Siyah-Jard is five farsakhs; then to the bank of the Jayhun, the River of Balkh, is seven farsakhs. To the right on the bank is the district of Khulm and the Zargham River; and to the left are Merv and Khwarazm—its name is Fil, and it lies on both sides of the River of Balkh—and Amul, Zamm, the mountains of Taligan, Faryab, Al-Nakhd, and Juzjan. Kuthayyir said: 'The rain clouds watered, when they poured down, the falling places of youths in Juzjan.' And the furthest villages of Balkh. One crosses the River of Balkh to Termez, and the river strikes its wall and its city is upon stone. The Road of Chaghaniyan: From Termez to Sarmanjan is six farsakhs; then to Darzanji is six farsakhs; then to Barinji is seven farsakhs; then to Chaghaniyan is five

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: farsakhs; then to Bundha (30) is six farsakhs; then to Hamwaran is seven farsakhs, and between them is a valley with a width of three farsakhs, or two farsakhs, or less or more; then to Aban Kaswan is eight farsakhs; then to Shuman is five farsakhs; then to Washjird is four farsakhs; then to Al-Rasht, a journey of four days. Al-Rasht is the furthest part of Khorasan from that direction, and it is between two mountains where there used to be an entrance for the Turks to raid, so Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid bin Barmak hung a gate there. The Road from Balkh to Upper Tokharistan: From Balkh to Walari is five farsakhs; then to the city of Khulm is five farsakhs; then to Bahar is six farsakhs; then to Bakbanul is five farsakhs; then to Qarid Alam is seven farsakhs. Near it are the villages of Bastam bin Surah bin Amir bin Musawir. What was assessed upon Abu al-Abbas Abdullah bin Tahir from the land tax (Kharaj) of Khorasan and the territories annexed to it for the years two hundred and one and two hundred and two: Rayy, ten million dirhams; Qumis, one million one hundred thousand and six

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: and ninety thousand dirhams; Jurjan—and its cities include Namiyah, Dihistan, and Wajlah—ten million one hundred and seventy-six thousand eight hundred dirhams; Kirman, five million dirhams—and Kirman is one hundred and eighty farsakhs by (31) one hundred and seventy farsakhs, and it used to be collected for the Chosroes (Sasanians) at sixty million dirhams; Sijistan (Seistan), after the deducted amount from the land tax of the villages of Mawriq, Al-Rukhkhaj, the lands of Dawar, and Zabulistan—which is one of the frontiers of Tokharistan—is nine hundred and forty-seven thousand dirhams [Total or specific item ambiguous in source, likely total Sijistan] six million seven hundred and seventy-six thousand dirhams; The Tabasayn (Two Tabas), one hundred and thirteen thousand eight hundred and eighty dirhams, and from the arrears of Tabasayn, fifteen thousand three hundred and seventy dirhams; Quhistan, seven hundred and eighty-seven thousand eight hundred and eighty dirhams, arrears one hundred and twenty-one thousand eight hundred and seventy-nine dirhams, auxiliary taxes (Ma'awin) two thousand six hundred dirhams; Nishapur, four million one hundred and eight thousand nine hundred dirhams, of which the arrears are seven hundred and fifty-eight thousand seven hundred and twenty-four dirhams, and from the crops of auxiliary taxes eight thousand dirhams; Tus, seven hundred and forty thousand eight hundred and sixty dirhams, of which the arrears are one hundred and thirty-nine thousand and twenty dirhams, and from the crops of auxiliary taxes seven thousand seven hundred dirhams; Nisa, eight hundred and ninety-three thousand four hundred dirhams, of which the arrears are one hundred and sixty thousand three hundred and thirty-one and two-thirds and one-fifth of a dirham; Abiward, seven hundred thousand dirhams

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: (32) of which the arrears are three hundred and seventeen thousand seven hundred and four dirhams; Sarakhs, three hundred and seven thousand four hundred and forty dirhams, of which the arrears are two hundred and nine thousand six hundred dirhams; Merv al-Shahijan, one million one hundred and forty-seven thousand dirhams, of which the arrears are sixty-seven thousand one hundred and forty-four dirhams and three daniqs, and from the thicket (Al-Ajamah) forty-eight thousand six hundred and sixty-nine dirhams and a third and a fifth of a dirham; Merv al-Rudh, four hundred and twenty thousand four hundred dirhams, of which the arrears are three hundred and seventeen thousand two hundred and twenty-five and a half dirhams; Badghis, four hundred and forty thousand dirhams, of which the arrears are sixty thousand dirhams; Herat, Asfazar, and Ghandah?, one million one hundred and fifty-nine thousand dirhams, of which the arrears are forty-five thousand four hundred and fifty-four dirhams; Pushang, five hundred and fifty-nine thousand three hundred and fifty dirhams, of which the crops of auxiliary taxes are eighty-nine thousand one hundred and fifty-four dirhams; Al-Taligan, twenty-one thousand four hundred dirhams; Gharjistan, one hundred thousand dirhams and two thousand sheep; The Districts of Tokharistan: Zamm, one hundred and six thousand dirhams; Al-Faryab (33) fifty-five thousand dirhams; Al-Juzjan, one hundred and fifty-four thousand dirhams; Al-Khuttalan, Balkh, Sa'd Kharah and its mountains, one hundred and ninety-three thousand three hundred dirhams; Khulm, twelve thousand three hundred dirhams; Qabrughash, four thousand dirhams; Termez, two thousand dirhams; Al-Rob

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: and Samangan, twelve thousand six hundred dirhams; Al-Riyusharan, ten thousand dirhams; Al-Bamiyan, five thousand dirhams; Barmakhan, Jumarin, and Al-Banjar, two hundred and six thousand five hundred dirhams; Al-Termez, forty-seven thousand one hundred dirhams; Al-Binaqan, three thousand five hundred dirhams; Karran, four thousand dirhams; Shughnan, forty thousand dirhams; Wakhan, twenty thousand dirhams; Al-Mandajan, two thousand dirhams; Akhrun, thirty-two thousand dirhams; Al-Kust, ten thousand dirhams; Niham, twenty thousand dirhams; Al-Chaghaniyan, forty-eight thousand five hundred dirhams; Basara, seven thousand three hundred dirhams; Al-Washjird, one thousand dirhams; Al-Andamin and Al-Zamthan, twelve thousand and thirteen beasts; Kabul, two million five hundred thousand dirhams, and from the Ghuz captives two thousand heads valued at six hundred thousand dirhams. Kabul is one of the frontiers of Tokharistan (34) and its cities include Farwaf and Azran habemus الترمذ forte designatur locus supra (p.34 ،1) .بونذا appellatus.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: and Khawas, Khashshak, Khabrah. In Kabul there is Oud (Agarwood) which is not of high quality, coconut, saffron, and myrobalan because it borders the land of India. Nasaf, ninety thousand dirhams; Kish, one hundred and eleven thousand five hundred dirhams; Al-Buttam, five thousand dirhams; Al-Bakikin, six thousand two hundred dirhams; Rustaq Jawan, seven thousand dirhams; Rustaq Al-Ruyan, two thousand two hundred and twenty dirhams; Afnah, forty-eight thousand dirhams; Khwarazm and Kardar, four hundred and eighty-nine thousand Khwarazmian dirhams; Amul, two hundred and ninety-three thousand four hundred dirhams. Transoxiana: Bukhara, which has a citadel, one million one hundred and eighty-nine thousand two hundred Ghitrifi dirhams; Al-Sughd and the other districts under the administration of Nuh bin Asad, three hundred and twenty-six thousand four hundred dirhams, of which two hundred and eighty thousand Muhammadi dirhams are upon Fergana, and upon the cities of the Turks sixty-four thousand four hundred Khwarazmian and Musayyabi dirhams. And from the coarse Kandaji fabrics, one thousand one hundred and eighty-seven robes; and from the shovels (or iron plates) and sheets of iron, one thousand three hundred pieces, halved. The total is two million one hundred and seventy-two thousand (35) five hundred Muhammadi dirhams. Of this, upon Al-Sughd and the mine at Al-Buttam and the salt mine at Kish, and Kish, Nasaf, Al-Buttam and other districts of Sughd, is one million and eighty-nine thousand Muhammadi dirhams; Usrushana

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: fifty thousand dirhams, of which forty-eight thousand are Muhammadi dirhams and two thousand are Musayyabi; Shash and the Silver Mine, six hundred and seven thousand one hundred Musayyabi dirhams; Khujandah, one hundred thousand Musayyabi dirhams. So the total land tax of Khorasan and what was annexed to Abu al-Abbas Abdullah bin Tahir from the districts and administrations is forty-four million eight hundred and forty-six thousand dirhams; and from the beasts for riding, thirteen heads; and from the sheep, two thousand sheep; and from the Ghuz captives, two thousand heads valued at six hundred thousand dirhams; and from the Kandaji fabrics, one thousand one hundred and eighty-seven robes; and from the shovels and sheets of iron, one thousand three hundred pieces, halved. Titles of the Kings of Khorasan and the East: King of Nishapur, Kanar; King of Merv, Mahoe; King of Sarakhs, Zadhoe; King of Abiward, Bahmanah; King of Nisa, Abraz; King of Gharjistan, Baraz-bandah; King of Merv al-Rudh, Kaylan; King of Zabulistan, Firuz; King of Kabul, Kabul-Shah (38). Abu al-Adhafir said: 'He did not leave Kabul or Zabulistan, and what is around them up to the two Rukhkhajs.' King of Termez, Termez-Shah; King of Bamiyan, Shir-Bamiyan; King of Sughd,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Firuz; King of Fergana, Ikhshid; King of Al-Riyusharan, Al-Riyushar; King of Juzjan, Kuzkan-Khudah; King of Khwarazm, Khusraw-Khwarazm; King of Al-Khuttal, Khuttalan-Shah, and it is said Shir-Khuttalan; King of Bukhara, Bukhara-Khudah; King of Usrushana, Afshin; King of Samarkand, Tarkhan; King of Sijistan, Al-Rukhkhaj and the lands of Dawar, Rutbil. Abd al-Malik bin Marwan said: 'Oh, how far is the casting place of a corpse whose head is in Egypt and whose body is in Al-Rukhkhaj.' King of Herat, Pushang and Badghis, Barazan; King of Kish, Nidun; King of Al-Buttam, Dhu al-Na'na'ah; King of Wardanah, Wardan-Shah; King of Jurjan, Sul; and King of Transoxiana, Kushan-Shah. The Kings of the Turks: Haylub Khagan, Jabghuya Khagan, Shabah Khagan, Sinjbu Khagan, Manush Khagan.

Fayruz Khaqan. Among the minor kings of the Turks are Tarkhan, Nizak, Khurtagin, Tamrun, Ghuzak, Suhrab, and Furak. [Section: Post-Stages of the Eastern Road] From Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) to Al-Daskarah is twelve post-stages. From the City of Peace (Baghdad) to (39) Al-Daskarah is ten post-stages. Then to Jalula, four post-stages. Then to Hulwan, ten post-stages. Then to Nasirabadh, nine post-stages. Then to Qarmasin, six post-stages. Then to Khandadh, ten post-stages. Then to Hamadhan, three post-stages. Then to Mashkuyah, twenty-one post-stages. Then to Rayy, eleven post-stages. Then to Qumis, twenty-three post-stages. Then to Nishapur, nineteen post-stages. [Section: The Road to the Districts of Jibal, Wasit, Ahwaz, and Fars] The levy of Shahrazur, Al-Samaghan, and Darabadh is two million seven hundred and fifty thousand dirhams. From Hulwan to Shahrazur is nine post-stages. From Hulwan to Sirwan, the city of Masabadhan, is seven post-stages. From Sirwan to Al-Saymarah, the city of Mihrajanqadhaq, is four post-stages. The land tax of Masabadhan and Mihrajanqadhaq is three million five hundred thousand dirhams. From Hamadhan to Qom is forty-seven parasangs. The land tax of Qom is two million dirhams.

From Al-Zarqa to Qom is three post-stages. From Qom to Isfahan is sixteen post-stages. From Madharan to Nihawand is three post-stages. From the City of Peace (Baghdad) to Wasit of Iraq is twenty-five post-stages. (40) Abu Nakhila said: "Al-Anbar has become a populated abode, While the abodes of Homs, Qinnasrin, and Al-Muwaqqar have been ruined by hypocrisy, And at Wasit nothing remains but the soft ground (or croaking frogs)." Between Wasit and the border of Suq al-Ahwaz is twenty post-stages. Then to Arrajan, twenty post-stages. Then to Al-Nubandajan, seventeen post-stages. Then to Shiraz, twelve post-stages. Then to Istakhr, five post-stages. [Section: Districts of Ahwaz] The district of Suq al-Ahwaz, Ramhormuz, Idhaj, Askar Mukram, Tustar, Jundishapur, Al-Sus, Surraq which is Dawraq, Nahr Tira, Manadhir al-Kubra, and Manadhir al-Sughra. The land tax of Ahwaz is thirty million dirhams. The Persians used to assess the tax on Khuzestan, which is Ahwaz, at fifty million dirhams. The lands of Ahwaz are vast, consisting of seven districts. Al-Fadl ibn Marwan informed me...

...that he accepted the contract for Ahwaz for forty-nine million dirhams and that he spent seventy thousand dirhams on its maintenance. [Section: The Road from Suq al-Ahwaz to Fars] From Ahwaz to Azam is six parasangs. From there to Abdin is five parasangs. Then to (41) Ramhormuz, six parasangs. Then to Al-Zutt, six parasangs. Then to a difficult ford and a long bridge over Wadi al-Milh (Salt Valley). Then to Dahlizan, eight parasangs. Then to Arrajan, eight parasangs. Abu al-Shammaqmaq said: "Allah wanted to reward Jamil, So He empowered me over him at Arrajan." It has a Kisra-style bridge, more than three hundred cubits long, made of stone over the valley of Arrajan. From Arrajan to Dasin is five parasangs. Then to Bandak, six parasangs, and in it is the Pass of the Elephant (Aqabat al-Fil). Then to Khan Hammad, six parasangs. Then to Al-Darkhuwid, four parasangs. Then to Al-Nubandajan, eight or six parasangs. Then to Karjan, five parasangs, containing the Pass of Bawwan, which has...

...walnut trees, olives, and fruits growing in the rock. Then to Al-Kharrarah, seven parasangs, containing the Pass of Clay (Aqabat al-Tin). Then to Juwayn, five parasangs. Then to Shiraz, five parasangs. Shiraz is from [Section: The District of Ardashir Khurrah] Its rural districts (rustaqs) are: Jur, Maymand, Khabr, Al-Saymakan, Al-Barjan, Karan, Al-Karbanjan, Al-Khawarustan, Kir, Kizarin, Abzar, Samiran, Tawwaj, Karzin, Siniz, Siraf, Kawar, Al-Ruwayhan, and Kam Firuz. From Suq al-Ahwaz to Dawraq by water is eighteen parasangs, and by land is twenty-(42) four parasangs.

[Section: District of Sabur] Its city is Al-Nubandajan. Its rural districts are: Al-Khisht, Al-Kimarij, Kazerun, Khurrah, Bandarahman, Dast Barin, Al-Hindijan, Al-Darkhuwid, Tanbuk, Al-Khubadhan, Al-Maydan, Mahan, Al-Junbudh, Al-Ramijan, Al-Dibanjan, Al-Shahijan, Mawz, Dadhin, Al-Shadrudh, Darbakhanjan, Al-Siyah Mass, Ibnuran, Khamarjan Lower, Khamarjan Upper, and Tirmardan. [Section: District of Istakhr] It is the city...

...and its rural districts are: The White City (Al-Madinah Al-Bayda), Nahran, Wasan, Iraj, Ma'in, Khabr Istakhr, Yazad, Abarquh, Al-Baranjan, Al-Mayadwan, Al-Kaskan, and Al-Hazar. From Shiraz to the city of Fasa, in the district of Darabjird, is thirty parasangs. From Fasa to Darabjird is eighteen parasangs. [Section: Rural Districts of Darabjird] Kurm, Jahram, Nayriz, Al-Bustijan, Al-Abjird, Al-Andiyan, Juwaym, Furj, Tarum, and Tamistan. [Section: District of Arrajan] Its rural districts are...

...Bash, Rishahr, Aslanjan, Al-Mallajan, and Farzak. From Shiraz to the city of (43) Jur is twenty parasangs. From there to Al-Bayda is seven parasangs. From Al-Nubandajan to Shiraz is twenty-three parasangs. Between Shiraz and Sabur is twenty parasangs. Between Shiraz and Jur is twenty parasangs. From Shiraz to the city of Istakhr is twelve parasangs. From Shiraz to Zarqan is four parasangs, then to Istakhr is eight parasangs. [Section: The Encampments (Zumum) of the Kurds in Fars] They are four encampments, and the interpretation of Zumum is the locations of the Kurds. Among them is the Zimm of al-Hasan ibn Jilwayh, called Al-Bazanjan, fourteen parasangs from Shiraz. The Zimm of Ardam ibn Juwanah, twenty-six parasangs from Shiraz. The Zimm of al-Qasim ibn Shahrbaraz, called Al-Kuriyan, fifty parasangs from Shiraz. And the Zimm of al-Hasan ibn Salih, called Al-Suran, seven parasangs from Shiraz. The districts of Fars are five districts: Istakhr, Sabur, Ardashir Khurrah, Darabjird, Arrajan, and Fasa.

It is one hundred fifty-five parasangs by one hundred fifty parasangs. The land tax of Fars by sufficiency (contract) is thirty-three million dirhams. Al-Fadl ibn Marwan informed me that he accepted its contract for thirty-five million dirhams by sufficiency, on the condition that there is no burden on the Sultan. The Persians used to assess the districts of Fars at forty million weight-dirhams (mithqals). (44) [Section: The Road from Shiraz to Kirman, then to Sijistan] From Shiraz to Al-Radiyan is seven parasangs. Then to Kharramah, two parasangs. Then to Al-Baranjan, four parasangs. Then to Kand, six parasangs. Then to Al-Hirah, six parasangs. Then to Bi'r Aqaba, five parasangs. Then to Al-Mayskanan, eight parasangs. Then to Sahik, eight parasangs. Then to Sarushak, seven parasangs. Then to Shahr Babak, seven parasangs. Then to Qasr al-Nu'man, eight parasangs. Then to the village of Aban, four parasangs. Then to Al-Marjan, four parasangs. Then to Bimand of Kirman...

...Kirman has the following cities: Al-Qufs, Al-Bariz, Al-Maraj, Al-Balus, and Jiroft, which is its greatest city, although the governor resides in Al-Sirjan. Then to the city of Al-Sirjan, four parasangs. Then to Quhistan, six parasangs. Then to Quradah, six parasangs. Then to Rustaq, six parasangs. Then to the city of Khannab, four parasangs. Then to Al-Ghubayra, five parasangs. Then to Khan Juzan, five parasangs. Then to Khan Khukh, six parasangs. Then to Sarwistan, seven parasangs. Then to the city of Diruzin, five parasangs. Then to Bam, nine parasangs. Then to Narmashir, seven parasangs. Then to Al-Fahraj, which is at the edge of the desert, seven parasangs. The desert is seventy parasangs to Sijistan. Then to Al-Ahsa' and Al-Abar (The Wells), eight (45) parasangs. Then to Jurj Manarah, nine parasangs, a station without water. Then to Ribat Ba'idah, seven parasangs. Then...

...to Asbidh, nine parasangs. Then to Karaghan, eight parasangs. Then to Bi'r al-Qadi (The Judge's Well), eight parasangs. Then to Rashid, which has one well, six parasangs. Then to Kawnishk, which has a rainwater cistern, four parasangs. Then to Bardin, which has a cistern, eight parasangs. Then to Jarun, which has wells, five parasangs. Then to the city of Sijistan, six parasangs. Sijistan has the following cities: Zaliq, Karkuyah, Haysum, Zaranj, Rawisht, Basward, and Al-Qarnayn, which has the trace of Rustam's horse tether. Its river is the Hindmand. Also Al-Rukhkhaj and the lands of al-Dawur, which is the kingdom of Rustam the Strong; Kaykaus made him king over it. From the city of Sijistan to the city of Herat is eighty parasangs. [Section: The Road from Shiraz to Nishapur] From Shiraz to Al-Zarqan is six parasangs. Then to the Bridge of Al-Kusahan...

...two parasangs. Then to Istakhr, four parasangs. Then to Bard, three parasangs. Then to a station with a well, nine parasangs. Then to Jah, five parasangs. Then to Al-Karjar, four parasangs. Then to Karkulan, five parasangs. Then to Hindask, seven parasangs. Then to Mihrabadh, three parasangs. Then to Abarquyah, three parasangs. Then to Muhajir, (46) ten parasangs. Then to Qasr al-Asad, fifteen parasangs. Then to Qasr al-Jawz, seven parasangs. Then to Al-Qal'ah, five parasangs of sand. Then to the city of Yazd, six parasangs. Then to Anjirah, six parasangs. Then to Khazanah, thirteen parasangs. Then to Saghand, twelve parasangs. Then to Ribat Muhammad ibn Yazdad, eight parasangs. Then to Khan Ashtaran, six parasangs. Then to Al-Haba'ik, seven parasangs. Then to Juwaran...

...four parasangs. Then to Tamharhan, four parasangs. Then to Al-Tabasin, eight parasangs. Then to the village of Muhammad ibn Kharrazadh, four parasangs. Then to Sarkhadh, four parasangs. Then to Afridhun, twelve parasangs. Then to Zanjy, twelve parasangs. Then to Al-Turaythith, four parasangs. Then to Khaksir, eight parasangs. Then to the villages of Quhistan, four parasangs. Then to Al-Hawar, six parasangs. Then to Aqbarasah, six parasangs. Then to Nishapur, six parasangs. From the city of Nishapur to the city of Herat is eighty parasangs. [Section: The Road from Shiraz to Darabjird] From Shiraz to the village of Bakkar is three parasangs. Then to the village of Al-Rumman, four parasangs. Then to Khuristan, nine parasangs. Then to Kurm, five parasangs. Then to the city of Fasa, four parasangs. Then to...

...Tamistan, four parasangs. Then to Al-Fustakan, six parasangs. Then (47) to Fasarudh, four parasangs. Then to Darabjird, eight parasangs. [Section: The Road from Istakhr to Al-Sirjan, the city of Kirman] From Istakhr to Hafr is seven parasangs. Then to Al-Buhayrah, five parasangs. Then to Asbanjan, seven parasangs. Then to the Village of Myrtle (Qaryat al-As), four parasangs. Then to Al-Sahik al-Kubra, six parasangs. Then to the Village of Salt (Qaryat al-Milh), nine parasangs. Then to Muryanah, eight parasangs. Then to Rawan, three parasangs. Then to Al-Marjan, which is the end of the work of Fars, ten parasangs. From Shiraz to this place is seventy-one parasangs. Then to Al-Rawth, three parasangs. Then to Farman, two parasangs. Then to Al-Sirjan, the city of Kirman, eleven parasangs. So, from the end of the work of Fars to Al-Sirjan is sixteen parasangs.

Then to Narmashir, seven parasangs. Then to Al-Fahraj, which is the edge of the desert, four parasangs. The desert is seventy parasangs. From Al-Marjan to the city of Bimand in the work of Kirman is four parasangs. Then to the city of Al-Sirjan, four parasangs. Then to Al-Arha', six parasangs. Then to Istur, four parasangs. Then to Khan Salim, eight parasangs. Then to Ba'khtah, eight parasangs. Then to Wadi Quhandiz, twelve parasangs. Then to Asbidhanah, four parasangs. Then to Al-Ma'dan (The Mine), four parasangs. Then to Al-Ribat, four parasangs. Then to Jiroft, four parasangs. From Jiroft to Bam is twenty (48) parasangs. Then to Nahr Sulayman, twenty parasangs. Then to Al-Dihqan, fifty parasangs. Then to Makran, Al-Mansurah, and the lands of Sindh. From Jiroft to the beginning of the work of Makran is forty-one parasangs. [Section: The Road from Al-Fahraj to Sindh]

From Al-Fahraj to Al-Tabaran in the work of Makran is ten parasangs. Then to Basurjan, the city of the Kharun, fourteen parasangs. Then to the village of Yahya ibn Amr, ten parasangs. Then to Hadhar, ten parasangs. Then to Madar, ten parasangs. Then to Musarah, nine parasangs. Then to Darak Bamawayh, nine parasangs. Then to Tajin, ten parasangs. Then to the Crossing of the Baluch (Muqata'at al-Balus), twenty parasangs. Then to the Salty Mountain (Al-Jabal al-Malih), six parasangs. Then to Al-Nakhl, nine parasangs. Then to Qalaman, six parasangs. Then to Saray Khalaf, four parasangs. Then to Fannazbur, three parasangs. Then to Hays on the road to Qandabil, a desert, twenty parasangs. Then to Saray Daran, ten parasangs. Then to Al-Jaythah, ten parasangs. Then to Qasdar, ten parasangs. From Qasdar to Al-Jur is forty parasangs. Then to Asrushan, forty parasangs. Then to the village of Sulayman ibn Sami', twenty-eight parasangs; and this village of Sulayman is the port of entry for those coming from Khorasan intending Sindh and India. Then to...

...Al-Mansurah, eighty parasangs. (49) So from the beginning of the work of Makran to Al-Mansurah is three hundred and fifty-eight parasangs. The road is in the land of the Zutt, and they are guards of the road. From Zaranj, the city of Sijistan, to Al-Multan is a journey of two months. Al-Multan was named "Farj Bayt al-Dhahab" (The Frontier of the House of Gold) because Muhammad ibn Yusuf, the brother of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf, found in a house there forty Bahars of gold. A Bahar is three hundred and thirty-three Manns. So it was named Farj Bayt al-Dhahab, and "Al-Farj" means the frontier. The total of that gold is two million three hundred and ninety-seven thousand six hundred Mithqals. [Section: Lands of Sindh] Al-Qayqan, Bannah, Makran, Al-Mid, and Al-Qandahar - Ibn Mufarrigh said: "In Qandahar, and whoever's death is written in Qandahar, news of him will be stoned (unknown/cut off)." - Qasdar, Al-Buqan, Qandabil, Fannazbur, Armabil, Al-Daybul, Qanbali, Kanbaya, Suhban, Sadusan, Rasik, Al-Rur, Sawandari, Al-Multan...

...Sandan, Al-Mandal, Al-Baylaman, Surasht, Al-Kiraj, Marmad, Qali, Dahanj, and Barus. Imran ibn Musa al-Barmaki farmed the tax of Sindh on the condition (50) that he would carry from it, after all expenses, one million dirhams. [Section: Lands of the Pahlavis] Rayy, Isfahan, Hamadhan, Dinawar, Nihawand, Mihrajanqadhaq, Masabadhan, and Qazvin. In Qazvin is the City of Musa and the City of Al-Mubarak. Between Qazvin and Rayy is twenty-seven parasangs. Qazvin is the frontier of Daylam. And Zanjan; between it and Qazvin is twenty-seven parasangs. From Zanjan to Abhar is fifteen parasangs. From Abhar to Qazvin is twelve parasangs. Also Al-Babir, Al-Taylasan, and Al-Daylam. The land tax of Qazvin is one million two hundred thousand dirhams. [Section: The Road from Ahwaz to Isfahan] From Idhaj to Juwardan is three parasangs. Then to Rustajird, four parasangs. Then to Salidast, six parasangs. Then to Bawin, five...

...parasangs. Then to Sawjar, six parasangs. Then to Al-Ribat, seven parasangs. Then to Khan al-Abrar, seven parasangs. From the Khan to Isfahan is seven parasangs. [Section: The Road from Fars to Isfahan] From Fars to Kam Firuz is five parasangs. Then to Kurd, five parasangs. Then to Tajab, four parasangs. Then to Samaram, five parasangs. Then to Siyah, five (51) parasangs. Then to Al-Burjan, seven parasangs. Then to Kibali, six parasangs. Then to Khan al-Abrar, then to Isfahan. [Section: The Road from Isfahan to Rayy] From Al-Yahudiyyah to Barkhwar is three parasangs. Then to Ribat Wazz, seven parasangs. Then to Anbariz, five parasangs. Then to Ad'afuh, six parasangs. Then to Al-Daffar, four parasangs. Then to Badh, five parasangs. Then to Abruz, five parasangs. Then to Hawadir, nine parasangs.

Then to Al-Muqatta'ah, five parasangs. Then to Qaris, nine parasangs. Then to Qom, six parasangs. From Qaris to Al-Dayr is seven parasangs. Then to Dazah, seven parasangs. Then to Rayy, seven parasangs. [Section: The Road from Baghdad to Basra] From Baghdad to Al-Mada'in - Hamid ibn Sa'id said: "O homes of Al-Mada'in, you are the adornment of dwellings." Then to Dayr al-Aqul. Then to Jarjaraya. Then to Jabbal. Then to Fam al-Sulh. Then to Wasit. Then to Nahr Aban. Then to Al-Faruth. Then to Dayr al-Ummal. Then to Al-Hawanit. Then you travel in the Qatr (region/land). Then in the Bata'ih (Marshes). Then in Nahr Abi al-Asad. Then in Tigris al-Awra'. Then in Nahr Ma'qil. Then in Fayd al-Basra. (52) [Section: The Road from Surra Man Ra'a to Wasit by Post] From Surra Man Ra'a to Ukbara is nine post-stages. Then to Baghdad, six post-stages. Then to Al-Mada'in, three post-stages. Then to Jarjaraya, eight post-stages. Then to Jabbal, five post-stages. Then to Wasit, eight post-stages. The Jawali (poll-tax) of Wasit is thirty thousand dirhams. The alms-tax (Sadaqat) of the Arabs in Basra is six million dirhams. [Section: The Road from Basra to Oman along the Coast]

From Basra to Abadan. Then to Al-Huduthah. Then to Arfaja. Then to Al-Zabuqah. Then to Al-Maqarr. Then to Asa. Then to Al-Mu'arras. Then to Khalijah. Then to Hassan. Then to Al-Qura. Then to Musaylihah. Then to Hamd. Then to the coast of Hajar. Then to Al-Uqayr. Then to Qatar. Then to Al-Sabkhah. Then to Oman, which consists of Suhar and Daba. [Section: The Distance to the East by Sea] From Basra to Abadan is twelve parasangs. Then to Al-Khashabat, two parasangs. Then you enter the sea; its right bank belongs to the Arabs and its left bank to Fars. Its width is seventy parasangs. In it are the mountains of Kusayr and Uwayr, and its depth is seventy to eighty fathoms. From Al-Khashabat to the city of Bahrain on the coast of the Arabs is seventy parasangs. Its people are pirates who prey on (53) ships; they have no crops, but they have palms and camels. A Bedouin said: "Cast into the desolate wastelands, By the coast of Bahrain for the young ones." From there to Al-Dardur is one hundred fifty parasangs. Then to Oman, fifty parasangs. Then to Al-Shihr, two hundred parasangs. From Al-Shihr to...

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Aden is one hundred farsakhs, and it is one of the great harbors. It has no crops or livestock, but it has ambergris, oud (aloeswood), musk, and merchandise from Sindh, India, China, Zanj (East Africa), Abyssinia, Fars, Basra, Jeddah, and Al-Qulzum. This sea is the Great Eastern Sea. Good ambergris comes from it, and upon it are the lands of Zanj, Abyssinia, and Fars. In it are fish one hundred to two hundred fathoms long; ships are feared for because of them, so they are scared away by beating wood against wood. In it are fish the size of a cubit that fly, and their faces are like the faces of owls. In it are fish twenty cubits long; inside its belly is another like it, and inside the other is another like it, up to four fish. In it are turtles; the circumference of a turtle is twenty cubits, and inside its belly are about a thousand eggs, and their backs are the good tortoiseshell. In it are fish shaped like cows that give birth and suckle, and shields are made from their skins. And fish shaped like camels. In it are birds that gather on the debris of the sea when it is calm, laying eggs and hatching chicks on the surface of the water without going out to land. The Road from Basra to the East along the coast of Fars (54): From Basra to the Island of Khark is fifty farsakhs; it is one farsakh by one farsakh and has crops, vines, and palm trees. From there to the Island of Lawan is eighty farsakhs; it is two farsakhs by two farsakhs and has crops and palm trees. Then to the Island of Abarun is seven farsakhs; it is one farsakh by one farsakh and has crops and palm trees. Then

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to the Island of Khin is seven farsakhs; it is half a mile by half a mile and has no inhabitants. Then to the Island of Kays is seven farsakhs; it is four farsakhs by the same, and contains palm trees, crops, and livestock, and it has diving for good pearls. Then to the Island of Ibn Kawan is eighteen farsakhs; it is three farsakhs by three farsakhs, and its people are Ibadhi Kharijites (Shurat). From the Island of Ibn Kawan to Ormuz is seven farsakhs. Then to Thara is a journey of seven days, and it is the border between Fars and Sindh. From Thara to Daybul is a journey of eight days. From Daybul to the mouth of the Mehran, the River of Sindh (Indus), in the sea is two farsakhs. From Sindh comes costus, cane (*Qana*), and bamboo (*Khayzuran*). From Mehran to Utkin, which is the first land of India, is a journey of four days. In this land, cane grows in its mountains and crops in its valleys, and its people are rebellious brigands. From there, at two farsakhs, are the Meds (Al-Mid), who are thieves. From there to Kuli is two farsakhs. From Kuli to Sindan is eighteen farsakhs; it has teak and cane. From Sindan to Mali is a journey of five days; Mali has pepper and cane. Sailors mentioned that every bunch of pepper has a leaf

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: sheltering it from the rain (55). When the rain stops, the leaf lifts, and when the rain returns, it returns. From there to Ballin is a journey of two days. From there to the Great Abyss (*Al-Lujjah al-Uzma*) is a journey of two days. From Ballin, the routes separate in the sea. Whoever takes the coastal route: from Ballin to Babattan is a journey of two days; it is a land of rice and provides provisions for the people of Serendib. From Babattan to Al-Sinjili and Kabshkan is a journey of one day, and it has rice. From there to the mouth of Kudafarid is three farsakhs. From there to Kaylakan, Al-Lawwa, and Kanja is a journey of two days, and it has wheat and rice. From there to Samandar is ten farsakhs; it has rice, and aloeswood is brought to it from a distance of

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: fifteen to twenty days journey through fresh water from Kamrun and other places. From Samandar to Uranshin is twelve farsakhs; it is a great kingdom with elephants, beasts, buffaloes, and many goods, and its king is of high status. From Uranshin to Abina is a journey of four days, and it also has elephants. Whoever travels from Ballin to Serendib (Sri Lanka), it is a journey of one day. Serendib is eighty farsakhs by eighty farsakhs. On it is the mountain upon which Adam, blessings of Allah be upon him, descended. It is a mountain reaching into the sky, seen by those in ships at sea from a distance of days. The Brahmins, who are the ascetics of India, mentioned that on this mountain is the imprint of Adam's foot, blessings of Allah be upon him, sunken into the stone, about seventy cubits long for a single foot. On this mountain there is something like lightning constantly. Adam, blessings of Allah be upon him, took the next step (56) into the sea, which is at a distance of two or three days from it. On this mountain and around it are rubies of all colors and similar gems; in its valley are diamonds. On the mountain are aloeswood, pepper, perfume, spices, the musk animal, and the civet animal. In Serendib there are coconuts, and its land contains emery (*Sinbadij*) used to polish gems. In its rivers is crystal, and around it in the sea is pearl diving.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: After Serendib is the Island of Al-Rami. It has the rhinoceros (*Karkaddan*), which is a beast smaller than an elephant and larger than a buffalo; it eats grass and ruminates like cows and sheep. It has buffaloes with no tails, bamboo, and brazilwood (*Baqqam*); its root is a cure for rapid poison, which sailors have tested against snake bites. It has naked people in thickets whose speech is not understood because it is whistling. They are small and shy away from people; the height of a human among them is four spans. The men have small penises and the women have small vulvas. The hair on their heads is red down. They climb trees with their hands without placing their feet on them. In the sea are white people who swim alongside ships; the ship moves at the speed of the wind. They sell ambergris for iron, carrying it in their mouths. There is an island with black people with frizzy hair who eat people alive, slicing them up. There is a mountain whose clay turns to silver if fire touches it. In the mountains of Zabaj (Java/Sumatra region) are huge snakes that swallow a man or a buffalo, and some of them swallow an elephant. It has camphor trees; a single tree can shade one hundred people, more or less. The top of the tree is drilled, and several jars of camphor water flow from it; then a hole is made lower than that in the middle of the tree, and pieces of camphor flow out (57), which is the gum of that tree, except it is inside it. Then that tree becomes invalid and dries up. In this island are many uncounted wonders.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Whoever wants China should turn from Ballin and keep Serendib on his left. From Serendib to the Island of Nikbalus (Nicobar) is a journey of ten to fifteen days. Its people are naked, their food is bananas, fresh fish, and coconut. Their wealth is iron, and they sit with merchants. From the Island of Nikbalus to the Island of Kalah is a journey of six days. It is the kingdom of Jaba the Indian. It contains mines of Qala'i lead (tin) and places where bamboo grows. To its left is the Island of Balus, at a journey of two days. Its people eat humans. It has good camphor, bananas, coconuts, sugar cane, and rice. From there to the Island of Jaba, Shalahit, and Harlah is two farsakhs. It is great, and its king wears gold jewelry and a gold cap and worships the Buddhas (?). It has coconuts, bananas, and sugar cane. In Shalahit are sandalwood, spikenard, and cloves. In Jaba is a small mountain at the peak of which is a fire that burns about one hundred cubits by the same; its thickness is a spear's length. By day it is smoke, and by night it is fire. Then a journey of fifteen days to the lands where perfume grows. Between Jaba and Mayit is a short distance. The kings of India and its people permit fornication but forbid wine, except the King of Qumar,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: for he forbids fornication and wine. The King of Serendib has wine brought to him from Iraq and drinks it. The kings of India desire tall (58) elephants and pay much gold to increase their prices. The tallest are nine cubits, except for the elephants of Aghbab, which are ten and eleven cubits. The greatest of the kings of India is Balhara, which means King of Kings. The engraving on his ring is 'Whoever loves for a matter gives guardianship [even] with his separation.' He dwells in Kamkum, the land of teak. After him is King Al-Tafin. After him is Jaba. After him is the King of Al-Jurz, who has the Tatariya dirhams. After him is Ghaba. After him is Rahmi; between him and these others is a journey of a year, and they mentioned that he has fifty thousand elephants, and he has velvet cotton garments and Indian oud (aloeswood). Then after him is the King of Qamrun; his kingdom connects to China. In his country is much gold and the rhinoceros (*Karkaddan*), which is a beast with a single horn on its forehead, a cubit long and two fists thick. Within it is an image from the beginning of the horn to its end; if split, you see the image white in black like ink, in the form of a human, a beast, a fish, a peacock, or other birds. The people of China make belts from it; a belt reaches a price between three hundred

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: dinars to three thousand dinars to four thousand dinars. All these kings have pierced ears. The King of Zabaj is called Al-Mahraj. In his kingdom is an island called Bartayil where music and drums are heard all night long; the sailors say that the Dajjal (Antichrist) is there. Horses emerge from the sea like our horses, with manes that drag on the ground. Al-Mahraj has a daily revenue amounting to (59) two hundred *mann* of gold; he makes bricks from it and throws them into the water, saying, 'This is my treasury.' And an island where there are monkeys like donkeys. Part of his revenue from cockfighting in a day is about fifty *mann* of gold; that is because he gets the thigh of the winning cock, so its owner redeems it. The Road to China: From Mayit, bearing left, to the Island of Tiyumah, which has Indian oud and camphor. From there to Qumar is a journey of five days; Qumar has Qumari oud and rice. From Qumar to Al-Sanf (Champa) on the coast is a journey of three days. It has Sanfi oud, which is better than Qumari because it sinks in water due to its quality and weight. It has cows and buffaloes. Among the famous cities of India are Samil, Hurin, Qalun, Qandahar, and Kashmir.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From Al-Sanf to Luqin, which is the first of the ports of China, is one hundred farsakhs by land and sea. It has Chinese stone, Chinese silk, good Chinese porcelain, and rice. From Luqin to Khanfu (Canton), which is the greatest port, is a journey of four days by sea and twenty days by land. It has all kinds of fruits, vegetables, wheat, barley, rice, and sugar cane. From Khanfu to Khanju is a journey of eight days, and it has the same as in Khanfu. From Khanju to Qantu is a journey of twenty days, and it has the same. Each of the ports of China (60) has a great river that ships enter, having tides. Flour, ducks, and chickens have been seen in the river of Qantu. The length of the land of China along the sea from Armabil to its end is a journey of two months. China has three hundred populated cities, all of them, ninety of which are famous. The border of China is from the sea to Tibet and the Turks, and to the west to India. In the eastern parts of China are the lands of Waqwaq, which are rich in gold, so much so that its people make the chains of their dogs and the collars of their monkeys from gold. They bring shirts woven with gold for sale. In Waqwaq there is good ebony.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Ishtiyamu the sailor was asked about the tide. They mentioned that in the Sea of Fars it only occurs with the rising of the moon, and it does not occur in the Great Sea except twice a year: once it rises in the summer months towards the northeast for six months, and when that happens, the water floods the eastern parts of the sea in China and recedes from the western parts of the sea; and once it rises in the winter months towards the southwest for six months, and when that happens, the water floods the western parts of the sea and recedes in China. At the end of China, opposite Qansu, are many mountains and many kings; this is the land of Al-Sila (Korea). It has much gold, and whoever enters it from among the Muslims settles there because of its pleasantness, and what is beyond it is unknown. What comes through this Eastern Sea from China is silk, *Firand* silk, (61) *Kimkhaw* (damask), musk, oud, saddles, sable, porcelain, cinnamon, and galangal. From Waqwaq comes gold and ebony. From India come various woods (*A'wad*), sandalwood, camphor, *Makafur*, nutmeg, cloves, cardamom, cubeb, coconut, cloth made from grass, velvet cotton cloth, and elephants. From Serendib come rubies of all colors and similar gems, diamonds, pearls, crystal, and emery used to polish gems. From Mali

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
