text: and Sindan comes pepper. From Kalah comes Qala'i lead (tin). From the southern region come brazilwood and *Dhadhi*. From Sindh come costus, cane, and bamboo. The length of this sea from Al-Qulzum to Waqwaq is four thousand five hundred farsakhs. What comes from Yemen is *Washi* fabric, their other garments, ambergris, *Wars* (dye), mules, and donkeys. The Indians are of seven classes: The Shakthariya, who are their nobles among whom is the King; all classes prostrate to them, but they do not prostrate to anyone. The Brahmins; they do not drink wine or fermented drinks. The Kastariya; they drink only three cups; the Brahmins do not marry them, but they marry into them. The Shudariya, who are farmers. The Bishiya, who are artisans and craftsmen. The Sandaliya, who are people of entertainment and melodies, and their women possess beauty. The Dhanbiya, who are dark-skinned (62) people of entertainment, musical instruments, and games. The sects of the people of India are forty-two sects. Some of them affirm the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, and the Messengers; some of them deny the Messengers; and some are deniers of all that. The Indians claim that they can achieve what they want through incantations, giving poison to drink

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: and extracting it from the one who was given it. They possess imagination and thought, and with it, they bind and unbind, harm and benefit. They manifest illusions that bewilder the intelligent, and they claim to withhold rain and hail. The news of the East has ended. The News of the West: The West is a quarter of the kingdom. Its commander (Isbahbadh) during the era of the Persians was called Kharbaran Isbahbadh. The Road from the City of Peace (Baghdad) to the West: From Baghdad to Al-Saylahin is four farsakhs. Then to Al-Anbar is eight farsakhs. Then to Al-Rabb is seven farsakhs. Then to Hit is twelve farsakhs. Abu al-Amaythal said: 'Did he not visit Hit for our night, or before that, the night of Al-Anbar?' Then to Al-Nawusa is seven farsakhs. Then to Al-Wasa is seven farsakhs. Then

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to Al-Fahimah is six farsakhs. Then to Al-Nuhiyah is twelve farsakhs in the desert. Then to Al-Daziqi (63) is six farsakhs. Then to Al-Furdah is six farsakhs. Then to Wadi al-Siba' is six farsakhs. Then to the Gulf of Bani Jami' is five farsakhs. Then to Al-Fash, opposite Qarqisiya, is seven farsakhs. Then to Nahr Sa'id is eight farsakhs. Then to Al-Jardan is fourteen farsakhs. Then to Al-Mubarak is eleven farsakhs. Then to Al-Raqqa is eight farsakhs; in Roman (Greek) it is Callinicum. Al-Raqqa is the center of Diyar Mudar, and it is Al-Rafiqah. Harran, in Roman, is Hellenopolis. Sadif said: 'I used to consider myself tough, but I was weakened by a grave in Harran containing the protection of religion.' Edessa (Al-Ruha), Samosata, Saruj, Ra's Kayfa, the White Land, Tal Muzan, Al-Rawabi, Al-Mazihin, and Al-Mudaybir. The land tax (Kharaj) of Diyar Mudar is five million

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: and six hundred thousand dirhams. The estimate of Al-Rusafa, Al-Zaytuna, Kafra Hajar, and Al-Jazirah is four thousand dinars. The Administration of the Euphrates: Qarqisiya, which is on the Euphrates and the Khabur, Al-Rahba, Al-Daliya, Ana, Hit, Al-Haditha, and Al-Rabb. The Cities of the Districts of Khabur: Al-Suwar, Al-Fadayn, Maksin, and Al-Shamsaniyah. (64) Al-Akhtal said: 'Its corpse became beside Al-Hoshak, and its head, short of it is the Khabur, then Al-Suwar.' And Al-Sukayr, Araban, Taban, Upper Taninir, Lower Taninir, and Samagha. These cities are on the Khabur. The Stations from Raqqa to Dawsar. Then to Balis, having crossed the Euphrates. Then to Khushaf. Then to Al-Na'ura. Then to Aleppo. Then to Qinnasrin and its districts.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The Districts of Qinnasrin: The district of Ma'arrat Misrin, the district of Murtahuwan, the district of Sarmin, Hiyar Bani al-Qaqa, the district of Duluk, the district of Ra'ban, and the district of Aleppo. The Awasim (Border Fortresses): The district of Qurus, the district of Al-Juma, the district of Manbij, the district of Antioch, the district of Tizin, Buqa, Balis, and Rusafa Hisham. The land tax of Qinnasrin and the Awasim is four hundred thousand dinars. Then from Qinnasrin to Shayzar. Then to Hama. Then to Homs. The Regions of Homs: As for its regions, they are the region of Hama and the region of Shayzar. Imru' al-Qais said: 'The friends of longing and youth were cut off, on the evening we passed Hama and Shayzar.' And the region of Famiya, the region of Ma'arrat al-Nu'man, the region of Sawaran, the region of Latmin, the region of Tal Mannas, the region of Al-Ghalas, the region of Kafartab, the region of Jusiya, the region of Lebanon, the region of Al-Sha'ira, and five regions

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: [including] Al-Ultamah, the region of Al-Bal'as, the region of Al-Bara, the region of Al-Rastan, the region of Zamin, the region of Al-Qastal, the region of Salamiyah, the region of Uqburta, the region of Al-Jalil, (65) the region of Al-Suwayda, Rafniya, and Tadmur (Palmyra). The Coasts: The district of Latakia, the district of Jabala, the district of Balniyas, the district of Antarsus, the district of Marqiya, Qasira, Al-Saqi, Jarthaba, Al-Hula, 'Amlu, Zandak, and Qabrata. The land tax of Homs is three hundred and forty thousand dinars. The Road from Homs to Damascus: From Homs to Jusiya is sixteen miles. Then to Qara is thirty miles. Then to Al-Nabk is twelve miles. Then to Al-Qutayfah is twenty miles. Then to Damascus is twenty-four miles. Damascus is Iram of the Pillars. It was formerly the abode of Noah, blessings of Allah be upon him. From Mount Lebanon was the beginning of his Ark, and it settled on Al-Judi, the mountain of Qardu. When the children of

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Noah multiplied, they settled in Babylon of the Sawad under the rule of Nimrod son of Cush, who was the first king on earth. The District of Damascus and its Regions: The plain of Ghuta, the region of Sanir, the city of Baalbek, Al-Biqa, the region of Lebanon, the district of Juniya, the district of Tripoli, the district of Jubayl, the district of Beirut, the district of Sidon, the district of Al-Bathniya, the district of Hawran, the district of Jawlan, the exterior of Al-Balqa, the mountain of Al-Ghur, the district of Ma'ab, the district of Jabal, the district of Al-Sharat, the district of Busra, the district of Amman, and Al-Jabiya. Hassan bin Thabit said: (66) 'Before Busra and before it is the Mountain of Snow (Mount Hermon); upon it the clouds are like leather strips.' Another said: 'Greet the remains that have become desolate in Amman, and ask the quarter; does it reply with an explanation?' The land tax of Damascus is four hundred thousand dinars and a fraction. The Road from Damascus to Tiberias:

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From Damascus to Al-Kiswa is twelve miles. Then to Jasim is twenty-four miles. Hassan bin Thabit said: 'Jasim has been effaced, then Bayt Ras, then Al-Jawab, then the Harith of Jawlan.' Then to Fiq is twenty-four miles. Then to Tiberias, the city of Jordan, is six miles. The District of Jordan: The district of Tiberias, the district of Samaria, the district of Baysan, the district of Fahl, the district of Jarash, the district of Bayt Ras. Hassan said: 'As if a vintage wine from Bayt Ras, its mixture is honey and water.' The district of Jadar, the district of Abil, the district of Susiya, the district of Saffuriya, the district of Acre, the district of Qadas, the district of Tyre. The land tax of Jordan is three hundred and fifty thousand dinars. The Road from Tiberias (67) to Ramla: From Tiberias to Al-Lajjun is twenty miles. Then to Qalansuwa is twenty miles. Then to Ramla, the city of Palestine, is twenty-four miles. The District of Palestine: The district of Ramla, the district of Iliya—which is Jerusalem (Bayt al-Maqdis), and between it and Ramla is eighteen miles. Jerusalem was the abode of the kingdom of David and Solomon, peace be upon them, and Rehoboam son of Solomon and the children of Solomon. From Jerusalem

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to the Mosque of Abraham, blessings of Allah be upon him, and his grave is thirteen miles towards the Qibla. The district of Emmaus (*Amwas*). Ibn Kulthum al-Kindi said: 'Many a desert tract like the crescent moon, and a chaste white woman at the winding valley of Amwas.' The district of Lydda (*Ludd*). The poet said: 'O my friend, I have performed Hajj and visited Jerusalem, and entered Lydda intending the feast of Saint George.' The district of Yibna, the district of Jaffa, the district of Caesarea, the district of Nablus, the district of Sebastia, the district of Ashkelon, the district of Gaza, and the district of Bayt Jibrin. The land tax of Palestine is five hundred thousand dinars. From Ramla to Jaffa, which is the nearest frontier port to them and is on the sea: from Ramla to it is eight miles. From Jerusalem to the Stinking Lake (Dead Sea) is undoubtedly four miles. Salt comes out of the Stinking Lake .... suitable for goldsmiths, and abundance called bitumen (*Al-Hummar*), which is the asphalt of the Jews. It is said that the Jordan river, which pours into the Stinking Lake, comes out in the land of India ...... a defeated man came and dove ...... and brought out something. The Road from Ramla to Fustat:

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From Ramla to Azdud is twelve miles. (68) Then to Gaza is twenty miles. Then to Rafah is sixteen miles. Then to Al-Arish is twenty-four miles in sand. Then to Al-Warrada is eighteen miles. Then to Al-Tha'ama is eighteen miles. Then to Al-Udhayb in sand is twenty miles. Then to Al-Farama (Pelusium) is twenty-four miles. Al-Ma'mun said: 'To Layla, he was shorter at the hippodrome than he was at Al-Farama, a stranger in the villages of Egypt enduring worry and regret.' Then to Jirjir is thirty miles. Then to Al-Ghadira is twenty-four miles. Then to Masjid Quda'a is eighteen miles. Then to Bilbeis is twenty-one miles. Then to Fustat, the city of Egypt, is twenty-four miles. He said: Egypt was named after Misr son of Ham son of Noah, blessings of Allah be upon him, and from his offspring are the Copts and the Berbers. The land of Egypt is defined as a journey of forty nights by the same. Egypt was the abode of the Pharaohs, and its name was Macedonia. Fustat is the tent of...

Amr ibn al-Aas at Bab al-Yun (Babylon), the King of the Romans said: 'I mean Ibn Layla Abd al-Aziz at Bab al-Yun, his bowls boil with music.' The Provinces (Kuras) of Egypt: Kura of Memphis (Manf) and Wasim, Kura of Dalas, Kura of al-Sharqiyya, Kura of Busir, Kura of Fayyum, Kura of Ahnas, Kura of al-Qays, Kura of Taha, Kura of al-Ashmunayn, (69) Kura of Asyut, Kura of Qahqa, Kura of al-Bahnasa, Kura of Akhmim and al-Dayr, Kura of Abshayah, Kura of Hu and Qina, Kura of Qift and Luxor (al-Uqsur), Kura of Esna and Armant and Sababah, Kura of Aswan, Kura of Sababah al-Maghrib, Kura of Bab al-Nubah, Kura of Alexandria, and al-Qulzum and al-Tur and Ayla. The Kuras of Masil and al-Mulaydis, Kura of Qartasa, Kura of Kharbata,

Amr ibn al-Aas at Bab al-Yun (Babylon), the King of the Romans said: 'I mean Ibn Layla Abd al-Aziz at Bab al-Yun, his bowls boil with music.' The Provinces (Kuras) of Egypt: Kura of Memphis (Manf) and Wasim, Kura of Dalas, Kura of al-Sharqiyya, Kura of Busir, Kura of Fayyum, Kura of Ahnas, Kura of al-Qays, Kura of Taha, Kura of al-Ashmunayn, (69) Kura of Asyut, Kura of Qahqa, Kura of al-Bahnasa, Kura of Akhmim and al-Dayr, Kura of Abshayah, Kura of Hu and Qina, Kura of Qift and Luxor (al-Uqsur), Kura of Esna and Armant and Sababah, Kura of Aswan, Kura of Sababah al-Maghrib, Kura of Bab al-Nubah, Kura of Alexandria, and al-Qulzum and al-Tur and Ayla. The Kuras of Masil and al-Mulaydis, Kura of Qartasa, Kura of Kharbata,

Kura of al-Badaqun, Kura of Sa and Shabas, Kura of Sakha, Kura of Tida, Kura of al-Afrahun, Kura of Lubya, Kura of al-Awsiyya, Kura of Tuh, Kura of Lower Manuf, Kura of Damsis, Kura of Upper Manuf, Kura of Atrib, Kura of Ayn Shams, Kura of Farasta, Kura of Tata and Tamy, Kura of Samannud, Kura of San and Iblil, Kura of al-Bajum, Kura of Sa'ira, Kura of Farhala, Kura of Ikhna and Rashid, al-Hawf al-Sharqi, al-Hawf al-Gharbi, al-Buhayrah, Asfal al-Ard (Lower Land), Batn al-Rif, al-Bashrud, al-Sa'id (Upper Egypt), Tinnis, Damietta on the Jar, al-Farama, Daqahla, Batira, Naqiza, Basta, Atrabiya, Qarbit, al-Khays,

Kura of al-Badaqun, Kura of Sa and Shabas, Kura of Sakha, Kura of Tida, Kura of al-Afrahun, Kura of Lubya, Kura of al-Awsiyya, Kura of Tuh, Kura of Lower Manuf, Kura of Damsis, Kura of Upper Manuf, Kura of Atrib, Kura of Ayn Shams, Kura of Farasta, Kura of Tata and Tamy, Kura of Samannud, Kura of San and Iblil, Kura of al-Bajum, Kura of Sa'ira, Kura of Farhala, Kura of Ikhna and Rashid, al-Hawf al-Sharqi, al-Hawf al-Gharbi, al-Buhayrah, Asfal al-Ard (Lower Land), Batn al-Rif, al-Bashrud, al-Sa'id (Upper Egypt), Tinnis, Damietta on the Jar, al-Farama, Daqahla, Batira, Naqiza, Basta, Atrabiya, Qarbit, al-Khays,

and al-Badaqun, al-Sharak, Tarnut, Shatnuf, Barnil, Ansina, Shutb, Dabruwah, Bumina, Tuna, Shata, and Dabiq. The people of the Maghreb and the Copts were under the rule of the Romans. The length of Egypt is from the two trees between Rafah and Al-Arish to Aswan, and its width is from Barqa to Ayla. It is a journey of forty nights by forty nights. From Baghdad to Egypt is five hundred and seventy parasangs (farsakh), (70) which is one thousand seven hundred and ten miles. Above Egypt are Nubia, the Beja, and Abyssinia. Uthman ibn Affan made a treaty with Nubia for four hundred heads (slaves) per year. The land tax (Kharaj) of Egypt in the days of Pharaoh was ninety-six million dinars. Abd Allah ibn al-Habhab collected two million seven hundred and twenty-three thousand eight hundred and thirty-seven dinars from it in the days of the Umayyads.

and al-Badaqun, al-Sharak, Tarnut, Shatnuf, Barnil, Ansina, Shutb, Dabruwah, Bumina, Tuna, Shata, and Dabiq. The people of the Maghreb and the Copts were under the rule of the Romans. The length of Egypt is from the two trees between Rafah and Al-Arish to Aswan, and its width is from Barqa to Ayla. It is a journey of forty nights by forty nights. From Baghdad to Egypt is five hundred and seventy parasangs (farsakh), (70) which is one thousand seven hundred and ten miles. Above Egypt are Nubia, the Beja, and Abyssinia. Uthman ibn Affan made a treaty with Nubia for four hundred heads (slaves) per year. The land tax (Kharaj) of Egypt in the days of Pharaoh was ninety-six million dinars. Abd Allah ibn al-Habhab collected two million seven hundred and twenty-three thousand eight hundred and thirty-seven dinars from it in the days of the Umayyads.

Musa ibn Isa carried from it in the Abbasid state two million one hundred and eighty thousand dinars. The Road from Fustat to the Maghreb: From Fustat to Dhat al-Sahil (?) is twenty-four miles, then to Tarnut thirty miles, then to Kawm Sharik twenty-two miles, then to al-Rafiqa twenty-four miles along the Nile, then to Qartasa thirty miles, then to Karyun twenty-four miles, then to Alexandria twenty-four miles, then to Rumina twenty miles, then to Dhat al-Hamam eighteen miles, then to Haniyat al-Rum thirty-four miles, then to al-Tahuna thirty miles, then to Kana'is al-Hadid twenty-four miles, then to Jubb al-Awsaj - there is no water there except rain water - thirty miles, then to Sikkat al-Hamam thirty miles, then to Qasr al-Shammas twenty-five (71) miles, then to Kharbat al-Qawm fifteen miles, then to Khara'ib Abi Halima thirty-five miles, then to al-Aqaba twenty miles, then to Marj al-Shaykh twenty miles, then to Hayy Abd

Musa ibn Isa carried from it in the Abbasid state two million one hundred and eighty thousand dinars. The Road from Fustat to the Maghreb: From Fustat to Dhat al-Sahil (?) is twenty-four miles, then to Tarnut thirty miles, then to Kawm Sharik twenty-two miles, then to al-Rafiqa twenty-four miles along the Nile, then to Qartasa thirty miles, then to Karyun twenty-four miles, then to Alexandria twenty-four miles, then to Rumina twenty miles, then to Dhat al-Hamam eighteen miles, then to Haniyat al-Rum thirty-four miles, then to al-Tahuna thirty miles, then to Kana'is al-Hadid twenty-four miles, then to Jubb al-Awsaj - there is no water there except rain water - thirty miles, then to Sikkat al-Hamam thirty miles, then to Qasr al-Shammas twenty-five (71) miles, then to Kharbat al-Qawm fifteen miles, then to Khara'ib Abi Halima thirty-five miles, then to al-Aqaba twenty miles, then to Marj al-Shaykh twenty miles, then to Hayy Abd

Allah thirty miles, then to Jiyad al-Saghir thirty miles, then to Jubb al-Mayda'an thirty-five miles, then to Wadi Makhil thirty-five miles, then to Jubb Haliman thirty-five miles, then to al-Maghar thirty-five miles, then to Taknist twenty-five miles, then to al-Nadama twenty-five miles, then to Barqa six miles. It is a city in a red desert, looking like a beautiful unripe date, surrounded by mountains. Between the mountains and the city is six miles. The poet said: 'The foot of Barqa I have trodden, Where the hyena and the wolf settle.' The Road from Barqa to the Maghreb: Then from Barqa to Malitiya is fifteen miles, then to Qasr al-Asal twenty-nine miles, then to Awbran twelve miles, then to Suluq thirty miles, then to Barsamat on the coast twenty-four miles, then to Bilbid on the coast twenty miles, then to Ajdabiya

Allah thirty miles, then to Jiyad al-Saghir thirty miles, then to Jubb al-Mayda'an thirty-five miles, then to Wadi Makhil thirty-five miles, then to Jubb Haliman thirty-five miles, then to al-Maghar thirty-five miles, then to Taknist twenty-five miles, then to al-Nadama twenty-five miles, then to Barqa six miles. It is a city in a red desert, looking like a beautiful unripe date, surrounded by mountains. Between the mountains and the city is six miles. The poet said: 'The foot of Barqa I have trodden, Where the hyena and the wolf settle.' The Road from Barqa to the Maghreb: Then from Barqa to Malitiya is fifteen miles, then to Qasr al-Asal twenty-nine miles, then to Awbran twelve miles, then to Suluq thirty miles, then to Barsamat on the coast twenty-four miles, then to Bilbid on the coast twenty miles, then to Ajdabiya

twenty-four miles, then to Haqra twenty miles, then to Sabkhat Manhusha thirty miles, then to Qasr al-Atash thirty-four miles, then to al-Yahudiyyatayn thirty-four miles on the sea, then to Qabr al-Abadi thirty-four miles, (72) then to Sirte (Surt) thirty-four miles, then to al-Qaryatayn thirteen miles, then to Qusur Hassan ibn al-Nu'man al-Ghassani thirty miles, then to al-Munsaf forty miles, then to Tawurgha twenty-four miles, then to Raghagha twenty miles, then to Wardasa eighteen miles. The poet said: 'The Berbers met a misfortune one day, And fate drove them to Wardasa.' Then to al-Muhtana twenty-two miles, then to Wadi al-Raml twenty miles, then to Tripoli (Tarabulus) twenty-four miles, then to Sabratha twenty-four miles, then to Bi'r al-Jammalin twenty miles, then to Qasr al-Daraq thirty miles, then to Abardakht twenty-four miles, then to al-Fawwarah thirty miles, then to Gabes (Qabis), the city of the non-Arab Africans (Afariqa), thirty miles, then to Bi'r al-Zaytunah thirteen miles, then to Katana

twenty-four miles, then to Haqra twenty miles, then to Sabkhat Manhusha thirty miles, then to Qasr al-Atash thirty-four miles, then to al-Yahudiyyatayn thirty-four miles on the sea, then to Qabr al-Abadi thirty-four miles, (72) then to Sirte (Surt) thirty-four miles, then to al-Qaryatayn thirteen miles, then to Qusur Hassan ibn al-Nu'man al-Ghassani thirty miles, then to al-Munsaf forty miles, then to Tawurgha twenty-four miles, then to Raghagha twenty miles, then to Wardasa eighteen miles. The poet said: 'The Berbers met a misfortune one day, And fate drove them to Wardasa.' Then to al-Muhtana twenty-two miles, then to Wadi al-Raml twenty miles, then to Tripoli (Tarabulus) twenty-four miles, then to Sabratha twenty-four miles, then to Bi'r al-Jammalin twenty miles, then to Qasr al-Daraq thirty miles, then to Abardakht twenty-four miles, then to al-Fawwarah thirty miles, then to Gabes (Qabis), the city of the non-Arab Africans (Afariqa), thirty miles, then to Bi'r al-Zaytunah thirteen miles, then to Katana

twenty-four miles, then to al-Yusr thirty miles, then to Kairouan (al-Qayrawan), the city of nosebags (al-Makhali), twenty-four miles. It is the city of Ifriqiya and is in the middle of the Maghreb. It is in the hands of Ibn al-Aghlab. Also in his hands are Gabes, Jalula, Sbeitla (Subaytla) - the city of King Jurjir (Gregory), who was Roman, and between it and Kairouan is seventy miles - Zarud, Ghadames, Qalsana, Gafsa (Qafsa), Qastiliya, the city of al-Zab, Tahuda, Salsaman, Waddan, Tafrjil, Zaghouan, and Tunis. Between Ifriqiya and it is two stages on (73) mules. The name of the city of Tunis is Carthage (Qartajanna). It is on the coast of the sea; its wall circumference is twenty-one thousand cubits. Between Tunis and the mainland of al-Andalus is the width of the sea, which is six parasangs there. Then to Cordoba (Qurtuba), the city of al-Andalus, is a journey of five days. In the hands of the Ibadi Rustamid, who is Maymun ibn Abd al-Wahhab ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Rustam, and he is of Persian origin, and is greeted as Caliph... [missing text?]... Rud

Between Tunis and the mainland of al-Andalus is the width of the sea, which is six parasangs there. Then to Cordoba (Qurtuba), the city of al-Andalus, is a journey of five days. In the hands of the Ibadi Rustamid, who is Maymun ibn Abd al-Wahhab ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Rustam, and he is of Persian origin, and is greeted as Caliph... [missing text?]... Rud

and Salamah and Salamiyah and Tiaret (Tahart) and what adjoins it. Between Ifriqiya and Tiaret is a month's journey on camels. And the city of Ceuta (Sabta) next to al-Khadra'. The king of Ceuta is Lyman. In the hands of Ibn Saghir the Masmudi Berber is Khalfana to Wadi al-Raml and Wadi al-Zaytun and Qasr al-Aswad ibn al-Haytham to Tripoli and what is beyond that to the Sea of al-Andalus. In the hands of the Sufri Kharijite is Draa (Dar'a), a large city with many inhabitants containing a silver mine, located towards the south near the land of Abyssinia, and a city called Ziz. In the hands of Ibrahim ibn Muhammad the Mu'tazilite Berber is a city next to Tiaret called Ayzarj. In the hands of the descendants of Idris ibn Idris (74) ibn Abd Allah ibn Hasan ibn Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah have mercy on them, is Tlemcen (Tilimsan). From Tiaret to it is a journey of twenty-five days, all inhabited. And Tangier (Tanja) and Fez (Fas),

and Salamah and Salamiyah and Tiaret (Tahart) and what adjoins it. Between Ifriqiya and Tiaret is a month's journey on camels. And the city of Ceuta (Sabta) next to al-Khadra'. The king of Ceuta is Lyman. In the hands of Ibn Saghir the Masmudi Berber is Khalfana to Wadi al-Raml and Wadi al-Zaytun and Qasr al-Aswad ibn al-Haytham to Tripoli and what is beyond that to the Sea of al-Andalus. In the hands of the Sufri Kharijite is Draa (Dar'a), a large city with many inhabitants containing a silver mine, located towards the south near the land of Abyssinia, and a city called Ziz. In the hands of Ibrahim ibn Muhammad the Mu'tazilite Berber is a city next to Tiaret called Ayzarj. In the hands of the descendants of Idris ibn Idris (74) ibn Abd Allah ibn Hasan ibn Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah have mercy on them, is Tlemcen (Tilimsan). From Tiaret to it is a journey of twenty-five days, all inhabited. And Tangier (Tanja) and Fez (Fas),

where his residence is. From Tiaret to it is a journey of twenty-four nights. Behind it is Tangier, and behind Tangier is al-Sus al-Adna (Lower Sus), which is two thousand one hundred and fifty miles from Kairouan, and its people are Berbers. Behind al-Sus al-Adna is al-Sus al-Aqsa (Farthest Sus), and between them is a journey of twenty-odd days. In his hands are Walila, Madraka, Matruka, the city of Zaqqur, Ghazza, Ghamira, al-Hajir, Tajrajra, Fankur al-Khadra' - which is on the sea, and the width of the sea there is six parasangs - and Awaris and what connects to the land of Zaghi ibn Zaghi and the naked Sudan (Blacks) to what aligns with it from the coastal regions. He is not greeted as Caliph, but rather it is said: Peace be upon you, O son of the Messenger of Allah. In the hands of the Umayyad, who is a descendant of Abd al-Rahman ibn Muawiyah ibn Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan ibn al-Hakam, is what is beyond the sea, the land of al-Andalus. It is Cordoba, and between it and the coast is a journey of five nights. From the coast of Cordoba, Granada to Narbonne (Arbuna), which is the end of al-Andalus next to the land of the Franks (Faranja), is a thousand miles. And Toledo (Tulaytula), where (75) the King used to reside. From Toledo to Cordoba is twenty nights. Al-Andalus has forty cities, including Merida (Marida), Zaragoza (Saraqusta),

where his residence is. From Tiaret to it is a journey of twenty-four nights. Behind it is Tangier, and behind Tangier is al-Sus al-Adna (Lower Sus), which is two thousand one hundred and fifty miles from Kairouan, and its people are Berbers. Behind al-Sus al-Adna is al-Sus al-Aqsa (Farthest Sus), and between them is a journey of twenty-odd days. In his hands are Walila, Madraka, Matruka, the city of Zaqqur, Ghazza, Ghamira, al-Hajir, Tajrajra, Fankur al-Khadra' - which is on the sea, and the width of the sea there is six parasangs - and Awaris and what connects to the land of Zaghi ibn Zaghi and the naked Sudan (Blacks) to what aligns with it from the coastal regions. He is not greeted as Caliph, but rather it is said: Peace be upon you, O son of the Messenger of Allah. In the hands of the Umayyad, who is a descendant of Abd al-Rahman ibn Muawiyah ibn Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan ibn al-Hakam, is what is beyond the sea, the land of al-Andalus. It is Cordoba, and between it and the coast is a journey of five nights. From the coast of Cordoba, Granada to Narbonne (Arbuna), which is the end of al-Andalus next to the land of the Franks (Faranja), is a thousand miles. And Toledo (Tulaytula), where (75) the King used to reside. From Toledo to Cordoba is twenty nights. Al-Andalus has forty cities, including Merida (Marida), Zaragoza (Saraqusta),

Narbonne, Girona (Jarunda), and al-Bayda'. Al-Andalus borders the land of the Franks and the adjoining lands of Polytheism. Al-Andalus is a journey of more than a month by a month. It is fertile, abundant in good things and fruits. The mountains of al-Andalus facing the North, the Romans, and the Franks have snow. At the end of that direction is a mountain with fire burning in stones and soil that has never been extinguished. The king of al-Andalus when it was conquered was called Roderic (Ludhariq) from the people of Isfahan; due to Isfahan, the people of Cordoba were named al-Isban (Spanish). This Umayyad is greeted with "Peace be upon you, O son of the Caliphs," because they do not consider the title of Caliphate applicable except to the one who controls the Two Holy Sanctuaries. The Tribes of the Berbers: Hawwara, Zanata, Amtaha, Darisa, Maghila, Warfajuma - which is from Nafza, Walita, Matmata, Sanhaja, Nafza, Kutama, Lawata, Mazata, Zabbuja, Nafusa, Lamta, Saddina, Masmuda, Ghamara, Qulla, Awraba,

Narbonne, Girona (Jarunda), and al-Bayda'. Al-Andalus borders the land of the Franks and the adjoining lands of Polytheism. Al-Andalus is a journey of more than a month by a month. It is fertile, abundant in good things and fruits. The mountains of al-Andalus facing the North, the Romans, and the Franks have snow. At the end of that direction is a mountain with fire burning in stones and soil that has never been extinguished. The king of al-Andalus when it was conquered was called Roderic (Ludhariq) from the people of Isfahan; due to Isfahan, the people of Cordoba were named al-Isban (Spanish). This Umayyad is greeted with "Peace be upon you, O son of the Caliphs," because they do not consider the title of Caliphate applicable except to the one who controls the Two Holy Sanctuaries. The Tribes of the Berbers: Hawwara, Zanata, Amtaha, Darisa, Maghila, Warfajuma - which is from Nafza, Walita, Matmata, Sanhaja, Nafza, Kutama, Lawata, Mazata, Zabbuja, Nafusa, Lamta, Saddina, Masmuda, Ghamara, Qulla, Awraba,

Atita, Banu Samjun, Abkata - which is from Nata, Banu Warkilan, Banu Yasduran, Banu Wartaji, and Banu Manhusa. (76) The abode of the Berbers was Palestine, and their king was Goliath (Jalut). When David, peace be upon him, killed him, the Berbers migrated to the Maghreb until they reached Lubya and Maraqiya, where they dispersed. Zanata and Maghila and ?????? and Farsana settled in the mountains. Lawata settled in the land of Barqa, which is Antabulus (Pentapolis) in Greek, meaning five cities. Hawwara settled in the city of Iyas, which is Tripoli (Atrabulus), meaning three cities. It belonged to the Romans, so the Romans migrated to Sicily, an island in the sea. Then the Berbers spread to al-Sus al-Adna behind Tangier, which is the city of Qamuniya, two thousand one hundred and fifty miles from the site of Kairouan.

Atita, Banu Samjun, Abkata - which is from Nata, Banu Warkilan, Banu Yasduran, Banu Wartaji, and Banu Manhusa. (76) The abode of the Berbers was Palestine, and their king was Goliath (Jalut). When David, peace be upon him, killed him, the Berbers migrated to the Maghreb until they reached Lubya and Maraqiya, where they dispersed. Zanata and Maghila and ?????? and Farsana settled in the mountains. Lawata settled in the land of Barqa, which is Antabulus (Pentapolis) in Greek, meaning five cities. Hawwara settled in the city of Iyas, which is Tripoli (Atrabulus), meaning three cities. It belonged to the Romans, so the Romans migrated to Sicily, an island in the sea. Then the Berbers spread to al-Sus al-Adna behind Tangier, which is the city of Qamuniya, two thousand one hundred and fifty miles from the site of Kairouan.

Then the Africans and Romans returned to their cities under a truce with the Berbers. The Berbers disliked settling in the cities, so they settled in the mountains and sands. The cities returned to being Roman until the Muslims conquered them. Rome (Rumiya), Burjan, the lands of the Slavs (Saqaliba), and the Abar are north of al-Andalus. What comes from the Western Sea are Slavic, Roman, Frankish, and Lombard servants, Roman and Andalusian slave girls, skins of beaver (Khazz) and hyrax (Wabar). From perfumes, Storax (May'a). From pharmaceuticals, Mastic (Mastaka). Coral (Bussadh), which the common people call Marjan, is extracted from the bottom of this sea near the land of the Franks.

Then the Africans and Romans returned to their cities under a truce with the Berbers. The Berbers disliked settling in the cities, so they settled in the mountains and sands. The cities returned to being Roman until the Muslims conquered them. Rome (Rumiya), Burjan, the lands of the Slavs (Saqaliba), and the Abar are north of al-Andalus. What comes from the Western Sea are Slavic, Roman, Frankish, and Lombard servants, Roman and Andalusian slave girls, skins of beaver (Khazz) and hyrax (Wabar). From perfumes, Storax (May'a). From pharmaceuticals, Mastic (Mastaka). Coral (Bussadh), which the common people call Marjan, is extracted from the bottom of this sea near the land of the Franks.

As for the sea behind the Slavs, upon which lies the city of Thule (Tuliya), no ship or boat sails in it, nor does anything come from it. Similarly, the sea containing the Fortunate Isles (Jaza'ir al-Sa'ada) cannot (77) be sailed, nor does anything come from it; it is also western. He said: I found the entire earth to be a journey of five hundred years: one third is inhabited civilization, one third is uninhabited deserts, and one third is seas. I found the land of Abyssinia and the Sudan (Blacks) to be a journey of seven years. The land of Egypt is one part out of sixty parts of the land of the Sudan, and the land of the Sudan is one part out of sixty parts of the whole earth. The Road from Baghdad to Raqqa via Mosul: From Baghdad to al-Baradan four parasangs, then to Ukbara five parasangs, then to Bahamsha three parasangs, then to al-Qadisiyya seven parasangs, then to Samarra (Surra Man Ra'a) three parasangs, then to al-Karkh two parasangs, then to Jabalta seven parasangs, then to al-Sawdaqaniya five parasangs, then to Baramma five parasangs, then to al-Sinn - where the Lesser Zab is - five parasangs, then to al-Haditha - where the Greater Zab is - twelve parasangs, then to Bani Tumyan seven parasangs, then to the city of Mosul seven parasangs.

As for the sea behind the Slavs, upon which lies the city of Thule (Tuliya), no ship or boat sails in it, nor does anything come from it. Similarly, the sea containing the Fortunate Isles (Jaza'ir al-Sa'ada) cannot (77) be sailed, nor does anything come from it; it is also western. He said: I found the entire earth to be a journey of five hundred years: one third is inhabited civilization, one third is uninhabited deserts, and one third is seas. I found the land of Abyssinia and the Sudan (Blacks) to be a journey of seven years. The land of Egypt is one part out of sixty parts of the land of the Sudan, and the land of the Sudan is one part out of sixty parts of the whole earth. The Road from Baghdad to Raqqa via Mosul: From Baghdad to al-Baradan four parasangs, then to Ukbara five parasangs, then to Bahamsha three parasangs, then to al-Qadisiyya seven parasangs, then to Samarra (Surra Man Ra'a) three parasangs, then to al-Karkh two parasangs, then to Jabalta seven parasangs, then to al-Sawdaqaniya five parasangs, then to Baramma five parasangs, then to al-Sinn - where the Lesser Zab is - five parasangs, then to al-Haditha - where the Greater Zab is - twelve parasangs, then to Bani Tumyan seven parasangs, then to the city of Mosul seven parasangs.

The Kuras of Mosul: Tikrit, and opposite it in the desert is the city of al-Hadr (Hatra). The king of Hatra was al-Satirun ibn al-Dayzan. Adi ibn Zayd said: (78) 'And the brother of al-Hadr when he built it, And when the Tigris was collected for him, and the Khabur.' Al-Tayrhan, al-Sinn, al-Haditha, Marj Juhayna, Nineveh - the city of Jonah son of Matthew, peace be upon him - Bajli, Bahadra, Ba'adhra, Habtun, Banqula, Hazza, Babghash, al-Mughalla, Ramin, al-Hanaya, Bajarma - which contains Khunya Sabur - Daquqa, and Khanijar. The land tax of Mosul is four million dirhams.

The Kuras of Mosul: Tikrit, and opposite it in the desert is the city of al-Hadr (Hatra). The king of Hatra was al-Satirun ibn al-Dayzan. Adi ibn Zayd said: (78) 'And the brother of al-Hadr when he built it, And when the Tigris was collected for him, and the Khabur.' Al-Tayrhan, al-Sinn, al-Haditha, Marj Juhayna, Nineveh - the city of Jonah son of Matthew, peace be upon him - Bajli, Bahadra, Ba'adhra, Habtun, Banqula, Hazza, Babghash, al-Mughalla, Ramin, al-Hanaya, Bajarma - which contains Khunya Sabur - Daquqa, and Khanijar. The land tax of Mosul is four million dirhams.

The Road from Mosul to Nusaybin: From Mosul to Balad seven parasangs, then to Ba'inatha six parasangs, then to Barqa'id six parasangs, then to Adhrama six parasangs, then to Tall Farasha five parasangs, then to Nusaybin four parasangs. Nusaybin is the city of Diyar Rabi'a. The Kuras of Diyar Rabi'a: Nusaybin, Arzan, Amid, Ra's Ayn, Mayyafariqin - the poet said: 'In Amid once and in Ra's Ayn, And sometimes in Mayyafariqin' - Mardin, Ba'arbaya, Balad, Sinjar, Qarda, and Bazabda. The poet said: 'In Qarda and Bazabda a summer resort, And a spring camp and sweet water resembling Salsabil, cool.' (79) And Tur Abdin. The poet said: 'The King of al-Hadr and the Euphrates, so what is the Tigris eastwards? The Tur (Mountain) is from Abdin.' The land tax of Diyar Rabi'a is seven million seven hundred thousand dirhams. From Nusaybin to Dara five parasangs, then to Kafartutha seven parasangs, then to Ra's Ayn seven parasangs, then to al-Jarud five parasangs, then to Hisn Maslama six parasangs, then to Bajrawan seven parasangs. The poet said: 'May Allah water the Balikh and Tall Bahri, And Bajrawan on the main road.' Then to Raqqa three parasangs. The Road from Nusaybin to Arzan on the Right:

The Road from Mosul to Nusaybin: From Mosul to Balad seven parasangs, then to Ba'inatha six parasangs, then to Barqa'id six parasangs, then to Adhrama six parasangs, then to Tall Farasha five parasangs, then to Nusaybin four parasangs. Nusaybin is the city of Diyar Rabi'a. The Kuras of Diyar Rabi'a: Nusaybin, Arzan, Amid, Ra's Ayn, Mayyafariqin - the poet said: 'In Amid once and in Ra's Ayn, And sometimes in Mayyafariqin' - Mardin, Ba'arbaya, Balad, Sinjar, Qarda, and Bazabda. The poet said: 'In Qarda and Bazabda a summer resort, And a spring camp and sweet water resembling Salsabil, cool.' (79) And Tur Abdin. The poet said: 'The King of al-Hadr and the Euphrates, so what is the Tigris eastwards? The Tur (Mountain) is from Abdin.' The land tax of Diyar Rabi'a is seven million seven hundred thousand dirhams. From Nusaybin to Dara five parasangs, then to Kafartutha seven parasangs, then to Ra's Ayn seven parasangs, then to al-Jarud five parasangs, then to Hisn Maslama six parasangs, then to Bajrawan seven parasangs. The poet said: 'May Allah water the Balikh and Tall Bahri, And Bajrawan on the main road.' Then to Raqqa three parasangs. The Road from Nusaybin to Arzan on the Right:

From Nusaybin to Dara five parasangs, then to Kafartutha seven parasangs, then to Qasr Bani Nazi' six parasangs, then to Amid - which is on the Tigris - seven parasangs, then to Mayyafariqin five parasangs, then to Arzan seven parasangs. The Road from Amid to Raqqa on the Left: From Amid to Shamshat seven parasangs, then to Tall Jafr five parasangs, then to Jarnan six parasangs, then to Bamiqada five parasangs, then to Jallab (80) seven parasangs, then to al-Ruha (Edessa) four parasangs, then to Harran four parasangs, then to Tall Mahra four parasangs, then to Bajrawan seven parasangs, then to Raqqa three parasangs. The Road from Balad to Sinjar then to Circesium (Qarqisiya) on the Left: From Balad to Tall A'far five parasangs, then to Sinjar seven parasangs, then to Ayn al-Jibal five parasangs, then to Sukayr al-Abbas on the Khabur nine parasangs, then to al-Fadayn on the Khabur five parasangs, then to Maksin on the Khabur six parasangs, then to Circesium - which is on the Euphrates and the Khabur - seven parasangs.

From Nusaybin to Dara five parasangs, then to Kafartutha seven parasangs, then to Qasr Bani Nazi' six parasangs, then to Amid - which is on the Tigris - seven parasangs, then to Mayyafariqin five parasangs, then to Arzan seven parasangs. The Road from Amid to Raqqa on the Left: From Amid to Shamshat seven parasangs, then to Tall Jafr five parasangs, then to Jarnan six parasangs, then to Bamiqada five parasangs, then to Jallab (80) seven parasangs, then to al-Ruha (Edessa) four parasangs, then to Harran four parasangs, then to Tall Mahra four parasangs, then to Bajrawan seven parasangs, then to Raqqa three parasangs. The Road from Balad to Sinjar then to Circesium (Qarqisiya) on the Left: From Balad to Tall A'far five parasangs, then to Sinjar seven parasangs, then to Ayn al-Jibal five parasangs, then to Sukayr al-Abbas on the Khabur nine parasangs, then to al-Fadayn on the Khabur five parasangs, then to Maksin on the Khabur six parasangs, then to Circesium - which is on the Euphrates and the Khabur - seven parasangs.

The Road from Raqqa to the Jaziran Frontier Fortresses: Salghus, Kaysum, Shamshat, Malatya, Zabatara, al-Hadath, Mar'ash - between them is thirty miles - Kamakh, Hisn Mansur, Qurus, Duluk, and Ra'ban. From Raqqa to Ayn al-Rumiyya six parasangs, then to Tall Abda seven parasangs, then to Saruj seven parasangs, then to al-Muzaniyya six parasangs, then to Sumaysat seven parasangs, then to Hisn Mansur six parasangs, then to Malatya ten parasangs, then to Zabatara five parasangs, then (81) to al-Hadath four parasangs, then to Mar'ash five parasangs, then to Amq Mar'ash - 'Amq' is any meadow surrounded by mountains. From Malatya to Kamakh four parasangs. The Road from Ayn al-Tamr to Busra: The poet said: 'They arrived at Ayn al-Tamr at sunrise, Trampling every thicket and river.' From Ayn al-Tamr to al-Akhdamiyya, then to al-Khafiyya, then to al-Khalt, then to Siwa. He said: 'To Allah belong the eyes of Rafi', how he was guided, Crossing the desert from Qaraqir to Siwa.' Then to al-Ujayfir, then to al-Gharraba, then to Busra. The Road from al-Jazira to the Coast:

The Road from Raqqa to the Jaziran Frontier Fortresses: Salghus, Kaysum, Shamshat, Malatya, Zabatara, al-Hadath, Mar'ash - between them is thirty miles - Kamakh, Hisn Mansur, Qurus, Duluk, and Ra'ban. From Raqqa to Ayn al-Rumiyya six parasangs, then to Tall Abda seven parasangs, then to Saruj seven parasangs, then to al-Muzaniyya six parasangs, then to Sumaysat seven parasangs, then to Hisn Mansur six parasangs, then to Malatya ten parasangs, then to Zabatara five parasangs, then (81) to al-Hadath four parasangs, then to Mar'ash five parasangs, then to Amq Mar'ash - 'Amq' is any meadow surrounded by mountains. From Malatya to Kamakh four parasangs. The Road from Ayn al-Tamr to Busra: The poet said: 'They arrived at Ayn al-Tamr at sunrise, Trampling every thicket and river.' From Ayn al-Tamr to al-Akhdamiyya, then to al-Khafiyya, then to al-Khalt, then to Siwa. He said: 'To Allah belong the eyes of Rafi', how he was guided, Crossing the desert from Qaraqir to Siwa.' Then to al-Ujayfir, then to al-Gharraba, then to Busra. The Road from al-Jazira to the Coast:

From Raqqa to Dawsar, then to Daqin, then to Jisr Manbij. Ka'b ibn Ju'ayl said: 'From Jisr Manbij I wake up after the tenth [night], In Nakhl Maskin where the Surahs are recited.' Then to Manbij, then to Aleppo (Halab), then to al-Atharib, then to Amq, then to Antioch (Antakiya), then to Latakia (al-Ladhiqiyya), then to Jableh, then to Syrian Tripoli (Atrabulus al-Shamiyya), then to Beirut, (82) then to Sidon (Sayda), then to Tyre (Sur), then to Qadas, then to Caesarea (Qaysariyya), then to Syrian Arsuf, then to Jaffa (Yafa), then to Ashkelon (Asqalan), then to Gaza. The Road from Raqqa to Homs and Damascus via Rusafa: From Raqqa to Rusafa twenty-four miles, then to al-Zarra'a forty miles, then to al-Qastal thirty-six miles, then to Salamiya thirty miles, then to Homs twenty-four miles, then to Shamsin eighteen miles, then to Qara twenty-two miles, then to al-Nabk twelve miles, then to al-Qutayfa twenty miles, then to Damascus twenty-four miles. The Road from Homs to Damascus via Baalbek, which is the Post Road: From Homs to Jusiya four stages, then to Baalbek six stages, then to Damascus nine stages.

From Raqqa to Dawsar, then to Daqin, then to Jisr Manbij. Ka'b ibn Ju'ayl said: 'From Jisr Manbij I wake up after the tenth [night], In Nakhl Maskin where the Surahs are recited.' Then to Manbij, then to Aleppo (Halab), then to al-Atharib, then to Amq, then to Antioch (Antakiya), then to Latakia (al-Ladhiqiyya), then to Jableh, then to Syrian Tripoli (Atrabulus al-Shamiyya), then to Beirut, (82) then to Sidon (Sayda), then to Tyre (Sur), then to Qadas, then to Caesarea (Qaysariyya), then to Syrian Arsuf, then to Jaffa (Yafa), then to Ashkelon (Asqalan), then to Gaza. The Road from Raqqa to Homs and Damascus via Rusafa: From Raqqa to Rusafa twenty-four miles, then to al-Zarra'a forty miles, then to al-Qastal thirty-six miles, then to Salamiya thirty miles, then to Homs twenty-four miles, then to Shamsin eighteen miles, then to Qara twenty-two miles, then to al-Nabk twelve miles, then to al-Qutayfa twenty miles, then to Damascus twenty-four miles. The Road from Homs to Damascus via Baalbek, which is the Post Road: From Homs to Jusiya four stages, then to Baalbek six stages, then to Damascus nine stages.

The Road from Kufa to Damascus: From al-Hira to al-Qutqutana, then to al-Buq'a, then to al-Abyad, then to al-Hawsha, then to al-Jam', then to al-Khatta, then to al-Jubba, then to al-Qulufa, then to al-Rawari, then to al-Sa'ida, then to al-Baqi'a, then to al-A'nak, then to Adhri'at, then to (83) a station, then to Damascus. The Stages from Aleppo to the Syrian Frontier Fortresses: From Aleppo to Qinnasrin seven stages, then to Antioch four stages, then to Alexandretta (al-Iskandariyya) four stages, then to al-Massisa (Mopsuestia) seven stages - and the Jayhan river splits it; the name of al-Massisa is Mopsuestia (Mabsubastiya). From al-Massisa to Adana three stages; the name of Adana is Adanum, and it is on the Sayhan river. The poet said: 'O he whom the mountains of the Romans prevent meeting him, And their passes and the two fords of Sayhan. Then the Pass (al-Darb) intercepting, then the gap of Tuwana, Then Heraclea, then the fortress, the fortress of Sinan.' Then from Adana to Tarsus five stages. The name of Tarsus in Greek is Tarsum. Abu Sa'id said: 'They left him in the courtyards of Tarsus, Just as they left his father in Tus.' Faraj ibn Uthman al-Muqsimi said: 'Would that she had descended to Tarsus, And reached a river there, familiar.

The Road from Kufa to Damascus: From al-Hira to al-Qutqutana, then to al-Buq'a, then to al-Abyad, then to al-Hawsha, then to al-Jam', then to al-Khatta, then to al-Jubba, then to al-Qulufa, then to al-Rawari, then to al-Sa'ida, then to al-Baqi'a, then to al-A'nak, then to Adhri'at, then to (83) a station, then to Damascus. The Stages from Aleppo to the Syrian Frontier Fortresses: From Aleppo to Qinnasrin seven stages, then to Antioch four stages, then to Alexandretta (al-Iskandariyya) four stages, then to al-Massisa (Mopsuestia) seven stages - and the Jayhan river splits it; the name of al-Massisa is Mopsuestia (Mabsubastiya). From al-Massisa to Adana three stages; the name of Adana is Adanum, and it is on the Sayhan river. The poet said: 'O he whom the mountains of the Romans prevent meeting him, And their passes and the two fords of Sayhan. Then the Pass (al-Darb) intercepting, then the gap of Tuwana, Then Heraclea, then the fortress, the fortress of Sinan.' Then from Adana to Tarsus five stages. The name of Tarsus in Greek is Tarsum. Abu Sa'id said: 'They left him in the courtyards of Tarsus, Just as they left his father in Tus.' Faraj ibn Uthman al-Muqsimi said: 'Would that she had descended to Tarsus, And reached a river there, familiar.

Carrying a young woman who dwelt in Ta'rus, One of the beautiful, swaying Rafimat. Every plump woman steals souls.' The Syrian Frontier Fortresses (Awadil): (84) Ayn Zarba, al-Haruniyya, al-Kanisa al-Sawda', and Tall Jubayr - eight miles from Tarsus. Darb al-Salama and the Road to the Gulf of Constantinople: From Tarsus to al-Ullayq twelve miles, then to al-Rahwa, then to al-Jawzat twelve miles, then to al-Jardaqub seven miles, then to al-Badhandun (Podandos) seven miles. Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik said: 'The day of al-Badhandun, Just as she came to you on the day of al-Badhandun.' Then to the King's Camp at Hamma Lu'lu'a and al-Safsaf ten miles. You reach the King's Camp having crossed the Pass and entered the open country. From the Camp to Wadi al-Tarfa' twelve miles, then to Mina twenty miles, then to the River of Heraclea (Nahr Hirqla) twelve miles. Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf said: 'Heraclea fell when it saw a wonder, Crouching bodies throwing naphtha and fire.' Then to Madinat al-Laban eight miles, then to Ra's al-Ghaba five

Carrying a young woman who dwelt in Ta'rus, One of the beautiful, swaying Rafimat. Every plump woman steals souls.' The Syrian Frontier Fortresses (Awadil): (84) Ayn Zarba, al-Haruniyya, al-Kanisa al-Sawda', and Tall Jubayr - eight miles from Tarsus. Darb al-Salama and the Road to the Gulf of Constantinople: From Tarsus to al-Ullayq twelve miles, then to al-Rahwa, then to al-Jawzat twelve miles, then to al-Jardaqub seven miles, then to al-Badhandun (Podandos) seven miles. Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik said: 'The day of al-Badhandun, Just as she came to you on the day of al-Badhandun.' Then to the King's Camp at Hamma Lu'lu'a and al-Safsaf ten miles. You reach the King's Camp having crossed the Pass and entered the open country. From the Camp to Wadi al-Tarfa' twelve miles, then to Mina twenty miles, then to the River of Heraclea (Nahr Hirqla) twelve miles. Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf said: 'Heraclea fell when it saw a wonder, Crouching bodies throwing naphtha and fire.' Then to Madinat al-Laban eight miles, then to Ra's al-Ghaba five

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: ten miles, then to Al-Maskanin is sixteen miles, then to Ayn Barghuth is twelve miles, then to Nahr al-Ahsa is eighteen miles, then to the suburb of Quniya (Iconium) is eighteen miles, then to Al-Alamayn is fifteen miles, then to Abrumasamana is twenty miles, then to Wadi al-Jawz is twelve miles, then to Ammuriya (Amorium) is twelve miles. (85) Another road from Al-Alamayn to the villages of Nasr al-Ifriti is fifteen miles, then to the head of Lake Al-Basilyun is ten miles, then to Al-Sanad is ten miles, then to the fortress of Sinada is eighteen miles, then to Ma'l is twenty-five miles, then to the forest of Ammuriya is thirty miles, then to the villages of Al-Hirab is fifteen miles, then to Saghri Nahr Ammuriya is two miles. Al-Mu'tasim had destroyed Ankara and conquered Ammuriya. Husayn bin al-Dahhak said: 'Not a trace remained of Ankara, and you uprooted the great Ammuriya.' Then to Al-Ilj is twelve miles, then to Falami al-Ghaba is fifteen miles, then to Hisn al-Yahud (Fortress of the Jews) is twelve miles, then to Sindabari

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is eighteen miles, then to Marj Humr al-Malik Badruliya is thirty-five miles, then to Hisn Gharubli is fifteen miles, then to Kana'is al-Malik (The King's Churches) is three miles, then to Al-Tulul is twenty-five miles, then to Al-Akwar is fifteen miles, then to Malajina is fifteen miles, then to Istabl al-Malik (The King's Stable) is five miles, then to Hisn al-Ghabra is thirty miles, then to the Gulf is twenty-four miles. Nicaea is opposite Al-Ghabra, and from Nicaea vegetables are carried to Constantinople, and between them is thirty miles. (86) Another road from Al-Badhandun to Al-Karm, then to Al-Nuba, then to the churches on the right of Kawkab, then to Wafra, then to Balisa, then to Marj al-Usquf (Bishop's Meadow), then to Falughari, then to Qaryat al-Asnam (Village of Idols), then to Wadi

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: al-Rih (Valley of the Wind), then to N?rata, then to Al-Sayd, then to 'Aynu, then to Mudawis, then to a ford, then to Qaryat al-Jawz (Village of Walnuts), then to Al-Ghattasin, then to Qaryat al-Bitriq (Village of the Patrician), then to Marj Naquliya, then to Danus. From there is a road to Druliya (Dorylaeum), and another road bearing left from it to Hisn Balumin. Then from there to Qatiya, then bearing left to Al-Randhaq, then to Abydos on the strait. Then to the Gulf of Constantinople, which is the sea called Pontus coming from the Sea of the Khazars; the width of its mouth there is six miles. At its entrance there is a city called Musannah. The Gulf is western, flowing until it passes Constantinople at sixty miles from its entrance. Ibn Abi Hafsa said: 'I circled the Constantinople of the Romans, leaning spears against it, until its wall was clothed in humiliation.' Its width there is four miles. When it reaches a place called Abdos (Abydos), it goes between two mountains and narrows until its width is a bowshot. Between Abdos and

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Constantinople is one hundred miles on level ground. At Abdos is the spring of Maslama ibn Abd al-Malik, where he besieged Constantinople. (87) The Gulf passes until it pours into the Sea of Sham (Mediterranean). Its width at its mouth is also a bowshot; a man can speak to a man on the opposite bank. There is a rock with a tower containing a chain that prevents Muslim ships from entering the Gulf. The length of the entire Gulf from the Sea of the Khazars to the Sea of Sham is three hundred and twenty miles. Ships descend in it from the islands of the Sea of the Khazars and those regions, and ascend in it from the Sea of Sham to Constantinople. As for the rest of the lands of the Romans, the first from the west is Rome and Sicily, which is on an island. Rome was the abode of their kingdom; twenty-nine of their kings resided there. Two kings resided in Nicomedia. Nicomedia is before the Gulf, and between it and Constantinople is sixty miles. Then two other kings ruled in Rome. Then Constantine the Great ruled in Rome, then he moved to Byzantium, built a wall around it, and named it Constantinople. It is the abode of their kingdom to this day. It is mentioned that the Gulf surrounds it on two sides, the east and the north. Its western and southern sides are on land. The thickness of its large wall is twenty-one cubits, and the thickness of its short wall is ten cubits. The thickness of the short one facing the sea (*Al-Jarr*) is five cubits. Between it and the sea is a gap of about fifty cubits. On the land side, on the

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: southern side, there are many gates for war. Among them is the Golden Gate, which is a gate plated with iron gilded with gold. It has about a hundred gates. It is mentioned (88) that the twelve Patricians are with their King in Constantinople. Its cavalry consists of four thousand and its infantry four thousand. It is mentioned that Muslim bin Abi Muslim al-Jarmi said that the provinces of the Romans which the King assigns to his governors are fourteen provinces. Behind the Gulf are three provinces: The first is the province of Tafila, which is the land of Constantinople; its border from the east is the Gulf to the Sea of Sham, and from the west is the wall built from the Sea of the Khazars to the Sea of Sham. Its length is a journey of four days. It is two days' journey from Constantinople. To the south is the Sea of Sham, and to the north is the Sea of the Khazars. The second province behind this province is the province of Thrace (Taraqiya); its border from the east is the Wall, from the south is the province of Macedonia, from the west is the land of Burjan (Bulgars), and from the north is the Sea of the Khazars. Its length is a journey of fifteen days, and its width is a journey of three days; it has ten fortresses. The third province is the province of Macedonia; its border from the east is the Wall, from the south is the Sea of Sham, from the west is the land of the Slavs, and from the north is Burjan. Its length is a journey of fifteen days, and its width is a journey of five days; it has three fortresses. Before the Gulf are eleven provinces: The province of Paphlagonia (Aflajuniya), which has five

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: fortresses. The province of Optimatoi (Al-Aftimati), meaning the ear and the eye; it has three fortresses and the city of Nicomedia, which is ruined today. (89) The province of Opsikion (Al-Absiq), which contains the city of Nicaea. It has ten fortresses. The sea is eight miles from Nicaea. It has a freshwater lake twelve miles long. In the lake are three mountains. There is a small gate from the city to the lake; when fear surprises them, they move their families from the fortress to skiffs in the lake and take them to the mountains in the lake. The province of Thrakesion (Tarqasis); among its fortresses is Ephesus (Afsis) in the rustaq (district) of Al-Awasi. It is the city of the Companions of the Cave (Ashab al-Kahf). It has four fortresses. A book in Arabic was read in their mosque concerning Maslama's entry into the land of the Romans. As for the Companions of Al-Raqim, they are in Kharmah, a district between Amorium and Nicaea. Al-Wathiq Billah sent Muhammad bin Musa the Astronomer to the land of the Romans to look at the Companions of Al-Raqim and wrote to the Great One of the Romans to send someone to guide him to them. Muhammad bin Musa told me that the Great One of the Romans sent someone with him who took him to Qurrah, then he traveled four stages to a small mountain whose diameter at the base is less than a thousand cubits. It has a tunnel from the surface of the ground leading to the place where the Companions of

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Al-Raqim are. He said: We began by ascending the mountain to its peak, where there was a dug well; we discerned water at its bottom. Then we descended to the entrance of the tunnel and walked in it for about three hundred steps until we reached the place we overlooked. There was a portico in the mountain on hewn columns containing several (90) chambers. Among them was a chamber with a high threshold, about the height of a man, with a hewn stone door. Inside were the dead bodies. There was a man entrusted with guarding them, accompanied by handsome eunuchs. He tried to prevent us from seeing them or inspecting them, claiming that he was not safe from some affliction befalling anyone who sought that, intending deception to prolong his earnings from them. I said to him, 'Let me look at them, and you are absolved.' I climbed up with a thick candle along with my servant. I looked at them in hairshirts that crumbled in the hand. Their bodies were anointed with aloe, myrrh, and camphor to preserve them. Their skins stuck to their bones, except that I passed my hand over the chest of one of them and found his hair rough and strong in growth. The guardian brought food and asked us to lunch with him. When we tasted his food, we felt ill and vomited; he had intended to kill us or choke us so that what he claimed to the King of the Romans—that they were the Companions of Al-Raqim—would remain valid for him. We said to him, 'We thought you were showing us dead people who resemble... the living, but these are not so.' The province of Anatolikon (Al-Natulus), meaning the East; it is the largest of the Roman provinces. It contains the city of Ammuriya (Amorium); the number of its towers is forty-four. Among its fortresses are Al-Alamayn

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Marj al-Shahm, Barghuth, Al-Maskanin, thirty fortresses, Al-Bathn, and Al-Musabtilin. The province of Charsianon (?) follows the road of Malatya; among its fortresses is Kharshanah and four fortresses. The province of the Bucellarians (Al-Buqallar); it contains the city of Ankara, Samala, and thirteen fortresses. (91) Next to it is the province of the Armeniacs (Al-Arminiyaq); among its fortresses are Qaluniya and sixteen fortresses. The province of Chaldia (Khaldiya); its border is Armenia, and it has six fortresses. The province of Seleucia (Saluqiya) from the direction of the Sea of Sham to Tarsus and Al-Lamis; the governor of the passes manages it. It contains the fortress of Seleucia and ten fortresses. The province of Cappadocia (Al-Qabadaq); its border is the mountains of Tarsus, Adana, and Al-Massisa. Among its fortresses are Qurrah, Husayn, Antighuwa, Al-Ajrab, and Dhu al-Qila' (Possessor of Fortresses)—it is a mountain with fortresses on it, so the Arabs named it Dhu al-Qila', then the name shifted to Dhu al-Kila'. Its name is Jisistrun, meaning 'Rivalling the Star.' It has fourteen fortresses. Among the matmuras (underground granaries) are Majida, Balansa, Malandasa, Quniya (Iconium), Malquniya, Badala, Barnawa, and Salimun. The meaning of Malquniya is 'Quarry of Millstones'; millstones are cut from its mountains.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Among the Patricians of the Romans are twelve Patricians, neither decreasing nor increasing. Six of them reside in Constantinople in the presence of the Tyrant (Emperor), and six are in the provinces: the Patrician of Ammuriya, the Patrician of Ankara, the Patrician of the Armeniac, the Patrician of Thrace (which is behind Constantinople towards Burjan), the Patrician of Sicily (a great island and vast kingdom opposite Ifriqiya), and the Patrician of Sardinia (who is the master of all the islands of the sea). The greatest city of the Romans, which is (92) their sanctuary, is Constantinople, also called Al-Badhrum. The King is the greatest of the Romans in their eyes and the most cherished by them. Kingship among them is not hereditary, nor is there a followed scripture; rather, it is by conquest. Men and women have ruled them. Their King is called Basili (Basileus). His dress is purple (*Al-Farfir*), a type of silk with slight glimmers of black. No one wears purple or red boots except the King; whoever attempts that is killed. Whoever is named King wears red boots and black boots. This city, Al-Badhrum, has four hundred men dressed in green robes adorned with gold; they are for the King's council and attending to his affairs. The Patricians are in charge of Constantinople and the King's chamberlainship. These people draw the sword against the children of Ishmael and deem killing lawful; they may beat prisoners with axes and stones or throw them into the oven, which is a fire pit. The horses stationed at the King's gate are four thousand horsemen and four thousand infantry. The King's army, whether stationary or traveling, has four banners under which are four Patricians; in the cavalry battalion of each one are twelve thousand men—six thousand mercenaries and six thousand apprentices. If the King goes out towards the lands of the Arabs, he encamps at Badruliya (Dorylaeum), four days from Constantinople. It is the gathering place for Arabs and Romans. It is a wide, green meadow with a clear river about thirty cubits wide (93) issuing from

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: springs and pouring into the Saghri of the Green Sea, and the Saghri pours into the Great Sea behind Constantinople. In it are hot springs of fresh, hot water over which the kings have built structures and vaults. A house holds a thousand people. There are seven houses where the water reaches a man's chest; it flows so its surplus goes into a lake. One exits from Darb al-Salamah (Pass of Safety), then descends to Al-Ullayq, then descends to Al-Jawzat, then Al-Jardaqub, then Hisn al-Saqaliba (Fortress of the Slavs), then Al-Rahwa, then Al-Badhandun (Podandos). The spring of Al-Badhandun, by which Al-Ma'mun died, is called Raqah; it issues from something like a great gate, full of cold water, unbearable in its coldness. I have not seen a greater spring than it. Then one travels from it into the two gaps, wading across the river about twenty times until coming to the hot spring, and passing a gentle steep road. Then Lu'lu'ah (Loulon) appears to you. Then one travels to a fortress, then travels to Waliyah, which is the Lake of Al-Maskanin. Then one comes to Hawtat al-Raqim, which is a depression in the earth measuring about two hundred cubits by two hundred cubits. In its center is a split with a lake, surrounded by trees. Around the trees at the base of the mountain are houses and dwellings; it is an exit for more than a hundred men. It has a door in the mountain under the earth that leads you out to the valley. People around it look down into its interior like a bowl. (94) They brought out to Ali bin Yahya a jar of water from the lake, oven bread, and cheese as a gift, and said, 'We are the weak ones of the Romans; we do not fight, we only serve these people whom Allah placed here.' The people are in a cave ascended to from the land of the depression by a ladder, perhaps eight cubits or so. They are thirteen men, including a beardless youth. They wear wool cloaks and wool wraps, and have boots and sandals. I took hold of some hairs on the forehead of one of them and pulled them, but nothing followed me.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The land tax of the Romans is by area: for every two hundred *mudd*, three dinars every year (a *mudd* is three *makuk*s). He takes a tenth of the crops, which goes into the granaries for the armies. He takes one dinar a year from Jews and Zoroastrians. From every house in which a fire is lit, six dirhams are taken annually. The fruits of the Romans ripen in the plain and the mountain in Aylul (September). His register is set for one hundred and twenty thousand men. Over every ten thousand men is a Patrician. With every Patrician are two Turmaykhs (Turmarchs); each Turmaykh is over five thousand men. With every Turmaykh are five Turanjarin (Drungaries); each Turanjar is over one thousand men. With every Turanjar are five Qamamisa (Comes/Counts); each Qumas is over two hundred. With every Qumas are five Qantarkhin (Kentarchs); each Qantarkh is over forty. With every Qantarkh (95) are four Daqarkhin (Dekarchs); each Daqarkh is over ten men. The pay varies; the maximum is forty pounds of gold, to thirty-six pounds, to twenty-four pounds, to twelve, to six pounds, to one pound. The soldiers' pay is between eighteen dinars to twelve dinars. This is decreed for them every year, but they are only paid this every

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: three years, or perhaps four years, or perhaps five years, or perhaps six years, as a single payment. The greatest of the Patricians is the King's Deputy and his Vizier; then the Logothete (Lughathit), master of the Land Tax Bureau; the Master of the Review of Books; the Chamberlain; the Master of the Postal Bureau; then the Judge; then the Master of the Guard; then the Watcher (?). The famous islands of the Romans are Cyprus, its circumference is twelve days; the island of Crete (Iqritish), its circumference is fifteen days; the Island of Gold, where servants were castrated; the Island of Silver; and the island of Sicily, its circumference is fifteen days. The scholar of the lands of the Romans said: The salaries of the chiefs are between three pounds of gold to one pound. The pound is ninety mithqals. Only beardless youths are employed in the Roman bureaus; the youth takes one dinar in the first year, two dinars in the second, and three dinars in the third, until he completes twelve years (96), then he takes twelve dinars. The post of the Romans consists of small workhorses with docked tails, light-footed. Their race track is on the first of Adhar (March). The King races his horses and the horses of his emirs at the Golden Gate. It is a race between two horses. The wagons have young servants standing in a row. The Romans do not have markets in their army camps; a man carries his biscuit, oil, wine, and cheese from his home.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The road bearing left from Lu'lu'ah to Wadi al-Tarfa, then to Hiraqla (Heraclea), then to Zabrala, then to Sadriya, then to Barghuth, then to Al-Ahsa, then to Quniya (Iconium). Then you enter Wadi Dhamari to the village of Daqilyas, then to Qaryat al-Burj, then to Mas Qumas, then you come to Al-Alamayn, then you proceed to the villages of Qatiya, then you proceed to Aylami, then you proceed to Druliya (Dorylaeum), which is the gathering place of the armies for the Arabs and the Romans. Then to Hisn Arandasi, then to the village of Afrasus, then to Baslaqin and Malajina—which are the King's stables and the location of his baggage and provisions—then to the Lake of Nicaea. Then you descend from it to Nicomedia, then to Al-Ma'abir (The Crossings), then to Al-Arn?ah, which is the King's land. Whoever wants Ammuriya from Darb al-Salamah goes via Lu'lu'ah, then to Nahr al-Tarfa, then to Khirbat Farita, then to Hisn Qunna, then to (97) 'A?qarsun, then to H?r Far??h the Upper, then you come to Bilad al-Huda, then you come to ????, and a village called Farita, then you come to 'Ibrat K?as, then you come to Lata, then you come to Ammuriya. Description of Rome and the Wonders within it: It has three sides; the eastern, southern, and western are on the sea, and the northern side faces the land. Its length from the Eastern Gate to the Western Gate is

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: twenty-eight miles. It has two walls of stone; between them is a space of sixty cubits. The width of the inner wall is twelve cubits and its height is seventy-two cubits. The width of the outer wall is eight cubits and its height is forty-two cubits. Between the two walls is a river covered with copper tiles; the length of each tile is forty-six cubits. This river is called Qastitalis. Between the Golden Gate and the King's Gate is twelve miles. The Bird Market in it is a farsakh. There is a market extending from the Eastern Gate to the Western Gate on three colonnades. The middle porticoes are on columns of yellow Roman brass; the shaft, base, and capital are cast from it. In it are merchants' shops. The height of the columns is thirty cubits. In front of these columns and shops is a channel of a river made of yellow brass from its east to its west; (98) a tongue of the sea flows in it. Ships sail in it with their cargo, so the ship comes with what is in it until it stops at the buyer's shop. Abu Bakr bin Umar al-Qurashi and Abdullah bin Abi Talib al-Qurashi from the district of Tunis in the Maghreb told me that the Lighthouse of Alexandria has three hundred and sixty-six rooms circling it, and the mosque is at its top. A horseman or two can ride to its top without stairs; rather, the horsemen and infantry circle to

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: its top like the minaret of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra). It is on the coast of the sea; its waves strike its foundation. No ship passes except beneath it to enter the lands. Inside the city is a church built in the name of the Disciples Peter and Paul; they are in it in a sarcophagus. The length of this church is three hundred cubits, its width is two hundred cubits, and its height is eighty cubits. It is built with arches of yellow brass and corners of cast yellow brass. The roof of this church and its walls are of yellow Roman brass. In Rome, there are one thousand two hundred churches. All its markets are paved with white marble. It has forty thousand baths. It has a church resembling Jerusalem (Bayt al-Maqdis), a mile long. In it is an altar upon which the offering is made, of green emerald, twenty cubits long and six cubits wide. It is carried by twelve statues of pure gold; the height of each statue is two and a half cubits. Each statue has two eyes of red ruby from which the church is illuminated. This church has twenty-(99) eight gates of pure gold, huge, and a thousand gates of cast yellow brass, besides gates of ebony, boxwood, and varieties of fine carved wood whose value is unknown. Around the wall of Rome are one thousand two hundred and twenty columns containing monks. Abdullah bin Amr bin al-Aas said: The wonders of the world are four: A mirror that was suspended on the Lighthouse of Alexandria; a man would sit under it and see who was in Constantinople, though the width of the sea is between them.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: And a horse of brass that was in the land of al-Andalus, saying with its palms like this, extending its hand, meaning 'There is no path behind me'; so no one treads that land but the ants swallow him. And a minaret of brass upon which is a rider of brass in the land of 'Ad; when the sacred months came, water poured from it, and people drank, watered, and filled the cisterns. When the sacred months ended, that water stopped. And a tree of brass upon which is a black woman of brass in the land of Rome; when the time for olives came, the black woman of brass whistled, and every black woman of the birds would come with three olives—two olives in her feet and an olive in her beak—until she threw them on that brass black woman, so the people of Rome would press enough oil for their condiment and lamps for their year until the next. (100) Postal Stages of the Road to the West: From Surra Man Ra'a to Jabalata is seven stages (3). Then to Al-Sinn, ten stages. Then to Al-Haditha, nine stages. Then to Mosul, seven stages. Then to Balad, four stages. Then to Adhrama, nine stages. Then to Nusaybin, six stages. Then to Kafartutha, six stages. Then to Ra's al-Ayn, ten

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: stages. Then to Al-Raqqa, fifteen stages. Then to Al-Naqira, ten stages. Then to Manbij, five stages. Then to Aleppo, nine stages. Then to Qinnasrin, three stages. Then to Sawwari, ten stages. Then to Hama, two stages. Then to Homs, four stages. Then to Jusiya, four stages. Then to Baalbek, six stages. Then to Damascus, nine stages. Then to Dayr Ayyub, seven stages. Then to Tiberias, which is the capital of Jordan, six stages. Then to Al-Lajjun, four stages. Then to Ramla, which is the capital of Palestine, nine stages. Then to Al-Jifar, seventeen stages. Then to Al-Baruriya, nineteen stages. Then to Fustat. From Fustat to Alexandria, thirteen stages. Then to Jubb al-Raml towards Barqa, thirty stages. Towards Barqa, above Tarsus on the sea coast, among the ruined cities of the Romans are Qalamiya at sixteen miles from Tarsus. Then Qarqash at ten miles from Qalamiya. (101) Then Qurasiya at four miles from Qarqis. Then Alexandria at twelve miles from Qurasiya. Then Sabastiya at four miles from Alexandria. Then Saluqiya (Seleucia) at four miles from the sea in a meadow. Then Nubayk, which is a fortress on a mountain. They narrated that when the Romans destroyed Jerusalem (Bayt al-Maqdis), Allah decreed captivity upon them every day. So not a day of time passes but that a nation of the nations surrounding

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the Romans takes a human captive from the Romans. Jacob the Prophet, blessings of Allah be upon him, used to fear his brother Esau (Al-Is) intensely. Allah revealed to him, 'Do not fear, for I will protect you as I protected your father.' So Jacob gave Esau a tenth of his sheep out of fear and seeking to repel his harm. Jacob's sheep, peace be upon him, were five thousand five hundred sheep, so the tenth was five hundred and fifty. Allah revealed to Jacob, peace be upon him, 'You did not trust in My word and gave a tenth of your sheep to Esau; therefore, I will make the children of Esau rule your children for five hundred and fifty years.' This was from the day the Romans destroyed Jerusalem and enslaved the Children of Israel until Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah have mercy upon him, conquered Jerusalem and expelled the Romans from it. The News of the West is ended. The News of Al-Jarbi: Al-Jarbi is the Northern lands, a quarter of the kingdom. The Commander (Isbahbadh) of the North during the era of the Persians was called Adharbadhagan Isbahbadh. In this domain are Armenia, Azerbaijan, (102) Rayy, and Damavand. The city of Damavand is Shalanbah. Bahram Gur said: 'I am the Lion of Shalanbah, and I am the Tiger of Talah.'

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: In it are Tabaristan, Al-Ruyan, Amul, Sariya, Shalus, Al-Lariz, Al-Sharriz, Tumis, Dihistan, Al-Kalar, Gilan, and Badhbashwarjar. The King of Tabaristan, Gilan, and Badhbashwarjar is called Gil-Gilan of Khorasan. Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik said: 'The elephant has been dyed as is his custom, for the Gil-Gilan of Khorasan. And the elephant's limbs are not dyed except for one of great importance.' In this region are Al-Babir, Al-Taylasan, the Khazars, the Alans, the Slavs (Saqaliba), and the Abar (Avars). The Road to Azerbaijan and Armenia: Turn off from the Khorasan road at Sinn Sumayra. From Sinn Sumayra to Dinawar is five farsakhs (two stages). From Dinawar to Zanjan is twenty-nine stages. Then to Maragha, eleven stages. Then to Miyanaj, two stages. Then to Ardabil, eleven stages. Then to Warthan, which is the last district of Azerbaijan, eleven stages. The Cities and Rustaqs (Districts) in the Province of Azerbaijan: Maragha, Miyanaj, Ardabil, Warthan, Sisar, Barza, Sabarkhast, and Tabriz belong to Muhammad bin al-Rawwad al-Azdi; Marand belongs to Ibn al-Ba'ith; Khoy, Kulasrah, and Mughan (103) belong to Shaklah; Barzand; Janzah (Ganja), the city of Abrawiz; Jabirwan; Nariz belonging to Ali bin Murr; Urmia, the city of Zoroaster; Salmas; and Al-Shiz, which contains the Fire Temple

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Adhurgushnasp, which is of great esteem among the Zoroastrians (Majus). When one of their kings ascended the throne, he would visit it from Al-Mada'in on foot. And Bajirwan, the Rustaq of Al-Salq, the Rustaq of Sindabaya, Al-Badhdh, the Rustaq of Urm, Balwankarj, the Rustaq of Sarah, Daskiyawar, and the Rustaq of Mayinharij. The Road from Dinawar to Barzand: From Dinawar to Al-Khabarijan is seven farsakhs. Then to Tal Wan is six farsakhs. Then to Sisar is seven farsakhs. Then to Andarab is four farsakhs. Then to Al-Baylaqan is five farsakhs. Then to Barza is six farsakhs. Then to Sabarkhast is eight farsakhs. Then to Maragha is seven farsakhs. Then to Dakharragan is eleven farsakhs. Then to Tabriz is nine farsakhs. Then to Marand is ten farsakhs. Then to Al-Khan is four farsakhs. Then to Khoy is six farsakhs. From Maragha to Kurasrah is ten farsakhs. Then to Sarah is ten farsakhs. Then to Al-Nir is five farsakhs. Then to Ardabil is five farsakhs. Then to Mughan is ten farsakhs.

From Ardabil to Khash is eight parasangs. Then to Barzand, six parasangs. Barzand was in ruins, so al-Afshin rebuilt it as a city and camped there. From Barzand to Sadrasb, where al-Afshin's first trench is, is two parasangs. Then to Zahrkash, where his second trench is, is two parasangs. Then to Du al-Rud, where his third trench is, is two parasangs. Then to Al-Badhdh, the city of Babak, is one parasang. (104) Husayn ibn al-Dahhak said: "He left none of its inhabitants in Al-Badhdh, except examples like the examples of Iram." The road from Barzand to the desert of Balasajan and to Warthan, which is the end of the work of Azerbaijan, is twelve parasangs. From Maragha to Janzah is six parasangs. Then to Musa-abadh, five parasangs. Then to Barzah, four parasangs. Then to Jabrawan, eight parasangs. Then to Nariz, four parasangs. Then to Urmia, fourteen parasangs. Then to Salmas by land and by Lake Urmia, six parasangs. The land tax of Azerbaijan is two million dirhams. The Road Taken by Muhammad ibn Humayd by Land When He Transported the Troops in Azerbaijan: He rode from Maragha to Barzah, then to Sisir, then to Shiz - which is four parasangs from Dinawar - then to Dinawar.

The Road to Armenia: From Warthan to Bardha'a is eight post-stages. Then to Mansurah of Armenia, four post-stages. From Bardha'a to Tiflis is ten post-stages. From Bardha'a to Bab al-Abwab (Derbent) is fifteen post-stages. From Bardha'a to Dabil (Dvin) is seven post-stages. From Marand to the Valley is ten parasangs.
