Then to Nashawa (Nakhchivan), ten parasangs. Then to Dabil, twenty parasangs. (105) From Warthan to Darman is three parasangs. Then to Baylaqan, nine parasangs. Then to Bardha'a, fourteen parasangs. From Bardha'a to Al-Badhdh is thirty parasangs. First Armenia: Al-Sisajan, Arran, Tiflis, Bardha'a, Baylaqan, Qabala, and Shirvan. Second Armenia: Jurzan, Sughdabil, Bab Fayruz Qubadh, and Al-Lakz. Third Armenia: Al-Busfarrajan, Dabil, Siraj Tayr, Baghawand, and Nashawa. Fourth Armenia: Shamshat, Khlat, Qaliqala (Erzurum), Arjish, and Bajanis. The districts of Arran, Jurzan, and Al-Sisajan were in the Kingdom of the Khazars. And

the districts of Dabil, Nashawa, Siraj, Baghawand, Khlat, and Bajanis were in the Kingdom of the Romans (Byzantines). The Persians conquered them up to the land of Shirvan, where the Rock of Moses containing the Spring of Life is located. Shamshat contains the grave of Safwan ibn al-Mu'attal al-Sulami, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Between it and the fortress of Ziyad is nearby. Upon it is a tree unknown to anyone; it bears fruit resembling almonds, eaten with its peel, sweeter than honey. Qubadh built the city of Baylaqan, the city of Bardha'a, the city of Qabala, and the Mud-brick Dam. Anushirvan built the city of Shabran, the city of Karkara, and the city of Bab al-Abwab. [There are] castles on roads in the mountain, numbering three hundred and sixty castles. He built Balanjar and Samandar. And he built in the land of Jurzan the city of Sughdabil, (106) and he also built his castle there and named it Bab Fayruz Qubadh. Also from Armenia are Khoy, Al-Sannariyah, Al-Baq, Kasal, Abkhaz, the Fortress of Jardman, Khizan, Shaki, and the City of the Gate (Bab). As for the Gates (Abwab), they are mouths of mountain passes in the Kabk Mountain (Caucasus). Among them are Bab ?ul, Bab al-Lan, Bab al-Shabran, Bab Ladhiqa, Bab Bariqa, Bab Samsakhi,

Bab Sahib al-Sarir, Bab Faylan Shah, Bab Karunan, Bab Tabarsaran Shah, Bab Liran Shah, Bab Liban Shah, Bab Anushirvan. The city of Samandar is behind the Gate (Bab), and what is beyond it is in the hands of the Khazars. In the stories of Moses, peace be upon him: {Did you see when we retired to the rock? Indeed, I forgot the fish}, which is alive. The Rock is the Rock of Shirvan, the Sea is the Sea of Gilan, the Village is the Village of Bajrawan {until they met a boy and he killed him} in the village of Khizan. The land tax of Armenia is four million dirhams. The Road between Jurjan and Khamlij, the City of the Khazars (It is northern, and that is why I mentioned it in this place): From Jurjan to Khamlij - which is on the bank of the river coming from the lands of the Slavs and pouring into the Sea of Jurjan - by sea, if the wind is good, is eight days. The cities of (107) the Khazars are Khamlij, Balanjar, and Al-Bayda'. Al-Buhturi said: "Honor increased in Iraq to that which they knew in Khamlij or in Balanjara." Outside the Gate (Bab) are the King of Suwar, the King of Al-Lakz, the King of Al-Lan, the King of Faylan, the King of Al-Masqat, Sahib al-Sarir, and the city of Samandar.

End of the report of Al-Jarbi, which is the Northern Lands. (108) Report of Al-Tayman (The South): Al-Tayman is the Southern Lands, a quarter of the kingdom. Its Spahbed is Nimruz Isbahbadh. The poll-tax (Jawali) in the City of Peace (Baghdad) was one hundred and thirty thousand dirhams. The revenues of the markets, mills, and mints in it were one million five hundred thousand dirhams. The Road from the City of Peace to Mecca: From Baghdad to the Bridge of Kutha is seven parasangs. Then to Qasr Ibn Hubayrah, five parasangs. Then to Suq Asad, seven parasangs. Then to Shahi, seven parasangs. Then to Kufa, five parasangs. That totals thirty-one parasangs. The Road of the Desert: When you leave Kufa and reach Al-Udhayb, you have fallen into Nejd. You are in Nejd until you reach Dhat Irq, then you fall into Tihamah. On your right when you leave Kufa towards Syria is Nejd, and on your left when you leave Kufa - Al-Arud - towards Ta'if is Nejd. From Kufa to Al-Qadisiyah is fifteen miles. Then to Al-Udhayb, the edge of

the desert, is six miles. (109) The poet said: "O companion, no sleep nor rest, Until you see a fire for me at Al-Udhayb." Then to Al-Mughithah, where there is rain water, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station (Muta'ashsha) is Wadi al-Siba' at fifteen miles. Jarir said: "Indeed the calamity is he whose grave is contained in Wadi al-Siba'; for every side is a falling place." Then to Al-Qar'a, where there are wells, thirty-two miles. The dinner-station is Masjid Sa'd at fourteen miles. Then to Waqisah, where there are cisterns and wells, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Taraf at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Aqabah, where there are wells, twenty-nine miles. The dinner-station is Al-Qubaybat at fourteen miles. A Bedouin said: "Is there for us a return from our time at Al-Qubaybat?" Then to Al-Qa', where there is a well, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Bahlaha' at thirteen miles. Then to Zubalah, which has abundant water, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Juraysi at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Shuquq, where there are cisterns and wells, twenty-one miles. The dinner-station is Al-Tananir at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Butan, which is Qabr al-Abadi, where there are cisterns, twenty-nine miles.

The dinner-station is Bardin at fourteen (110) miles. Then to Al-Tha'labiyah, which is one-third of the way, where there are cisterns, twenty-nine miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Muhallabiyah at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Khuzaymiyah, where there are cisterns and water wheels, thirty-two miles. The dinner-station is Al-Ghamis at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Ajfar, where there are cisterns and wells, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is Batn al-Agharr at fifteen miles. Then to Fayd, which is half the way, where there is a flowing spring. In Fayd there is a pulpit (minbar), markets, cisterns, and flowing springs, thirty-six miles. The dinner-station is Al-Qara'in at twenty miles. Then to Tuz, where there are cisterns and wells, thirty-one miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Qarnatayn at seventeen miles. Then to Sumayra', where there are cisterns and wells, twenty miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Fahimah at thirteen miles. Then to Al-Hajir, where there are cisterns and wells, thirty-three miles. The dinner-station is Al-Abbasiyah at fifteen miles. Then to Ma'dan al-Qurashi - the common people call it Ma'dan al-Nuqrah - where there are wells, thirty-four miles. The dinner-station is Qarura at seventeen miles. The alms-tax of Bakr ibn Wa'il goes to the master of the road of M?h, which is three thousand dirhams.

The Road to Medina: Medina is Hijazi-Najdi. So whoever takes the road to Medina: From Al-Ma'dan to Al-Usaylah, where there are salty wells, forty-six miles. Then to Batn Nakhl, abundant in water, thirty-six miles. (111) Then to Al-Taraf, where there is rain water, twenty-two miles. Then to Medina, which is Taybah, thirty-five miles. Sirmah al-Ansari said: "When he came to us, Allah made His religion manifest, And he became happy with Taybah, pleased." Al-Abbas ibn al-Fadl al-Alawi said: "And upon Taybah which Allah blessed For the Seal of the Messengers." It is also called Yathrib. In the Jahiliyyah, there was a governor over it and Tihamah from the Marzban of the Desert collecting its tax. Qurayzah and Nadir were kings whom they made kings over Medina over the Aws and Khazraj. Regarding that, the poet of the Ansar says: "Paying the tax (Kharj) after the tax of Kisra, And a tax from Qurayzah and Nadir." The Areas (A'rad) of Medina: Among them is Tayma', containing its fortress Al-Ablaq al-Fard. It is between Syria and Hijaz. Its king was Al-Samaw'al ibn Adiya the Jew, described as loyal, about whom the poet says:

"In Al-Ablaq al-Fard of Tayma is his home, A fortified fortress and a neighbor not treacherous." Among them is Dumat al-Jandal. It is thirteen stages from Medina, ten stages from Kufa, and ten stages from Damascus. Its fortress is Marid. (112) Al-Zabba' said: "Marid rebelled and Al-Ablaq became mighty." The two arbitrators met at Duma. Aws ibn Jabir said: "If you were in Duma or in Fari', You would not escape the falling doubt of death." Among them are Al-Furu', Dhu al-Marwah, Wadi al-Qura, Madyan, and Khaybar. Marhab said: "Himyar knew that I am Marhab, Armed with weapons, a tested hero." Among them are Fadak, Arab villages, Al-Wahidah, Namirah, Al-Hadiqah, 'Adi, Khadrah, Al-Sa'irah, Al-Rahbah, Al-Sayalah, Sayah, Raht, Ghurab, Al-Akhal, and Al-Himyah. The Road Taken by the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family, when he migrated: The guide took him to the lower part of Mecca until he came to the coast lower than Usfan. Then he cut across the road until he passed Qudayd. Then he took the path in Al-Kharrar.

Then he climbed Thaniyat al-Mar'ah. Then he went through the valley of Madlajat Mujaj. Then he took Marjah of Mujaj, then the valley of Marjah Dhi al-Ghadwayn, then the valley of Dhat Kashd. Then he took Al-Ajrad. Then he took Dhu Samar, then the valley of A'da, Madlajat Ti'hin. Then he reached Al-Uthbanah. Then he passed Al-Qahah. Then he descended Al-Arj. Then he took Thaniyat al-A'yar to the right of Rakubah. (113) Then he descended Ri'm. Then to Bani Amr ibn Awf in Quba. The Main Road from Medina to Mecca: From Medina to Al-Shajarah, which is the Miqat of the people of Medina, six miles. Then to Malal, where there are wells, twelve miles. Then to Al-Sayalah, where there are wells, nineteen miles. Then to Al-Ruwaythah, where there are cisterns, thirty-four miles. Then to Al-Suqya, where there is a flowing river and a garden, thirty-six miles. Then to Al-Abwa', where there are

wells, twenty-nine miles. Then to Al-Juhfah, which is in Tihamah and has wells; the sea is eight miles from it. It is the Miqat of the people of Syria, twenty-seven miles. Then to Qudayd, where there are wells, twenty-seven miles. Then to Usfan, where there are wells, twenty-four miles. Then to Batn Marr, where there is a spring and a cistern, thirty-three miles. Then to Mecca, sixteen miles. The Main Road from Ma'dan al-Nuqrah to Mecca: From it to Mughithat al-Mawan, where there are cisterns, wells, and scarce water, thirty-three miles. The dinner-station is Al-Samt at sixteen miles. Then to Al-Rabadhah, where there are cisterns and wells, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is Arimah at fourteen miles. Then to Ma'dan Bani Sulaym, where there are water cisterns; water is least found there, twenty-four miles. The poet said: "This is a station most worthy of abandonment, The wolf howls and the crow weeps." (114) The dinner-station is Sharura at twelve miles. Then to Al-Salilah, twenty-six miles. The dinner-station is at Al-Kanabayn at thirteen miles. Then to Al-Umq, where there is a cistern and wells, twenty-one miles. The dinner-station is Al-Sanja at

twelve miles. Then to Al-Ufay'iyah, where there is a cistern and wells, thirty-two miles. The dinner-station is Al-Kura' at fifteen miles. Then to Al-Maslah, where there are cisterns and wells; it is the Miqat of the people of Iraq, thirty-four miles. The dinner-station is Al-Kubranah at fourteen miles. Then to Al-Ghamrah, where there are cisterns and wells, eighteen miles. The dinner-station is Al-Qasr at eight miles. Then to Dhat Irq, where there is a well with abundant water, twenty-six miles. The dinner-station is Awtas at twelve miles. Then to Bustan Bani Amir, with abundant water, twenty-two miles. The dinner-station is Ghamr Dhi Kindah at eleven miles. Then to Mecca, twenty-four miles. The dinner-station is Mushash at eleven miles. So from Baghdad to Mecca is two hundred seventy-five and two-thirds parasangs, which is eight hundred twenty-seven miles. Boundaries of the Haram: From the Medina road at three miles. From the Jeddah road at ten miles. From the Yemen road at seven miles. From the Ta'if road at eleven miles. From the Iraq road at six miles. The length of the Sacred Mosque is three hundred seventy cubits, and its width is three hundred (115) fifteen cubits. The length of the House (Kaaba) is twenty-four cubits and a span by twenty-three

cubits and a span. The measurement around the Hijr is fifty cubits. The measurement of the Tawaf is one hundred and seven cubits. The height of the Kaaba into the sky is twenty-seven cubits. Mecca was the abode of Adam, peace be upon him. Then the nations did not cease to venerate the Sanctuary until Allah Almighty designated for Abraham, peace be upon him, the place of the House, so he and Ishmael, peace be upon them, raised its foundations and built it. The Districts (Mikhlaws) of Mecca in Nejd: Ta'if, Najran - The poet said: "And the Kaaba of Najran is a duty upon you, Until you kneel at its gates" - Qarn al-Manazil - The poet said: "Did you not ask the quarter to speak? At Qarn al-Manazil it has worn out" - Al-Fatq, Ukaz, Al-Zaymah, Turabah, Bisha, Tabalah, Al-Hajirah, Thajjah, Jurash, and Al-Sarat. And its districts in Tihamah: Dankan, Ashm, Baysh, and Akk.

The Road from Mecca to Ta'if: Al-Numayri said: "She winters in Mecca enjoying bliss, And her summer resort is in Ta'if." (116) From Mecca to Bi'r Ibn al-Murtafi'. Then to Qarn al-Manazil, which is the Miqat of the people of Yemen and Ta'if. Then to Ta'if. Whoever wants [to go] from Mecca to Ta'if via the Aqabah road comes to Arafat, then Batn Nu'man, then ascends Aqabat Hira', then overlooks Ta'if, descends, and ascends a light slope, then enters Ta'if. The Road from Mecca to Yemen: From Mecca to Bi'r Ibn al-Murtafi', containing a well. Then to Qarn al-Manazil, a great village. Then to Al-Fatq, a large village. Then to Safn, containing two wells. Then to Turabah, a large village. Then to Kara, containing palms and springs. Then to Ranyah, containing palms and springs. Then to Tabalah, a large city containing springs. Then to Bisha bi-'Atan, large, containing surface water. Humayd ibn Thawr

al-Hilali said: "When she wished, she sang to me in the winding valleys of Bisha, To the palms of Tathlith or Yabambama." Then to Jasda', containing a well and no inhabitants. Then to Banat Harb, a great village containing a spring and a well. Then to Yabambam, with no inhabitants. Then to Katnah, a great village containing wells. Then to Al-Thajjah, containing a well. Then to Sarum Rah, a great village containing springs and vines; Jurash is eight miles from it. (117) Then to Al-Mahjarah, a great village containing springs. Between Sarum Rah and Al-Mahjarah is Talhat al-Malik, a great tree resembling the willow but larger than it; it is the border between the work of Mecca and the work of Yemen. Then to 'Arqah, its water is little and no inhabitants in it. Then to Sa'dah, a great city where leather

and sandals are tanned. Then to Al-A'mashiyah, no inhabitants in it, containing a small spring. Then to Khaywan, which is a great village with many vines and huge clusters [of grapes], containing two cisterns; its people are the Umaris. Then to Athafit, a city containing vines, crops, and springs. Then to Sana'a, the city of Yemen. The Rajiz poet said: "There must be Sana'a even if the journey is long, Even if every mount bends and becomes sore." Abu Nuwas said: "We are the lords of Na'it, and ours is Sana'a, And the musk in its mihrabs." Sana'a is split by its wadi, Al-Sirrar, which flows when rain comes in the summer months and pours into Saywan, becoming like a lake. The poet said: "Woe to me for the dweller of the bank of Al-Sirrar, Inhabited by a gazelle, intensely shy." The Districts (Mikhlaws) of Yemen: (118) Mikhlaf of Sana'a, Al-Khashab, Rahabah, and Marmal. From this Mikhlaf the fire emerged that burned the garden mentioned by Allah Almighty in His Book, so it became like a harvested field. In Sana'a was Ghumdan, the residence of Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan al-Himyari. About it, Umayyah ibn Abi al-Salt al-Thaqafi says: "Drink blissfully, wearing the crown, reclining, At the top of Ghumdan, a house you occupy." And Mikhlaf of Sa'dah. From Sana'a to Khaywan is twenty-four parasangs. From Khaywan to Sa'dah is sixteen parasangs. From Sa'dah to Al-Mahjarah,

which is below Aqabat al-Mandah at Talhat al-Malik, which is the beginning of the work of Yemen, is twenty parasangs. So between Al-Mahjarah and Sana'a is sixty parasangs. Mikhlaf al-Bawn, containing Raydah, and in it is the neglected well and the lofty palace mentioned by Allah, Blessed and Exalted. Mikhlaf Khaywan. Mikhlaf of Najdi Khawlan Dhi Suhaym and its Ghawri (lowland) part, containing Riyam, the fire which the people of Yemen used to worship. On the right of Sana'a: Mikhlaf Shakir, Wadi'ah, Yam, and Arhab. Mikhlaf al-Hardah and Hamdan. Mikhlaf Jawf Hamdan. Mikhlaf Jawf Murad. Mikhlaf Shanu'ah, Sada, and Ju'fi. Mikhlaf al-Jasrah. Mikhlaf al-Mashriq, Bushan, and Ghadar, containing Na'it. Mikhlaf A'la and An'am,

and Al-Masna'atayn, Bani Ghutayf, and the village of Ma'rib. (119) Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di said: "Or Sheba, the inhabitants of Ma'rib, When they build Al-Arim against its flood." In Ma'rib is the Palace of Solomon and Al-Qashib, the Palace of Bilqis. Ibn Dhi Jadan said: "Al-Qashib became desolate of its people, And the beloved departed from its quarters." And Sirwah and the Dam, which is Al-Arim. From Sana'a to Sada, Ju'fi, and Shanu'ah is forty-two parasangs. Mikhlaf Hadramawt; between it and Al-Jarr are sands. From Sada to it is thirty parasangs. So from Sana'a to Hadramawt is seventy-two parasangs. Mikhlaf Khawlan Rada', containing Wadi al-Naml. Mikhlaf Ahwar. Mikhlaf al-Haql. Dhamar ?y sixteen parasangs from Sana'a. Mikhlaf Bani Amir. That and Rada'. Mikhlaf Dathinah. Mikhlaf al-Sarw, and at its border is Marsa al-Khayr. Mikhlaf Ans. Mikhlaf Ru'ayn. Nasfan and Kahlan, containing Lake Baynun. Imru' al-Qays ibn Hujr said:

"And the abode of Bani Sawasah in Ru'ayn, Men go mad on its sides." Mikhlaf Dankan and Dhabhan. Mikhlaf Nafi' and Mashu. Mikhlaf Hajar, Badr, Akhillah, and Al-Suhib. Mikhlaf Lahij. Mikhlaf Abyan, containing Aden. (120) Mikhlaf Ba'dan and Rayman. Mikhlaf Al-Thajjah and Al-Mazra'. Mikhlaf Dhi Makarib and Al-Amluk. From Sana'a to Dhamar is sixteen parasangs. From Dhamar to Nasfan and Kahlan is eight parasangs. From Nasfan to Hajar and Badr is twenty parasangs. From Hajar and Badr to the village of Aden, which is Mikhlaf Abyan, is twenty-four parasangs. So from Sana'a to Aden is sixty-eight parasangs. Mikhlaf Al-Salaf and Al-Adam. Mikhlaf Najlan and Nahb. Mikhlaf

Al-Janad. Mikhlaf Al-Sakasik, which is the end of Yemen. From Sana'a to Dhamar, as we said, is sixteen parasangs. From Dhamar to Ulu Yuhsib is eight parasangs. Yuhsib is the city of Zafar and its palace is Raydan. Imru' al-Qays said: "He settled standing and built a lofty structure On Raydan, high, unreachable." The kings of Yemen used to reside in Zafar. From Ulu Yuhsib to Al-Sahul is eight parasangs. From Al-Sahul to Al-Thajjah is eight parasangs. From Al-Thajjah to Al-Janad is eight parasangs. So from Sana'a to Al-Janad is forty-eight parasangs. To the left returning to Sana'a: Mikhlaf Dhi Shu'bayn. Mikhlaf Al-Ziyadi. Mikhlaf Al-Ma'afir. Mikhlaf Bani Majid, containing the good Baqrani (carnelian?). Mikhlaf Al-Rakb. Mikhlaf Sulb and Nafd (121) and Al-Ighar. Mikhlaf Al-Manakhiyyin, containing Al-Mudhaykhirah, a fortified castle inhabited by the family of...

of Dhi Manakh; in it is the house of Ibn Abi Ja'far al-Manakhi of Himyar. Mikhlaf Haml, Damth, and Shar'ab. Mikhlaf 'Annah, 'Inayah, and Raji'. Mikhlaf al-Sahul and Bani Sa'b. Mikhlaf Wahazhah. Mikhlaf Lower Yuhsib. Mikhlaf Upper Yuhsib. Mikhlaf al-Qufa'ah, al-Wazirah, and al-Hajar. Mikhlaf Zabid, and facing it is the coast of Ghalafiqah and the coast of al-Mandab. Mikhlaf Rama'. Mikhlaf Maqra. Mikhlaf Alhan. Mikhlaf Jablan, where al-Jablani from the family of Dhi Sharh resides; Jablan consists of two parts: the part of Obedience and the part of Disobedience. Mikhlaf Dhi Jarrah. Mikhlaf al-Haqlayn. Mikhlaf al-Urf and al-Akhrut.

From Sana'a to al-Urf is eight parasangs. From al-Urf to Alhan is ten parasangs. From Alhan to Jablan is fourteen parasangs. So from Sana'a to Jablan is thirty-two parasangs. From Jablan to Zabid and Rama' is twelve parasangs. Mikhlaf Khawlan behind Sana'a. Mikhlaf Jadad and Hawshab. Mikhlaf Akk, opposite which is the anchorage of Dahlak. Mikhlaf Mahsa'. Mikhlaf Haraz and Hawzan. Mikhlaf al-Akhruj and Majnah. Mikhlaf Hadur. Mikhlaf Ma'dhin and Hamlan, in which is the city of (122) Dahr. Mikhlaf Shakir and Shibam. Bayt Aqyan and al-Masani', inhabited by the family of Dhi Hawal, who are descendants of Dhi Maqar; among them is Yu'fir ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Kurayb al-Hawali. Imru' al-Qays said:

"And Bayt Aqyan and Hajar followed, Their numbers and wealth did not benefit them." He also said: "He removed Dhu Aras from al-Masani', Who had possessed the plains and the mountains." Mikhlaf Wadi' and al-Mu'allal, which is between Sana'a and Shibam. From Sana'a to Shibam is eight parasangs. The poet said: "This wicked time kept turning me around, Until it built for me a tent in Shibam." Mikhlaf al-Saghar. Mikhlaf Khanash and Milhan. Mikhlaf Hakam and Jazan and the anchorage of al-Sharjah. Mikhlaf Hajur and al-Maghrib. Mikhlaf Qadam, which aligns with the village of Mahjarah. Mikhlaf Hayyah and al-Kawdhan. Mikhlaf Masuh. Mikhlaf Kindah and al-Sakun. Mikhlaf al-Sadaf. The Stages (Sikak) between Ghamrah and Sana'a are forty-nine stages. From Sana'a to Dhamar is four stages. Between Dhamar and Aden is seven stages. Between Dhamar and al-Janad is four stages. Between Sana'a and Ma'rib (123) is seven stages. Between Ma'rib and 'Andal, which is Hadramawt, on camels is nine stages.

It was found in the Diwan of Kharaj (Land Tax) a report from some governors of Yemen that its tax collection was six hundred thousand dinars; this is the maximum collected from it in this state (Abbasid). The administrative divisions of Yemen in Islam were distributed among three governors: a governor over al-Janad and its Mikhlaws (districts), which is the largest; a governor over Sana'a and its Mikhlaws, which is the middle one; and a governor over Hadramawt and its Mikhlaws, which is the lowest. Buildings in Yemen: The people of Yemen said that the devils built for Dhu Bata', the King of Hamdan when Solomon, peace be upon him, married him to Bilqis, palaces. It was written on a stone: "We built Baynun, and we built Salhin, and Sirwah, and Mirwah, and Baynun in Ruhadah, Aydin, and Hindah, and Hunaydah, and Falthum, Buraydah, and seven councils in Qa'ah." Ibn Dhi Jadan said:

"After Baynun there is no eye nor trace, And after Salhin people build houses." It was read in Na'it on a palace an inscription: "This palace was built the year our journey was from Egypt." Wahb ibn Munabbih said: "That was more than one thousand six hundred years ago." In a fortress belonging to Shammar Yar'ash ibn Nashir An'am, an inscription in Himyaritic was found: "This is what Shammar Yar'ash built with the help of his master, the Sun." On the gate of the city of Zafar was found written: "To whom belongs Zafar? To the good Himyar. To whom belongs Zafar? To the evil Abyssinians. To whom belongs Zafar? To the free Persians. To whom belongs Zafar? To the merchant Quraysh. (124) To whom belongs Zafar? It returns to Himyar." Meaning it goes back to Himyar. The Abyssinians had conquered Yemen, and four kings from them ruled it for seventy-two years. The Road from Masjid Sa'd to Basra: To Bariq, then to al-Qala', then to Salman. The poet said: "Dead in Radman and dead in Salman, And dead at Ghazzat."

Then to Aqr, then to al-Akhadid, then to Ayn Sayd, then to Ayn Jamal, then to Basra. The Road from Basra to Mecca: From Basra to al-Manjashaniyya, then to al-Hufayr, then to al-Rahil, then to al-Shaji, then to al-Kharja', then to al-Hafr, then to Mawiya, then to Dhat al-Ushr, then to al-Yansu'ah, then to al-Samina, then to al-Nibaj, then to al-Awsaja, then to al-Qaryatayn, then to Rama. Yazid ibn Mufarrigh al-Himyari said: "Did you cut your rope from Umama, After the days of Barama?" Then to Imrah, then to Takhfah. Jarir said: "And I have made a day at Takhfah for our horses, For the family of Abu Qabus, a day denied (unpleasant)." Then to Dariyya, then to Jadila, then to Falja, then to al-Dafina,

Then to Quba, then to Marran, then to Wajrah, then to Awtas, then to Dhat Irq, then to Bustan Bani Amir, then to Mecca. Whoever turns from al-Nibaj goes to al-Nuqrah. The Road from al-Yamamah to Mecca: (125) From al-Yamamah to al-Ard. Ibn Mufarrigh said: "Or an owl calling the thirsty, Between al-Mushaqqar and al-Yamamah." Then to al-Hadiqah, then to al-Sayh, then to al-Thaniyya, then to Suqayra', then to al-Sadd, then to Sadah, then to Sharifa, then to al-Qaryatayn on the Basra road, then to the stations mentioned previously to Mecca. The Road from Oman to Mecca on the Coast: From Oman to Farq, then to Awkalan, then to the coast of Habah, then to al-Shihr, which is the land of Frankincense (Kundur). The poet said:

"Go to al-Shihr and leave Oman, If you don't find dates, you find frankincense." Then to Mikhlaf Kindah, then to Mikhlaf Abd Allah ibn Madhhij, then to Mikhlaf Lahij, then to Aden Abyan, then to the pearl diving sites, then to Mikhlaf Bani Majid, then to al-Manjalah, then to Mikhlaf al-Rakb, then to al-Mandab, then to Mikhlaf Zabid, then to Ghalafiqah, then to Mikhlaf Akk, then to al-Hardah, then to Mikhlaf Hakam, then to Athr, then to the anchorage of Dankan, then to the anchorage of Hali, then to al-Sarrin, then to Aghyar, then to al-Harjab, then to al-Shu'aybah, then to a station (Manzil), then to Jeddah, then to Mecca. The Road from Khawlan Dhi Suhaym to Mecca: (126) From Khawlan Dhi Suhaym to al-Arsh of Jazan, then to Bisha Bi'atan, then to Wadi Dankan, then to Hali, then to Bisha Ibn Ja'wan, then to Qanuna. Nusayb said:

"Residing in al-Majazah of Qanuna, And your family is in al-Ujayfir, then al-Thamad." Then to al-Hasbah, then to Dawqah, then to 'Ulayb, then to Yababah. The poet said: "My heart spent the evening distracted by them, Between Qanuna, then 'Ulayb, then Yababah." Then to a station, then to al-Lith, then to Yalamlam, the Miqat of the people of Yemen, then to Mulkan, then to Mecca. The Road from Egypt to Mecca: From Fustat to al-Jubb, then to al-Buwayb, then to the station of Ibn Bunduqah, then to 'Ajrud, then to al-Dhanabah, then to al-Kursi, then to al-Hafr, then to a station, then to Ayla, then to Haql, then to Madyan, then to al-Aghra', then to a station, then to al-Kilabah, then to Shaghb, then to Bada, then to al-Sarhatayn, then to al-Bayda', then

to Wadi al-Qura, then to al-Rahibah, then to Dhu al-Marwah, then to al-Marr, then to al-Suwayda', then to Dhu Khushub, then to Medina, then to the stations mentioned previously to Mecca. The Road from Damascus to Mecca: (127) From Damascus to a station, then to a station, then to Dhat al-Manazil, then to Sargh, then to Tabuk, then to al-Muhdathah, then to al-Aqra', then to al-Junaynah, then to al-Hijr, then to Wadi al-Qura. The poet said: "Convey to Abu Bakr when the affair is settled, And the horses have passed Wadi al-Qura." Then to al-Rahibah, then to Dhu al-Marwah, then to al-Marr, then to al-Suwayda', then to Dhu Khushub, then to Medina, then to the stations mentioned previously to Mecca.

The Road from Basra to al-Yamamah: From it to a station, then to Kazima. The Rajiz poet said: "They reached in the morning from Kazima the reed hut, With Ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib." Another said: "He traveled in a night from between Kazima, To al-Nawasif of Thahlan, then al-Bayn." Then to a station, then to a station, then to a station, then to al-Qar'a, then to Takhfah, then to al-Samman. Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di said: "O abode of Salma in al-Haruriyya, be safe, Beside al-Samman, then al-Mutathallam." Then to a station, then to a station, then to a station, then to Jubb al-Turab, then to a station, then to a station, then to Salimah, then to al-Nibak, then to al-Yamamah. The Areas (A'rad) of al-Yamamah: Hajar and Jaww, which is al-Khadramah, a day and a night from Hajar. Al-Ard, which is (128) a valley splitting al-Yamamah from its top to its bottom, containing villages. Al-Manfuhah, Wabrah, al-Qirfah, Ghabra', Mahshamah, al-Amiriyya, Baysan, Barqah,

Dhahik, Tawdah, and al-Miqrah. Imru' al-Qays said: "So Tawdah, then al-Miqrah, its trace was not effaced, By what the south and north winds wove over it." And al-Majazah. The poet said: "Residing in al-Majazah of Qanuna, And your family is in al-Ujayfir, then al-Thamad." And Wadi Qarran. Villages of Bahrain: They are al-Khatt, al-Qatif, al-Arah, Hajar, al-Furuq, and Baynunah. Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di said: "Upon them, from the wild of Baynunah, Ewes with young in a herd." And al-Mushaqqar, al-Zarah, and Juwatha. The poet said: "It does not harm Ashnas not to have, The day of Juwatha and the day of Dhi Qar." And Sabun, Darin, al-Ghabah, and al-Shanun. The Road from al-Yamamah to Yemen: From al-Yamamah to al-Kharj, then to Nab'ah, then to al-Majazah, then

to al-Ma'dan, then to al-Shafaq, then to al-Thawr, then to al-Falaj, then to al-Safa, then to Bi'r al-Abar, then to Najran, then to al-Hima, then to Baranis, then to Muray', then to al-Mahjarah, then to the stations mentioned previously in the main road to Sana'a. End of the report of al-Tayman (The South). (129) Post Stages in the Kingdom: Nine hundred and thirty stages. The expenses of the animals, their prices, and the salaries of the couriers (Banadirah) and foot-messengers (Faraniqin) for a year are one hundred fifty-nine thousand one hundred dinars. The Route of the Jewish Merchants, the Radhanites: Who speak Arabic, Persian, Roman (Greek), Frankish, Andalusian, and Slavic. They travel from the East to the West and from the West to the East by land and sea. They bring from the West servants, slave girls, boys, brocade, beaver skins, furs, sable, and swords. They embark from Fancha (?) in the Western Sea, emerging at al-Farama, and carry their trade on backs to al-Qulzum - between them is twenty-five parasangs. Then they sail the Eastern Sea from al-Qulzum to al-Jar and Jeddah, then proceed to Sindh, India, and China. They carry from China musk, aloeswood, camphor, cinnamon, and other things

transported from those regions until they return to al-Qulzum. Then they carry it to al-Farama, then sail in the Western Sea. Sometimes they turn with their goods to Constantinople and sell them to the Romans. Sometimes they travel with them (130) to the King of the Franks and sell them there. If they wish, they carry their goods from the land of the Franks in the Western Sea, emerging at Antioch, travel on land for three stages to al-Jabiya, then sail in the Euphrates to Baghdad, then sail in the Tigris to al-Ubulla, and from al-Ubulla to Oman, Sindh, India, and China. All of this is connected. As for the route of the Rus merchants: They are a type of Slavs. They carry beaver skins, black fox skins, and swords from the furthest parts of the Slav lands to the Roman Sea, where the ruler of the Romans tithes them. If they travel in the Don (?) river of the Slavs, they pass by Khamlij, the city of the Khazars, where its ruler tithes them. Then they proceed to the Sea of Jurjan and disembark on whichever of its shores they wish. The diameter of this sea is five hundred parasangs. Sometimes they carry their goods from Jurjan on camels to Baghdad. Slavic servants translate for them. They claim to be Christians and pay the Jizya. As for their route on land: Whoever leaves from Spain or the land of the Franks crosses to al-Sus

al-Aqsa, then goes to Tangier, then to Ifriqiya, then to Egypt, then to Ramla, then to Damascus, then to Kufa, then to Baghdad, then to Basra, then to Ahwaz, then to Fars, then to Kirman, then to (131) Sindh, then to India, then to China. Sometimes they take the route behind Rome in the land of the Slavs, then to Khamlij the city of the Khazars, then in the Sea of Jurjan, then to Balkh and Transoxiana, then to the Yurt of the Toghuzghuz, then to China. The Inhabited Earth is divided into four parts: Arufi (Europe), containing al-Andalus, the Slavs, the Romans, the Franks, Tangier, up to the border of Egypt. Lubya (Libya/Africa), containing Egypt, al-Qulzum, Abyssinia, the Berbers, and adjoining lands, and the Southern Sea; in these lands there are no wild boars, deer, wild asses, or mountain goats. Ethiopia, containing Tihamah, Yemen, Sindh, India, and China. Scythia, containing Armenia, Khorasan, the Turks, and the Khazars. Among the wonders of the Earth: A fire in Sicily, al-Andalus, and India that burns in stones. If anyone tries to

carry a flame from it, it does not ignite. In Sicily there are no large ants called "horsemen" (Fursan), nor are there monkeys in the land of Cordoba due to the abundance of predatory beasts there. In the land of the Romans on the Sea of the Khazars, there is a land called al-Mustatilla (?) where rain is constant winter and summer. Its people cannot thresh or winnow their crops; they gather them in houses in the ears, take out what they need, rub it with their hands, (132) then grind and bake it. In their land, there are many falcons, as many as crows with us; they are in flocks. Despite their abundance, they cannot keep chickens. The people of Hijaz and Yemen receive rain all summer and have fertility in winter. The rain of Sana'a and its surroundings is in June, July, August, and some of September, from noon until sunset. A man meets another at midday and says: "Hurry before the rain," because rain is inevitable in these days. Among the wonders are two houses found in al-Andalus upon its conquest in the City of Kings. One of the houses, the House of Kings, was opened and found to contain twenty-four crowns, the number of their kings. The value of a single crown is unknown. On each crown is the name of its owner, his age, and how many years he ruled. In this house was found the Table of Solomon son of David, peace be upon them. On the other house were found twenty-four

locks. Whenever one of them became king, he added a lock to it. They did not know what was in the house until Roderic (Ludhariq) became king, the last of their kings. He said: "I must know what is in this house," imagining it contained wealth and jewels. The bishops and deacons gathered to him, magnifying the matter to him and asking him to follow what the kings before him did. He refused but to (133) open it. They said: "Consider whatever wealth you imagine is in it; we will gather it for you and give it to you, but do not open it." He disobeyed them and opened the door. Inside the house were pictures of the Arabs on their horses with their turbans, sandals, bows, and arrows. The Arabs entered their country in the year that door was opened. Qutayba ibn Muslim found in a city called Baykand huge pots that were reached by ladders. This is a circle depicted by the wise men in the shape of the world, showing to the eye that Allah Almighty, by the subtlety of His management, made these four natures mix from their extremities

and edges that resemble each other, like the mixing of heat with heat and cold with cold, as in this figure, until He created this world from them, despite the enmity and opposition between them. Praise be to Allah abundantly. Everything in this quarter is hot and moist, the nature of air, blood, spring, and youth (Saba). It has the East, its wind is the South, and its hours are the first, second, and third. Of the body's faculties, the natural digestive faculty. Of tastes, sweetness. Of planets, the Moon and Venus. Of Zodiac signs, Aries, Taurus, and Gemini. And upon Him I rely. Everything in this quarter is hot and dry, the nature of fire, yellow bile, summer, youth (Shabab), and the South (Tayman). Its wind is the East (Saba), and its hours are the fourth, fifth, and sixth. Of the body's faculties, the psychic and animal faculty. Of tastes, bitterness. Of planets, Mars and the Sun. Of Zodiac signs, Cancer, Leo, and Virgo. In Allah is help sought. Everything in this quarter is cold and moist, the nature of water, phlegm, winter, old age, and the West. Its wind is the West (Dabur), and its hours are the tenth, eleventh, and twelfth. Of tastes, what resembles salty. Of planets, Jupiter and Mercury. Of Zodiac signs, Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces. Of faculties, the expulsive. And to Him is the desire. Everything in this quarter is cold and dry, the nature of earth, black bile, autumn, maturity (Iktihal), and the North (Jarbi). Its wind is the North, and its hours are the seventh, eighth, and ninth. Of faculties, the retentive. Of tastes, astringent. Of planets, Saturn. Of Zodiac signs, Libra, Scorpio, and Sagittarius.

Among the wonders of construction are the two Pyramids in Egypt. The height of each is four hundred cubits; the higher it goes, the narrower it gets. They are of marble and alabaster. The length is four hundred cubits by a width of four hundred cubits, in the Royal cubit. Written on them in Musnad script is every magic and every wonder of medicine and astronomy. It is said, and Allah knows best, that they were built by Ptolemy al-Qaludhi the King. Written on them is: "I built them. Whoever claims strength in his kingdom, let him demolish them, for demolition is easier than building. Yet the revenue of the world would not suffice to demolish them." He said: Beside the two Pyramids are ten smaller pyramids. He said: Isma'il ibn Yazid al-Muhallabi, the scribe of Lu'lu' the slave of Ibn Tulun, narrated to me saying: We went out with Abu Abd Allah al-Wasiti, the scribe of Ahmad ibn Tulun, to one of the small pyramids. We had laborers with us. We found its surface area to be the resting place of ten camels. He ordered its demolition. They removed the first layer (134) of stones and reached crushed sand. Then they removed the second layer and reached the third layer, which had carved niches. They removed the third layer and descended into a courtyard measuring forty cubits by forty cubits. In it were four semi-domed chambers: northern, eastern, western, and southern. They were blocked by slab stone doors. We opened the eastern one and found in it an onyx jar with an onyx head in the shape of a pig, filled with mummy. We opened the western and southern ones and found in each the like of what we found in the eastern one, except that the shapes of the jar heads differed. In the courtyard were three hundred and sixty statues in the form of humans.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: resembling expiatory coverings. Then I opened the southern *Nimkhanjah* (chamber), and we found within it a jar of solid black stone, covered by the same material. We attempted to open it, but it was sealed with lead. We kindled a fire over it until the lead melted, and we opened it. Inside was a dead elder, and under his head was a tablet of white onyx. The fire we had kindled on the jar had cracked it and scorched the clothes that were on the dead man. We took the tablet and reassembled it, finding on one side two images of gold: one was the image of a man with a snake in his hand, and the other was the image of a man on a donkey with a staff in his hand. On the other side was the image of a man on a she-camel with a rod in his hand. We took all of that and went to Ahmad ibn Tulun. He called for a craftsman who reassembled the tablet, (135) and we agreed that the images were Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad, may the prayers of Allah be upon them all. He took one of the jars and gave Abu Abdallah the Scribe a single jar, and gave me one. I went with it to my house, took some aloeswood, and agitated the mummy inside it. It began to breathe slightly. I continued to manipulate it until I extracted it, and it turned out to be layers of cloth wrapped one over the other. I began to unfold them until I reached a piece of ox-hide upon which those wrappings were wound. I unfolded it, and when I reached the end of it, a drop of blood dripped from it. I do not know what that was, and Allah knows best. As for the construction of Rome and Alexandria, it is said that Alexandria was built in three hundred years, and that its people remained for seventy years unable to walk in it during the day except with black cloths over their eyes for fear of the intensity of the whiteness of its walls. Its marvelous lighthouse is upon a crab of glass in the sea (*Al-Jarr*). Besides its inhabitants, there were six hundred thousand Jews in it as servants to its people.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Memphis (Manf) is the city of Pharaoh where he used to reside. He made seventy gates for it and made the city walls of iron and brass. In it were the rivers that flowed from beneath his throne, which are four. (136) And the amphitheater of Famiya (Apamea), Palmyra, Baalbek, Lydda, and the Gate of Jayrun. And two columns at Ain Shams (Heliopolis) in the land of Egypt, which are remnants of columns that were there. At the top of each column is a band of copper. Water drips from one of them from under the band to the middle of the column; it does not go beyond it, and its dripping never ceases night or day. Its place on the column is green and wet, but the water does not reach the ground. It is from the construction of Hushang. And the Citadel of Sus in Ahwaz, which is a citadel upon a citadel; similar to it in construction is the Citadel of Sus al-Aqsa. Both are also from the construction of Hushang. The Romans say there is no stone structure more magnificent than the Church of Edessa (Al-Ruha), nor

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: any wooden structure more magnificent than the Church of Manbij, because it is made of arches of jujube wood; nor any marble structure more magnificent than the Qasiyan of Antioch; nor any structure of stone arches more magnificent than the Church of Homs. But I say: There is no structure of gypsum and baked brick more magnificent than the Iwan of Kisra at Al-Mada'in (Ctesiphon). Al-Buhturi said: 'As if the Iwan, out of the wonder of its craft, is a hollow in the side of a prominent, towering mountain. Battlements rise for it, raised upon the heads of Radwa and Quds. It is not known whether men made it for Jinn to dwell in, or Jinn made it for men.' (137) And the Khawarnaq of Bahram Gur in Kufa. The poet said: 'The tribes of Qahtan built their glory, and their rulers are with Bahram Gur. And by his Iwan, the Khawarnaq, among them, they knew the trace of their kingdom and Al-Sadir.' And there is no stone structure more solid or magnificent than the Shadharwan (Weir) of Tustar, for it is made of boulders, iron columns, and lead mortar. And the carving of Shabdaz is a hollow in the mountain. And the Barrier of Yajuj and Majuj (Gog and Magog). Description of the Barrier of Yajuj and Majuj: Salam the Interpreter told me that when Al-Wathiq Billah saw in his dream that the Barrier built by Dhu al-Qarnayn between us and Yajuj and Majuj had opened, he sought a man to send to the place to inquire about it. Ashnas said, 'There is no one here

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: suitable except Salam the Interpreter,' who used to speak thirty languages. He said: Al-Wathiq called for me and said, 'I want you to go out to the Barrier so that you may see it and bring me news of it.' He assigned fifty strong young men to me, gave me five thousand dinars, and gave me my blood money of ten thousand dirhams. He ordered that each of the fifty men be given a thousand dirhams and a year's provision. He ordered that felt garments covered with leather be prepared for the men, and he made for them fur gloves and wooden stirrups. He gave me two hundred mules to carry provisions and water. So we set out (138) from Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) with a letter from Al-Wathiq Billah to Ishaq bin Ismail, the ruler of Armenia, who was at Tiflis, regarding our dispatch. Ishaq wrote for us to the Master of the Throne (Sahib al-Sarir), and the Master of the Throne wrote for us to the King of the Alans, and the King of the Alans wrote for us to Filan Shah, and Filan Shah wrote for us to Tarkhan, King of the Khazars. We stayed with the King of the Khazars for a day and a night until he sent five guides with us. We traveled from his place for twenty-six days and ended up at a black land with a foul stench. We had equipped ourselves with vinegar before entering it to smell against the offensive odor. We traveled in it for ten days. Then we came to ruined cities and traveled in them for twenty days. We asked about the condition of those cities, and we were told that they were the cities that Yajuj and Majuj used to infiltrate, so they destroyed them. Then we came to fortresses near the mountain in a gorge of which is the Barrier. In those

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: fortresses are a people who speak Arabic and Persian, are Muslims, read the Quran, and have Quranic schools and mosques. They asked us where we came from, and we informed them that we were envoys of the Commander of the Faithful (Amir al-Mu'minin). They began to wonder and say, 'The Commander of the Faithful?' We said, 'Yes.' They said, 'Is he an old man or a young man?' We said, 'A young man.' They wondered even more and said, 'Where is he?' We said, 'In Iraq, in a city called Surra Man Ra'a.' They said, 'We have never heard of this.' Between each of those fortresses and the next is a farsakh to two farsakhs, less or more. Then we came (139) to a city called Ikkah; its area is ten farsakhs square. It has iron gates; the gates are lowered from above. Inside the city are farms and mills. It is the place where Dhu al-Qarnayn camped with his army. Between it and the Barrier is a journey of three days. Between it and the Barrier are fortresses and villages until you reach the Barrier on the third day. It is a round mountain. They mentioned that Yajuj and Majuj are within it, and they are two types. They mentioned that Yajuj is taller than Majuj, and the height of one of them is between a cubit and a cubit and a half, less or more. Then we came to a high mountain upon which is a fortress. The Barrier which

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Dhu al-Qarnayn built is a pass between two mountains, two hundred cubits wide. It is the path from which they emerge and disperse into the earth. He dug its foundation thirty cubits deep and built it with iron and copper until he brought it to the surface of the earth. Then he raised two jambs facing the mountain on both sides of the pass; the width of each jamb is twenty-five cubits with a thickness of fifty cubits. Ten cubits protrude from beneath them outside the gate (?). The entire construction is of iron bricks submerged in copper. The brick is a cubit and a half by a cubit and a half, with a thickness of four fingers. There is an iron lintel (*darwand*), its ends resting on the two jambs; its length is one hundred and twenty cubits. It is fitted onto the two jambs, each end resting by ten cubits, with a width of five cubits. Above the lintel (140) is construction with those iron bricks in copper up to the top of the mountain, and its height is as far as the eye can see. The construction above the lintel is about sixty cubits. Above that are iron battlements; at the end of each battlement are two horns, each bending towards the other. The length of each battlement is five cubits with a width of four cubits. There are thirty-seven battlements on it. Suddenly, there is an iron gate with two leaves

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: hanging; the width of each leaf is fifty cubits, with a height of seventy-five cubits and a thickness of five cubits. Their pivots are in a socket proportional to the lintel. No wind enters through the gate or from the mountain, as if it were created naturally. On the gate is a lock seven cubits long and a fathom thick in circumference. Two men cannot embrace the lock. The height of the lock from the ground is twenty-five cubits. Above the lock by about five cubits is a bolt whose length is greater than the length of the lock, and its two hasps are each two cubits. On the bolt is a hanging key, a cubit and a half long. It has twelve teeth; each tooth is shaped like the pestle of a mortar. The circumference of the key is four spans. It hangs on a chain welded to the gate, eight cubits long with a circumference of four spans. The ring holding the chain is like the ring of a mangonel. The threshold of the gate is ten cubits wide by one hundred cubits long, excluding what is under the two jambs; the exposed part is five cubits. (141) All these cubits are the black cubit. With the gate are two fortresses, each being two hundred cubits by two hundred cubits. At the gate of these two fortresses

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: are two trees. Between the two fortresses is a fresh spring. In one of the fortresses are the building tools with which the Barrier was built, including iron pots and iron ladles. On each tripod are four pots like soap pots. There are remnants of iron bricks there, rusted together. The chief of those fortresses rides out every Monday and Thursday—they inherit that gate just as Caliphs inherit the Caliphate. He comes riding with three men; on the neck of each man is a sledgehammer. There is a staircase at the gate. He climbs to the top of the stairs and strikes the lock a blow at the beginning of the day. A clamor is heard from them [Yajuj and Majuj] like a hive of wasps, then they fall silent. When it is noon, he strikes it another blow and listens to the gate; their clamor the second time is more intense than the first, then they fall silent. When it is time for Asr, he strikes another blow, and they make a noise like that again. Then he sits until sunset, then departs. The purpose of striking the lock is so that those behind the gate hear it and know that there are guards there, and so these [guards] know that those [Yajuj and Majuj] have not caused any damage to the gate.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Near this place is a large fortress, ten farsakhs by ten farsakhs, the area (?) of which is one hundred farsakhs. Salam said: I said to those present from the people of the fortresses, (142) 'Has anything ever damaged this gate?' They said, 'Nothing is in it except this crack.' The crack was crosswise, thin like a thread. I said, 'Do you fear anything for it?' They said, 'No, this gate is five cubits thick by the cubit of Alexander, which is a cubit and a half by the black cubit for every single cubit of Alexander.' He said: I approached and took a knife from my boot and scraped the place of the crack, extracting about half a dirham's worth from it to tie in a handkerchief to show Al-Wathiq Billah. On the single right leaf of the gate, high up, is written in iron in the primal language: 'So when the promise of my Lord comes, He will make it level, and the promise of my Lord is true' [Quran 18:98]. We looked at the construction; most of it is striped: a row of yellow copper and a row of black iron. In the mountain, the place where the gates were cast is excavated, as well as the place of the pots where the copper was mixed, and the place where lead and copper were boiled. There are pots resembling brass; each pot has three handles containing chains and hooks with which the copper was hoisted to the top of the wall. We asked those there, 'Have you seen any of Yajuj and Majuj?' They mentioned that they once saw a number of them on top of the mountain, but a black wind blew and threw them to their side. The size of a man, according to the eye, was a span and a half. The mountain, from the outside,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: has no flat top or slope, nor is there vegetation, grass, trees, or anything else on it. It is a smooth, standing, flat, white mountain. (143) When we departed, the guides took us towards Khorasan. The king was called Al-Lub. Then we left that place and came to the place of a king called Tabanuyin, who is the owner of the land tax. We stayed with them for some days and traveled from that place until we arrived at Samarkand in eight months. We arrived at Isfijab and crossed the river of Balkh, then proceeded to Ushrusana, Bukhara, and Termez, then we reached Nishapur. Of the men who were with us, twenty-two died or fell sick on the way out; those who died were buried in their clothes, and those who fell sick were left in some villages. On the return, fourteen men died. So we arrived at Nishapur with fourteen men. The people of the fortresses had provided us with enough supplies. Then we went to Abdullah bin Tahir, who gave me eight thousand dirhams and gave each man with me five hundred dirhams. He granted an allowance of five dirhams daily for a horseman and three dirhams for a foot soldier until Rayy. None of the mules

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: that were with us survived except twenty-three mules. We arrived at Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra), and I entered upon Al-Wathiq and informed him of the story and showed him the iron I had scraped from the gate. He praised Allah and ordered alms to be given. He gave the men one thousand dinars each. Our arrival at the Barrier took sixteen months, and we returned in twelve (144) months and some days. Salam the Interpreter told me the summary of this news, then dictated it to me from a book he had written for Al-Wathiq Billah. Among the wonders of the natures of lands: Whoever enters Tibet does not cease laughing and being happy without knowing the reason until he leaves it. Whoever among the Muslims enters lands at the end of China called Al-Sila, which has much gold, settles there because of its pleasantness and never leaves it at all. Whoever stays in Mosul for a year finds a clear surplus in his strength. Whoever stays in the capital of Ahwaz for a year and checks his intellect finds it diminished; no one with red cheeks is found there, and fever there is perpetual. Al-Jahiz mentioned that a number of midwives of Ahwaz informed him that they might deliver a newborn and find it feverish. The capital of Ahwaz gathers vipers in its mountain that pierces into its dwellings and overlooks it, and in its houses are deadly scorpions (*Jarrarat*). Ghaliya and perfume spoil there after two months, and likewise in Antioch. Whoever enters the land of Zanj must get scabies. Whoever fasts for a long time in Al-Massisa

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: in the summer, black bile is stirred up in him, and he may go mad. Whoever lives in Bahrain, his spleen becomes enlarged. The poet said: 'And whoever lives in Bahrain, his spleen enlarges, and he is envied for what is in his belly while he is hungry.' (145) They have unripe dates called Al-Nabiji; if made into wine and drunk, it changes the whiteness of the sweat until it turns yellow. Whoever walks in the City of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, finds a wondrously pleasant scent. In Shiraz, in the land of Fars, there is a pleasant fragrance. The wise said: The best land by creation is Rayy, and it has Al-Sarr and Al-Sarban. The best by construction is Jurjan. The best by distinction is Tabaristan. The best by extraction is Nishapur. The best land, ancient and modern, is Jundishapur, which has beautiful rivers. And Merv, which has the Raziq the Gentle and the Majan. And Al-Ghuta, which has the two valleys; whoever persists in eating onions there for forty days gets freckles on

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: his face. Nusaybin has the Hirmas. Al-Saymara has what the two fortresses contain. Basra has the two rivers. Fars has the Pass of Bawan. Mustashraf Shahrazur and Bakarkha have a garden from here and a garden from there, and a river in the middle. Al-Mada'in, Sus, and Tustar are between four valleys: Dujayl, Al-Masruqan, Mahruban, and Al-Basiyan. Nahavand, Isfahan, and Balkh. The most delightful of them, combining scent and beauty, is the Overlook (Mustashraf) of Samarkand from the mountain of Sogd. Hudayn bin al-Mundhir al-Raqashi likened it, saying: 'It is like the sky for greenness, its palaces are the stars for brightness, its river is the Milky Way for crossing, and its wall is the sun for covering.' (146) King Qubadh said: 'The best of my kingdom for fruits are Al-Mada'in, Sabur, Arrajan, Rayy, Nahavand, Hulwan, and Masabadhan.' Among the wonders of water transformation: A mountain in Yemen from whose peak water springs and flows down its side; before it reaches the ground, it freezes and becomes this white Yemeni alum. And a valley in Azerbaijan whose water flows then turns to stone, becoming slabs of rock. Among the wonders of mountains: The Mountain of Al-Arj which is between Mecca and Medina; it continues to Sham until it connects with Lebanon of Homs* and Sanir of Damascus. Then it continues and connects

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: with Antioch and the mountains of Al-Massisa, where it is called Al-Lukam. It connects with the mountains of Malatya, Shimshat, and Qaliqala to the Sea of the Khazars, where Al-Bab and Al-Abwab are; there it is called Al-Qabq. The Veil of Kisra: Kisra used to be screened from five directions: Whoever came from Sham was screened at Hit; whoever came from Hijaz, at Al-Udhayb; whoever came from Fars, at Sarifin; whoever came from the Turks, at Hulwan; and whoever came from the Khazars and Alans, at Al-Bab and Al-Abwab. He would write about their news, and they would stay until his command regarding them was returned. Chapter on the Outlets of Rivers: The outlet of Jayhun, the river of Balkh, is from the mountains of Tibet. It passes by Balkh, Termez, Khasasak (147) (the city of the Kurdan, having villages), Amul, Haramari, Farbr, and Khwarazm until it pours into the Sea of Jurjan at Lake Kardan. The outlet of Mihran, the river of Sindh, is from the mountains of Shughnan. The river of Sindh is a branch

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: of the river Jayhun. Part of the kingdom of India is attributed to it. It passes by Al-Mansura and pours into the Great Eastern Sea after rivers in the land of India flow into it. The outlet of the Euphrates is from Qaliqala. It passes through the land of the Romans and is fed by many springs. Arsanas, the river of Shimshat, flows into it. It comes to Kamakh and exits two miles from Malatya. It comes to Jabalata until it reaches Sumaysat; from there ships and rafts are carried. It comes until it reaches the Sawad, then rivers branch off from it in the Sawad of Baghdad. It pours into the Tigris. Part of it passes through Kufa, penetrating its Sawad, then also pours into the Tigris below Al-Mada'in. The outlet of the Tigris is from the mountains of Amid. It passes the mountains of Al-Salsala and is fed by many springs from the regions of Armenia. Then it passes by Balad; from there ships and rafts are carried. It is fed by the two Zabs, Al-Nahrawan, and the two Sarats. It pours into the Marshes (Al-Bata'ih), then pours into the Blind Tigris (Dijlah al-Awra), then pours into the Eastern Sea. The outlet of Al-Rass, the river of Armenia, is from Qaliqala. It passes by Arran, and the river of Arran flows into it. Then it passes by Warthan until it reaches the Junction, which is the Meeting of the Two Seas which

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Allah, Mighty and Holy, mentioned. It and the Kur join; between them is the city of Al-Baylaqan. When (148) they join, they flow until they pour into the Sea of Jurjan. The outlet of Isbidhrudh is from the gate of the city of Sisar. The outlet of Shah-rudh is from Taligan of Rayy; they join and pour into the Sea of Jurjan. The outlet of the two Zabs is from the mountains of Armenia, and they pour into the Tigris; the Greater pours at Al-Haditha and the Lesser at Al-Sinn. Ibn Mufarrigh said: 'Verily, he who lived treacherous to his covenant, and died a slave, is Allah's slain by the Zab.' The outlet of Al-Nahrawan is from the mountains of Armenia. It passes by Bab Salwa, where it is called Tamarra. It is fed by the Qatuls. When it reaches Bajisra, it is called Al-Nahrawan, and it pours into the Tigris below Jabbal. The outlet of Al-Khabur is from Ra's al-Ayn. It is fed by the Hirmas and pours into the Euphrates at Qarqisiya. The outlet of the Hirmas is from Tur Abdin and it pours into the Khabur. The outlet of Al-Balikh is from Ayn al-Dhahbanah in the land of Harran, and it pours into the Euphrates below Al-Raqqa the Crooked. The outlet of Al-Tharthar is from the Hirmas; it passes by Al-Hadr (Hatra) and pours into the Tigris.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The outlet of the Nile of Egypt is from the Mountain of the Moon (Jabal al-Qamar) in Yemen. It pours into two lakes behind the Equator. It circles the land of Nubia and comes to Egypt. Part of it pours at Damietta into the Roman Sea, and the rest cuts through Fustat until it also pours into the Roman Sea. The outlet of Dujayl of Ahwaz is from the land of Isfahan (149) and it pours into the Eastern Sea. The outlet of the river of Jundishapur, upon which is the Bridge of the Zab, is also from Isfahan and pours into Dujayl of Ahwaz. The outlet of the River of Sus is from Dinawar, and it also pours into Dujayl of Ahwaz. The Masruqan branches from Dujayl above the Shadharwan of Tustar and pours into the Eastern Sea. The outlet of Zarrin Rudh, the valley of Isfahan, is from there. It waters its rustaqs, which are seventeen rustaqs, then sinks into the sand at the end of them. Then it emerges in Kirman, sixty farsakhs from the place where it sank, waters the land of Kirman, then pours into the Eastern Sea. That was known by a rod on which was written, thrown into it, and it came out in Kirman. The outlet of Sayhan, the river of Adana, is from the land of the Romans and pours into the Roman Sea.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The outlet of Jayhan, the river of Al-Massisa, is from the land of the Romans. It pours into the river of Al-Tinat, is fed by Wadi al-Zanj, and also pours into the Roman Sea (Al-Jarr al-Shami). The outlet of Al-Arand (Orontes), the river of Antioch, is from the land of Damascus towards the desert road. It runs with the south and pours into the Roman Sea. The outlet of Barada, the river of Damascus, is from that place; it waters the Ghuta and pours into the Lake of Damascus. The outlet of Quwayq, the river of Aleppo, is from a village called Sinyab, seven miles from Dabiq. Then it passes to Aleppo, eighteen miles. Then it passes to Qinnasrin, twelve miles. Then to Marj al-Ahmar, twelve miles. Then it overflows into the swamp. So from its source to its sink is forty-two miles towards the Qibla of Jerusalem (Hajar) .....

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: (150) In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Some of those I trust who stuck to the trading lands narrated that there are waters beyond Jayhun, the river of Balkh, and great rivers like Jayhun... [drink?] which is a river called Kankar at the beginning of the kingdom of Shash, a river called Turk, a river called Siyawat, and a river called Taraz-ab, and others in which great ships sail in the Turk lands to the end of China. They flow from the east to the west. And the rivers of Sarakhs, the flow of its water from springs, Nishapur, Rayy, and the border of Iraq to the end of the first station of Al-Qadisiyah at the head of the desert, flow from the west to the east, like the river of Hulwan, the river of Ardabil, the river of Dabil, the river of Nahrawan, the Tigris, the Euphrates, and every branch of them. It is mentioned that Jayhun, from where it branches into two branches, has its source from the mountains of China and what is beyond China. It runs among great stones and huge rocks such that it is not possible to navigate a ship in it, nor for one not used to it to cross. At a distance of three and a half days from its fork, where one of its branches flows to Sindh and one branch is Jayhun, there is a crossing to the Turks who are called Shakina. They equip themselves from the city of Khuttalan to a Ribat called Ribat Fulan at a distance of a farsakh from it. Then they go out to a mountain on the bank of this great river. Hardly any human passes over the back of that mountain except the strong non-Arabs (*Al-'Uluj*) who are accustomed to crossing it. When merchants descend upon them, they hire them to carry their loads and goods to the peak of that mountain. They walk on it (?) carrying about thirty *mann*; each man among them carries this until they reach (151) the top of the peak. When they are settled on it—and they have markers set up between them and

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the people of Al-Shughnan seeing them from this side, for example—when they see those markers, they become certain that the merchants have landed on the top of the peak. It is a path the size of a man's foot to walk on. If the merchants descend, a strong non-Arab (*'Ilj*) from among them advances and descends to the bottom of this river from the peak of the mountain with what is on him. When the strong non-Arabs see the merchants, they have camels they have taught to cross that river. They cross on them, accompanied by a guard for them, until they meet the merchants. They conclude their covenants and agreements with the merchants, then carry their heavy loads and goods and cross with them on the backs of their camels. Then every merchant among them takes his way on this, going to China and to Multan. This water is mentioned to pass over the Mountain of Gold and passes by great stones and rocks, grinding from it gold resembling the scale of fish skin, smaller and larger. On this river, below this crossing, is a village called Wakhad. They have a penetration from the side of Wayshijird called the River Bakhshu which falls into Jayhun. Its people come out from Bakhshu until they descend on the bank of Jayhun. They spread goat skins with the hair facing up on the bank of the river and tie and secure them with stakes all around. One of them goes down into the river on the bank and splashes water onto those skins, and another wipes the water from the skins and releases it. The water is turbid and heavy. When they know that the roots of the hair of the skins are full of sand and gold, they take it and spread it on the face of the ground in the eye of the sun. When it dries, they take them—and they have leather mats spread out—and shake them there and take the gold from them. It is mentioned in Balkh that it is the finest, reddest, and purest gold.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: In the city called Khuttalan—which is the kingdom of Al-Harith bin Asad, cousin of Dawud bin Abi Dawud bin Abbas, who raided Firuz—there are over a thousand springs. It has two springs: a spring at the Lower Gate and a spring at the Upper Gate; the upper one is called Nazkul. (152) Abu al-Fadl, the horse-trainer of Ibn al-Harith bin Asad, narrated that the origin of the Khuttali workhorses, whose breed is praised, is from that spring. In the time of a king there called Bayk, he had many broodmares that he sent into the pasture to graze in the meadows. They would shelter at that spring in the midday heat under the shade of a tree to nap there. The shepherd would gather his beasts to it. It is wide and broad, about four hundred cubits by the same, containing still, stagnant, clear water. One day, the shepherd, having woken from his sleep among his horses, saw a tall workhorse, as tall as can be. A terrifying thing appeared to him plainly, so he began to watch it to see what it was. When the time of Asr approached, it dove into the spring. The shepherd remained bewildered. He continued to shelter at that spring, watching, until one day that very workhorse came out accompanied by a filly and many other horses. They mixed with his horses constantly in the pasture until they became accustomed to his horses. This workhorse impregnated a filly from the fillies of that King which were with the shepherd. She gave birth to a large, excellent foal ... in stature. When the shepherd saw that, he was pleased and rejoiced, and he informed his master of it. The King's joy was great, and he went out with his stewards to hunt, inclining towards the pasture of his horses and grass. He came to the enclosure of his shepherd and ordered his trainer to lasso a foal from those foals that were the offspring of the stallion in the spring. He threw the lasso on a foal among them, saddled it, and rode it. It was as if it flew between the sky and the earth, smooth in the bridle, light in rising. When

He dismounted and put down his saddle. Then those workhorses came out from the pasture with what had been born among them, except for the one that gave birth to foals; they all returned to the spring, and no beast came out of it until this time (153), nor did any appear. So, the breed of Khuttalani workhorses remained from them. This narrator told me about a merchant named Abdullah al-Shakhshi, a person known in Balkh and its surroundings, that he bought a beast from them whose height in the sky was three cubits by the black cubit, and its width was a cubit as well. Among the wonders narrated is that a city called Kesh, a two-day journey from Samarkand, has a large, high obstacle between them. Behind Kesh are mountains of snow where the snow of every year is distinct, so that if a person with sharp vision were there, he could count the snow of past years from every year; and between the snow of each year is a red, dusty line from the summer days, as it was unable [to melt]. In that snow are large white worms like elephants. If they descend from... ? extended until... ? much water comes out of it and extends with what melts from the snows and falls to mountains called the mountains of.......... [In] the mountains is a large spring called Hashtadan Dar, and much water comes out of it, and it is called in Samarkand the River of Jirt, which is the river of Bukhara. A narrator told me that he had a need in that region, so he went out to it, and he had a friend there. He asked him about the wonders of this spring, and he informed him that there are inhabitants in it...

...on the water in the form of the sons of Adam, the most beautiful that Allah has created. A shepherd from this village used to bring his sheep to this spring, and some shepherds would descend to it but not get close to it. This shepherd used to play the string instrument, the reed pipe, and the flute. And it was.......... the flute and the reed pipe (154), and they would float on the surface of the water, listening to him and taking pleasure in the sound of his singing. While he was there one day, having played the two strings and slept at the head of the spring, the people of the spring deliberately came openly onto the surface of the water and seized him against his will, taking him to them. When a day and a night had passed over him and he did not return to his family, they grieved for him. They came to that spring to track his traces and found him floating on the surface of the water, moving along, while the people of the spring were forcing him to play the flute and strike the string. His family pleaded with them and asked them to release him, but they did not answer their request. They remained like that for eight days, with no one daring to enter the spring to rescue him. When they woke up after the eighth day, they did not see the shepherd nor anyone with him from them, and his matter was hidden from them. Hisham bin Muhammad mentioned, saying: Some of those I trust told me on the authority of Hamid ibn Bahra, the Dehghan of Lower Fallujah, that there were great wonders in four cities. In the first of them, there was formerly a representation of the entire earth; if some of the people of his kingdom rebelled against him regarding his land tax, he would breach its rivers upon them [on the map], so they would drown wherever they were, unable to block it until they paid what they owed. If he blocked its rivers against them in its representation, they would be blocked against them in their lands. In the second city, there was a basin; if the king wanted to gather them for his food, he brought whatever he liked...
...of the drinks from them, and poured it into that basin, and it would all mix together. Then the cupbearers would stand (155) and take the vessels; whoever poured something into his vessel...

An excerpt from the Book of Land Tax and the Art of Writing by Abu al-Faraj Qudama bin Ja'far the Scribe of Baghdad. Chapter Eleven: On the Bureau (Diwan) of the Post, the Routes, and the Roads to the Regions of the East and the West. Abu al-Faraj said: The Post requires a bureau solely for it, and the letters sent from all regions should be intended for its director, so that he is the one who forwards everything from them to the place designated for it to go. He undertakes the presentation of the letters of the postmasters and the news in all regions to the Caliph or making summaries of them. He oversees the matter of the couriers, the signatories, and those stationed on the routes, and the processing of their salaries, and the investiture of the pouch-bearers in the rest of the garrison cities. What is required in the director of this bureau is that he be trustworthy, either in...

...himself or to the Caliph undertaking the command in his time, because this bureau does not involve work that requires a capable examiner; rather, it requires a trustworthy preserver. The protocols required for the bureau are close to the protocols we have explained elsewhere regarding what regulates its works and conditions. As for other matters regarding the roads, the locations of the routes, and the paths to all regions, we have not mentioned them. However, the director of this bureau cannot do without having with him that which he does not need to refer to others for, and if the Caliph asks him about it at a time of need for his departure or sending an army whose matter concerns him, or other things for which necessity calls for knowledge of the roads, he finds it ready with him and recorded by him, without needing to burden himself with working it out or asking about it. It is appropriate that we now begin to mention that and enumerate it by the names of the places, mentioning the stations, the number of miles and farsakhs (parasangs), and other descriptions of the condition of the station regarding its water, its roughness, its smoothness, its population, or other aspects of its condition. We begin with the road taken from the City of Peace [Baghdad] to Mecca, which is the Greatest Rite and the Ancient House of Allah. After reaching it, we will proceed to mention what follows regarding the road to Yemen, then in the rest of the directions close to it, naming them, if Allah wills. From the City of Peace to the Bridge of Kutha on the River of the King (Nahr al-Malik) is seven farsakhs. From the Bridge of Kutha to the Palace of Ibn Hubayra is five farsakhs. From the Palace of Ibn Hubayra to Suq Asad is seven farsakhs. From Suq Asad to Sahi is five farsakhs. From Sahi to the city of Kufa is five farsakhs. From Kufa to al-Qadisiyyah is fifteen miles. From al-Qadisiyyah to al-Udhayb is six miles. Al-Udhayb was a garrison between the Arabs and the Persians at the border of the wilderness; it has two connected walls from al-Qadisiyyah to al-Udhayb, and on both sides are palm trees. If one exits...

...from it, the one exiting enters the desert. From al-Udhayb to al-Mughithah, which has cisterns, is fourteen miles. From al-Mughithah to al-Qara'a, which is a station containing wells, is thirty-two miles. From al-Qara'a to Waqisah, which has cisterns and wells, is twenty-four miles. From Waqisah to al-Aqabah, which has wells and a station, is twenty-nine miles. From al-Aqabah to al-Qa'a is twenty-four miles. From al-Qa'a to Zubalah, which is populous with many inhabitants, is twenty-four miles. From Zubalah to al-Shuquq, which has cisterns, is eighteen miles. From al-Shuquq to the Tomb of al-Abadi, which has cisterns, is twenty-nine miles. From the Tomb of al-Abadi to al-Tha'labiyyah is twenty-nine miles. From al-Tha'labiyyah to al-Khuzaymiyyah, which has a shortage of water, is thirty-three miles; al-Khuzaymiyyah is a city with a wall, a pulpit, a bathhouse, and cisterns, and it was named al-Khuzaymiyyah because Khuzaymah installed water wheels there; it used to be called Zarud, and its sand is red. From al-Khuzaymiyyah to al-Ajfar is twenty-four miles. From al-Ajfar to Fayd, which is the station of the official and has a canal, crops, and a pulpit, is thirty-six miles. From Fayd to Tuz, which has cisterns, wells, and a fortress built by Abu Dulaf, is thirty-three miles. From Tuz to Sumayra, which has cisterns, is sixteen miles. From Sumayra to al-Hajir, which has cisterns and wells, is twenty-three miles. From al-Hajir to the Mine of al-Naqrah (Ma'din al-Naqrah), which has wells and cisterns, is twenty-seven miles. From al-Naqrah to Mughithat al-Mawan is twenty-seven miles. From Mughithah to al-Rabadhah, whose water is plentiful and which has a pulpit, is twenty-four miles. From al-Rabadhah to the Mine of Banu Sulaym, which has wells and cisterns, is nineteen miles. From the Mine of Banu Sulaym to al-Umaq is twenty-six miles. From al-Umaq to Afa'iyah, which has little water, is thirty-two miles. From Afa'iyah to al-Maslah, which has much water, is thirty-four miles. From al-Maslah to al-Ghamrah, which has much water and from where one turns towards Yemen, is eighteen miles. From al-Ghamrah to Dhat Irq, which has much water and from where the Ihram (ritual consecration) takes place, is twenty-six miles.

If we return to al-Naqrah: From al-Naqrah to al-Usaylah, which has scarce water, is forty-six miles. From al-Usaylah to Batn al-Nakhl, which has much water and palm trees, is thirty-six miles. From Batn al-Nakhl to al-Taraf is twenty-two miles. From al-Taraf to Medina is thirty-five miles. As for the road from Medina to Mecca: From Medina to al-Shajarah, which has wells and cisterns—it is not a station, but from it the Ihram takes place—is six miles. From al-Shajarah to Malal, which has wells, is twelve miles. From Malal to al-Sayyalah, which has water and where peregrines and hawks are sold, is nineteen miles. From al-Sayyalah to al-Ruwaythah, which has water holes, is thirty-four miles. From al-Ruwaythah to al-Suqya, which has trees and running water, is thirty-six miles. From al-Suqya to al-Abwa, which has wells and farms, is twenty-nine miles. From al-Abwa to al-Juhfah, which has wells and is the port of al-Jarr, is twenty-seven miles. From al-Juhfah to Qudayd, which has wells for floodwater, is twenty-six miles. From Qudayd to Usfan, which has wells, is twenty-four miles. From Usfan to Batn Marr, which has palm trees, crops, and a pond in which water flows, is sixteen miles; Batn Marr is a great village with many people and houses, and four miles from it is the tomb of Maimuna, the wife of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and six miles from that is the Mosque of Aisha, then to Mecca is six miles, and from there the people of Mecca enter Ihram, and it is the boundary of the Sanctuary.
