So from Batn Marr to Mecca is sixteen miles. From Mecca is the road of Ta'if, three stages: From Mecca to the Well of Ibn al-Murtafi'. From the Well of Ibn al-Murtafi' to Qarn al-Manazil, a village from which the people of Yemen enter Ihram; one turns from it to Ta'if on the right. Whoever leaves Mecca intending for Ta'if comes to Arafat, then passes from it to Batn Na'man, a mountain called Na'man of the Clouds because clouds are always upon it. Then he ascends an obstacle (Aqabah) from it; when the ascender levels out upon it...

...he overlooks Ta'if, then descends and ascends again a light obstacle called Tan'im al-Ta'if. From al-Ghamrah, you turn towards Yemen: From al-Ghamrah to al-Jadad is twelve miles, which is the place of the Post and the dividing point of caravans; it has nothing but a single well, and palm trees and crops watered by camels, and it is the place of Yasar, the client of Uthman bin Affan. From al-Jadad to al-Fatq. From al-Fatq to Turabah, which is a great village with flowing springs and crops, and it is the village of Khalisa, the freedwoman of al-Mahdi. From Turabah to Safar, which is a station containing two houses for the Postmaster in the desert, and it has fresh water from two wells. From Safar to Kara, a station with palm trees and a fresh spring; there is nothing but the house of the Postmaster and the station for caravans, and it is in the belly of a valley with many palm trees. From Kara to Ranyah, a station in a desert with large palm trees and a great fresh spring, and the habitation around it is upon invitation. From Ranyah to Tabalah, a great village with many people, Mudarite for Qays, containing a pulpit, springs, and wells. From Tabalah to Bisha, a great village with many people in the belly of the valley, with visible water from springs and wells, Mudarite Qaysite. From Bisha to Jasda, a station of Bedouins from Qays. From Jasda to Banat Haram, a great village with many houses and crops, and the water is from a spring and a fresh well. From Banat Haram to Yabambam, a station in a desert with one fresh well and no people, and around it are Bedouins from Khath'am; between it and Jurash is about fourteen miles. From it to Kathbah, a great village with houses, palaces, and wells in a desert; between it and Jurash is eight miles. From Kathbah...

...to al-Thajjah, the location of the Post, and in it is a water well where caravans stop; it is in the land of Zabid, and around it are their Bedouins. From al-Thajjah to Sharum Rah, which is a great village in a desert with many springs and vineyards; in it is a clan from Hamdan called Janb. From Sharum Rah to al-Mahjarah, which is a great mountainous village with many springs and people. Between it and Sharum Rah is a tree called Talhat al-Malik (The King's Acacia); this tree is the boundary between Yemen and Hejaz. It is a tree resembling the poplar tree, except that it is larger, and the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used it to demarcate between Yemen and Mecca. From al-Mahjarah to 'Araqa, a station in a mountain with Bedouins from Khawlan; the water in it may be scarce or plentiful, and it is the first district of Yemen, belonging to the district of Sa'dah. From 'Araqa to Sa'dah, which is a great village containing a pulpit, a mosque, and many merchants. The tanning of Yemen for leather and sandals is done there. Most of their merchants are from the people of Basra. There is a road from it for the Basrans that returns to al-Rakibah then to Sa'dah. Sa'dah has administrative districts (Mikhlifs) and many villages. From Sa'dah to al-A'mashiyyah, a station in a mountain with no people, and their water is from a small spring under a tree, and around it is a tribe from Hamdan. From al-A'mashiyyah to Khaywan, a great village with a congregational mosque, a pulpit, and many people; it has vineyards described for the largeness of their bunches, it is mountainous, and the water is from the sky [rain], and its people are from Bakil. From Khaywan to Athafit, which is a great village with a pulpit; its people are Jushamites, its market is held on Friday, and it has crops and vineyards, and the drinking water is from a cistern. From Athafit to Raydah, a great village with a pulpit, many people, vineyards, crops...

...springs, and pasture in the belly of a valley, and its administration includes districts. From Raydah to Sana'a, the capital of Yemen. This is the road on which the milestones are located, and it is the road of the camels and the workers. If one who wants Mecca departs [he goes] to the Well of al-Hadha, a station containing nothing but a single well. From the Well of al-Hadha to a great, inhabited village, which is where the people of Yemen enter Ihram; its water is a flowing stream, and it is Qurayshite, called Qarn. Then from Qarn upwards is the intended road. We have written the road from Kufa to Mecca. As for the road from Basra to Mecca: From Basra to al-Hafir, then to Mawiyyah, then to Dhat al-Ushr, then to al-Yansnu'ah, then to al-Saminah, then to al-Nibaj, then to al-Awsajah, then to al-Qaryatayn, then to Ramah. From al-Nibaj there is a road to al-Naqrah. From Ramah to Imrah, then to Dariyah, then to Jadilah, then to Faljah, then to al-Dafinah, then to Qaba, then to Marran, then to Wajrah, then to Awtas, then to Dhat Irq, then to Bustan Ibn Amir, then to Mecca. As for the road from Egypt to Mecca, its stations in succession are as we describe: Fustat, al-Jubb, al-Buwayb, Baydamah, Manzil Ibn Maru, 'Ajrud, al-Rabibah, al-Kursi, al-Hisn, Manzil Ayla, Sharaf al-Ba'l, Madyan, al-Aghra', Manzil al-Kallabah, Shaghb, Bada...

...al-Sarhatayn, al-Bayda, Wadi al-Qura, al-Rahibah, Dhu al-Marwah, al-Suwayda, Khushub, Medina. As for the one who takes the coastal road: When he gets to Sharaf al-Ba'l, he goes to al-Sala, then to al-Nabk, then to Zibah, then to 'Uwaynid, then to al-Wajh, then to Manhus, then to al-Jarrah, then to al-Ahsa, then to Yanbu, then to Mas'ulan, then to al-Jar. From al-Jar to Medina is a journey of two days. As for the road from Damascus to Mecca, the stations from it are: to Dhat al-Manazil, then Sargh, then Tabuk, then al-Muhdathah, then al-Aqra', then al-Junaynah, then al-Hijr, then Wadi al-Qura, then Medina. As for the road from al-Yamama to Mecca: From it to al-Arid, to Hadiqah, to al-Sayh, to al-Thaniyyah al-Aqqa', to Suqayrah, to al-Sadd, to Mararah, to Suwayqah, and to al-Qaryatayn on the Basra road. From al-Yamama there is another road to Mans... Bahat al-Zulf, a station frequented by the people of al-Jawn, Mawiyyah on the Basra road. As for the road from Sana'a to Mecca via the stations: From it to al-Rahabah, then to the village of...

...Rafidah, then to Khaywan, then to Sa'dah, then to al-Nadh, then al-Qasabah, then al-Thajjah, then Kathbah, then Banat Haram, then Jasda, then Bisha, then Tabalah, then Ranyah, then al-Za'ra, then Safar, then al-Fatq, then Bustan Ibn Amir, then Mecca. As for the road from Mikhlaf Khawlan to Mecca: From it to Dhi Suhaym, then al-Arsh, then Bisha, then Dhankan, then Haly, then Yabah, then Ibn Jawan, then 'Alib, then al-Lith, then a station, then Yalamlam, then Malkan, then Mecca. As for the road from Oman to Mecca, via the coastal road the stations are: Farq, 'Awkalan, Coast of Manah, lands of al-Shihr, districts (Mikhlifs) of Kindah, districts of Abdullah bin Madhhij, Mikhlaf Lahj, Abyan, Aden, Maghad al-Lu'lu' (Pearl Diving Place), Mikhlaf Banu Majid, al-Manjalah, Mikhlaf al-Rakb, al-Mandeb, Mikhlaf Rama', Zabid, Mikhlaf 'Akk, al-Hardah, Mikhlaf al-Hakam, 'Athr. So whoever wants the main road takes from 'Athr to al-Arsh, then passes on the main road through the districts. Whoever wants the coast takes from 'Athr to the Anchorage of Dhankan, then the Anchorage of Haly, then al-Sirrin...

...then Aghyar, then al-Harjab, then al-Shu'aybah, then a station, then Jeddah, then Mecca. As for whoever wants the road from al-Yamama to Basra, the stations of the road are: al-Nibak, Sulaymah, a station, Jubb al-Turab (three stations), al-Samman, Tafkhah, al-Qara'a (three stations), Kazimah, a station, Basra. The stations from al-Yamama to Yemen are: al-Kharj, Nab'ah, al-Majazah, al-Ma'din, al-Shafaq, al-Thawr, al-Falaj, al-Safa, Bir al-Abar, Najran, al-Hima, Baranis, Muray', al-Mahjarah. The stations from Oman to Basra are: al-Sabkha (which is between Oman and Bahrain), Qatar, al-Uqayr, Coast of Hajar, Humd, Maslahah, al-Qarantayn, Hassan, Khalijah, al-Mu'arras, 'Asa, al-Maqarr, al-Zabuqah, 'Arafja, al-Huduthah, Abadan. Since we have mentioned the road to Mecca from every direction and followed that with the road to the southern regions like Yemen and what connects to it from al-Yamama, Oman, and Bahrain, and what is close to those directions, let us follow that with the road to what those directions divert to from the eastern regions, namely Ahwaz, Fars, Isfahan, Kerman, Sijistan, and what adjoins them. Let us begin with the City of Peace [Baghdad]: From it to Kalwadha is two farsakhs, to al-Mada'in is five farsakhs, to Sib Bani Kuma is seven farsakhs, to Nu'maniyah is four farsakhs, to Jabal is five farsakhs, to...

...Nahr Sabis is seven farsakhs, to Fam al-Silh is five farsakhs, and to Wasit is seven farsakhs. So that is fifty farsakhs from Wasit to the City of Peace. From Wasit to al-Rusafah is ten farsakhs, to al-Qatr is twelve farsakhs, to Nahr Ma'qil is six farsakhs, and to the city of Basra is four farsakhs. So that is fifty farsakhs from Wasit to Basra. From Basra to al-Ubullah is four farsakhs. From al-Ubullah to Bayan is five farsakhs. From Bayan to Hisn Mahdi on the high ground is six farsakhs, and on the water via the New River (Nahr al-Jadid) is eight farsakhs. From Hisn Mahdi to Suq al-Arba'a is four farsakhs. From Suq al-Arba'a to al-Muhawwal is six farsakhs. From al-Muhawwal to Dulab is eight farsakhs. From Dulab to Suq al-Ahwaz is two farsakhs. So that is thirty-six farsakhs from Basra to Suq al-Ahwaz. From Suq al-Ahwaz to Ha?rul is two farsakhs. From Ha?rul to Azam is four farsakhs. From Azam to S?a?l is four farsakhs. From S?a?l to the Village of al-Hubara is three farsakhs. From the Village of al-Hubara to al-Ain is three farsakhs. From al-Ain to Ram Hormuz is four farsakhs. From Ram Hormuz to Wadi al-Milh is four farsakhs. From Wadi al-Milh to al-Zutt is two farsakhs. From al-Zutt to Khabaran is three farsakhs. From Khabaran to al-Mustarah is two farsakhs. From...

...al-Mustarah to Dihlizān is two farsakhs. From Dihlizān to K?arsan is three farsakhs. From K?arsan to Nisa?l is three farsakhs. From Nisa?l to Arrajan is five farsakhs. From the city of Arrajan to Dasin is seven farsakhs. From Dasin to Bunduq is six farsakhs. From Bunduq to Khan Hammad is six farsakhs. From Khan Hammad to Amran is nine farsakhs. From Amran to al-Nawbandajan is six farsakhs. From al-Nawbandajan to al-Karkan is five farsakhs. From al-Karkan to al-Kharrarah is five farsakhs. From al-Kharrarah to Khullan is five farsakhs. From Khullan to Juwaym is four farsakhs. From Juwaym to Shiraz is five farsakhs. So that is one hundred and two farsakhs from Ahwaz to Shiraz. From Shiraz to Istakhr is twelve farsakhs. From Istakhr to Ziyadabadh is eight farsakhs. From Ziyadabadh to Jubanan is four farsakhs. From Jubanan to the Village of Abdul Rahman is six farsakhs. From the Village of Abdul Rahman to the Village of al-As is seven farsakhs. From the Village of al-As to Sahik is six farsakhs. From Sahik to Sarmaqan is nine farsakhs. From Sarmaqan to Pusht-i Kham is ten farsakhs. From Pusht-i Kham to Bimand is ten farsakhs. From Bimand to al-Sirjan, the capital of Kerman, is four farsakhs. So that is seventy-six farsakhs from Shiraz to al-Sirjan.

From al-Sirjan to Quhistan is six farsakhs. From Quhistan to Ribat Kumakh is eight farsakhs. From Ribat Kumakh to Sahwi is six farsakhs. From Sahwi to Amsir is four farsakhs. From Amsir to Khanab is six farsakhs. From Khanab to Ghubayra is four farsakhs. From Ghubayra to Kawram is eight farsakhs. From Kawram to Kushk is eight farsakhs. From Kushk to Ra'in is ten farsakhs. From Ra'in to Darjin is eight farsakhs. From Darjin to Bam is twelve farsakhs. From Bam to Narmasir and the desert is eight farsakhs. From Narmasir to Sijistan is one hundred farsakhs. So that is one hundred and eighty-eight farsakhs from al-Sirjan, the capital of Kerman, to Sijistan in the desert and the main road. Whoever wants to go from Shiraz to Isfahan: From it to Naysabur is seven farsakhs. From Naysabur to Ma'in is seven farsakhs. From Ma'in to the Aqabah (Obstacle) of Kisa is three farsakhs. From the Aqabah to Khuskān is seven farsakhs. From Khuskān to Qasrayn is five farsakhs. From Qasrayn to Istakhran is seven farsakhs.

From Istakhran to Khawarish is six farsakhs. From Khawarish to Saray Mas and Marwah is four farsakhs. From Mas and Marwah to Karu is seven farsakhs. From Karu to al-Khan is nine farsakhs. From al-Khan to Isfahan is seven farsakhs. So that is seventy farsakhs from Shiraz to Isfahan. Whoever wants to take the road from Ahwaz to Isfahan: From Suq al-Ahwaz to Askar Mukram is eight farsakhs, then to al-Miyanij is seven farsakhs. From al-Miyanij to Idhaj is three farsakhs. From Idhaj to Barbabil is four farsakhs. From Barbabil to Rustagird, which is a fortress in a mountain pass, is seven farsakhs. Then to Shalil is five farsakhs. From Shalil to Khuristan is nine farsakhs. From Khuristan to Urdibihisht-Abadh is four farsakhs. From Urdibihisht-Abadh to Karirkan is seven farsakhs. From Karirkan to Babakan is seven farsakhs. From Babakan to al-Khan is seven farsakhs. From al-Khan to the city of Isfahan is seven farsakhs. So that is eighty-five farsakhs from Ahwaz to Isfahan via the Idhaj road. Since we have mentioned the road to Ahwaz, Fars, Kerman, Sijistan, and what adjoins that of the roads to Isfahan and Fars, let us return to mention the roads. Let us begin by mentioning the roads to the rest of the districts of the East and its regions. Let us begin that from the City of Peace [Baghdad] as well: From it to al-Nahrawan is four farsakhs. From al-Nahrawan to Deir Bazma is four farsakhs. From Deir Bazma to al-Daskarah is eight farsakhs.

From al-Daskarah to Jalula is seven farsakhs. From Jalula to Khanaqin is seven farsakhs. From Khanaqin to Qasr Shirin is six farsakhs. From Qasr Shirin to Hulwan is five farsakhs. So that is forty-one farsakhs from the City of Peace to Hulwan. From Hulwan to Madaruwastan is four farsakhs. From Madaruwastan to Marj al-Qal'ah is six farsakhs. From Marj al-Qal'ah to Qasr Yazid is four farsakhs. From Qasr Yazid to al-Zubaydiyah is six farsakhs. From al-Zubaydiyah to Khushkarish is three farsakhs. From Khushkarish to Qasr Amr is four farsakhs. From Qasr Amr to Qirmisin is three farsakhs. So that is thirty farsakhs from Qirmisin to Hulwan. From Qirmisin to Qantarat Maryam (Bridge of Maryam) is five farsakhs. From Qantarat Maryam to Mas?h is four farsakhs. From Mas?h to Qasr al-Lusus is six farsakhs. From Qasr al-Lusus to Asadabadh is seven farsakhs. From Asadabadh to al-Za'franiyah is six farsakhs. From al-Za'franiyah to the city of Hamadhan is three farsakhs. So that is thirty-one farsakhs from Qirmisin to the city of Hamadhan. Whoever wants the road from Qirmisin to Nihawand takes from Qirmisin to al-Dukkan seven farsakhs. From al-Dukkan to Qasr al-Lusus is nine farsakhs. From Qasr al-Lusus to Kahras is five farsakhs. From Kahras...

...to Nihawand is four farsakhs. So that is twenty-five farsakhs from Qirmisin to Nihawand. Whoever wants to go from Nihawand to Hamadhan: From Nihawand to Rakah is six farsakhs. From Rakah to al-Dayman is five farsakhs. From al-Dayman to Hamadhan is seven farsakhs. So that is eighteen farsakhs from Nihawand to Hamadhan. Whoever wants to go from Nihawand to al-Karaj, which is the capital of al-Aygharayn: From Nihawand to Rakah is six farsakhs. From Rakah to Jurab is eight farsakhs. From Jurab to al-Karaj is five farsakhs. So that is nineteen farsakhs from Nihawand to al-Karaj. Whoever needs to know the road from Hamadhan to al-Aygharayn and its capital al-Karaj: From Hamadhan to Tasfandayn is five farsakhs. From Tasfandayn to Jurab is seven farsakhs. From Jurab to al-Karaj is five farsakhs. So that is seventeen farsakhs from Hamadhan to al-Karaj. From Hamadhan to al-Karaj via the Sawah district: From Hamadhan to Jur is five farsakhs. From Jur to Khandab is seven farsakhs. From Khandab to al-Sa?an is seven farsakhs. From al-Sa?an to al-Karaj is nine farsakhs. So on this road, it is twenty-eight farsakhs. Whoever wants Isfahan from al-Karaj: From al-Karaj to Khurramabadh is seven farsakhs. From Khurramabadh to Abqisah is seven...

...farsakhs. From Abqisah to Jurbadhqan is six farsakhs. From Jurbadhqan to Qanuran is eight farsakhs. From Qanuran to Marj Wazhar is seven farsakhs. From Marj Wazhar to al-Marabin is four farsakhs. From al-Marabin to Azmiran is twelve farsakhs. From Azmiran to Isfahan is three farsakhs. So that is fifty-four farsakhs from al-Karaj to Isfahan. Then we return to Hamadhan and the road from it to the rest of the regions of the East. From Hamadhan to Daranwa is five farsakhs. From Daranwa to Buzanjird is five farsakhs. From Buzanjird to Zarah is four farsakhs. From Zarah to Tazarah is four farsakhs. From Tazarah to al-Asawirah is four farsakhs. From al-Asawirah to Rudhah and Bustah is three farsakhs. From Rudhah and Bustah to Dawudabadh is four farsakhs. From Dawudabadh to Susanqin is three farsakhs. From Susanqin to Darudh is four farsakhs. From Darudh to Sawah is five farsakhs. From Sawah to Mishkuyah is eight farsakhs. From Mishkuyah to Qastanah is eight farsakhs. From Qastanah to al-Rayy is seven farsakhs. So that is sixty-four farsakhs from Hamadhan to al-Rayy. From al-Rayy to Mufaddalabadh is four farsakhs. From Mufaddalabadh to Afridin is six farsakhs. From Afridin to Kasib is eight farsakhs. From Kasib...

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to Al-Khuwar is six farsakhs. From Al-Khuwar to Qasr al-Milh (Salt Castle) is seven farsakhs. From Qasr al-Milh to Ra's al-Kalb is seven farsakhs. From Ra's al-Kalb to Sarkh is four farsakhs. From Sarkh to Semnan is four farsakhs. From Semnan to Akharin is nine farsakhs. From Akharin to the village of Dayah is four farsakhs. From the village of Dayah to Qumis is four farsakhs. From Qumis to Al-Haddadah is seven farsakhs. From Al-Haddadah to Kuzistan is four farsakhs. From Kuzistan to Badhash is three farsakhs. From Badhash to Maymid is twelve farsakhs. From Maymid to Haftdar is seven farsakhs. From Haftdar to Asadabad is seven farsakhs. From Asadabad to Bahmanabad is six farsakhs. From Bahmanabad to Al-Nawq is six farsakhs. From Al-Nawq to Khosrowjerd is six farsakhs. From Khosrowjerd to Husaynabad is four farsakhs. From Husaynabad to Sankardar is five farsakhs. From Sankardar to Bishkand is five farsakhs. From Bishkand to Nishapur is five farsakhs. So, from Rayy to Nishapur is one hundred and forty farsakhs. From Nishapur to Baghis is four farsakhs. From Baghis to Al-Hamra is six farsakhs. From Al-Hamra to Al-Muthaqqab of Tus is five farsakhs. From

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Al-Muthaqqab to Al-Nawqan is five farsakhs. From Al-Nawqan to the Mazdavaran Pass is six farsakhs. From the Mazdavaran Pass to Awkinah is eight farsakhs. From Awkinah to the city of Sarakhs is six farsakhs. From Sarakhs to Qasr al-Najjar is three farsakhs. From Qasr al-Najjar to Ashtarmaghak is five farsakhs. From Ashtarmaghak to Talistanah is six farsakhs. From Talistanah to Al-Dandanqan is six farsakhs. From Al-Dandanqan to Yanujard is five farsakhs. From Yanujard to the city of Merv is five farsakhs. So, from Nishapur to Merv is seventy farsakhs. From the city of Merv, there are two roads: one to the region of Shash and the lands of the Turks, and the other to the region of Tokharistan. From the city of Merv to Kushmahan, which is a large village on the road to the desert connected to the Ghuz, is five farsakhs. From Kushmahan to Al-Diwan, which has a post station, is six farsakhs. From Al-Diwan to Al-Tahmalaj, a place with a post station, is two farsakhs. From Al-Tahmalaj to Al-Munsaf, a place with a post station, is four farsakhs. From Al-Munsaf to Al-Ahsa, a place with a post station, is eight farsakhs. From Al-Ahsa to Nahr Uthman, a place with a post station, is three farsakhs. From Nahr Uthman to Al-Uqayr, a place with a post station, is three farsakhs. From Al-Uqayr to the city of Amul is five farsakhs. So, from Merv to Amul is thirty-six farsakhs. From the city of Amul to the bank of the river of Balkh is one farsakh. From the place where

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: one crosses to a village called Ali's Village is one farsakh. From Ali's Village in the desert to the Fortress of Umm Ja'far is six farsakhs. From the Fortress of Umm Ja'far, until leaving the desert to Baykand, is six farsakhs. From Baykand to the gate of the wall of Bukhara is two farsakhs. From the Gate to a village called Mastin is one and a half farsakhs. From Mastin to Bukhara is five farsakhs. So, from Amul to the city of Bukhara is twenty-two and a half farsakhs. From the city of Bukhara to Shargh is four farsakhs. From Shargh to Al-Tawawis is three farsakhs. From Al-Tawawis to Kuk is three farsakhs; this is a barren village from which the King of the Turks raided. To the south of this place are mountains leading to the lands of China. From Kuk to Karminiya is four farsakhs. From Karminiya to Al-Dabbusiya is five farsakhs. From Al-Dabbusiya to Rabnjan is five farsakhs. From Rabnjan to Zarman is six farsakhs. From Zarman to Qasr Alqama is five farsakhs. From Qasr Alqama to the city of Samarkand is two farsakhs. So, from the city of Bukhara to Samarkand is thirty-seven farsakhs. From Samarkand to Barkath is four farsakhs. From Barkath to Khushufaghan in the desert of Qatwan is four farsakhs. From Khushufaghan to Furnamadh, which is mountainous, is five farsakhs. From Furnamadh to Zamin in the desert is four farsakhs. This Zamin is the junction of two roads: a road to Shash and a road to Fergana.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: As for the road to Shash: From Zamin to Khawas in the desert is six farsakhs. From Khawas to the River of Shash is five farsakhs. When the river is crossed, from the station on the bank to Banakat is four farsakhs. From Banakat to Jinanjkath on the River Turk is four farsakhs. If River Turk is crossed, Strukath is on the left. From Strukath to Banunkath is three farsakhs. From Banunkath to the city of Shash is two farsakhs. From the city of Shash to a camp inside the wall is two farsakhs. From there to Gharkard is five farsakhs. From Gharkard in the desert to Isfijab is four farsakhs. From Isfijab to Sharab in a desert containing two great rivers, one called Mawa and the other Yuran, is four farsakhs. From Sharab to Badukhkat in 'Rakawat' (depressions or stations) is four farsakhs. From Badukhkat to Tamtaj in 'Rakawat'—and this Tamtaj is in a desert with a great river and reed beds—is five farsakhs. From Tamtaj to Barjaj in 'Rakawat' is four farsakhs. This Barjaj is a great hill surrounded by a thousand water springs that gather into a single river

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: flowing to the east, named Barku-Ab, meaning 'Inverted Water,' because its flow is from bottom to top (west to east). From Barjaj to a station is six farsakhs on Barku-Ab. This river has thickets, tamarisks, and forests on both its banks; its game is black francolin. From this station, you cross this river and descend to the right. From the crossing to Shawghar, a mountain of whetstones, is three farsakhs. From Shawghar to Jawikath in a wilderness with no habitation is two farsakhs. From Jawikath to the city of Taraz, amidst pasture and habitation, is two farsakhs. From the city of Taraz to Lower Nushajan is three farsakhs. From Lower Nushajan to Kasri Bas in mountains—on its right is two farsakhs, and on its left is Qum, which is a warm region and the beginning of the Kharlukhiya (Kharlukhs). Qum is between Taraz and Kulan to the north. Behind Qum is a desert of sand and pebbles containing vipers, extending to the border of Kimak, two farsakhs. From Kasri Bas to Kul Shub, which is similar to Kasri Bas, and to its right is a mountain with many fruits, fresh dates, and mountain vegetables, is four farsakhs. From Kul Shub to Kulan, of similar description, is four farsakhs. So, from the city of Taraz to Kulan is fourteen farsakhs in a desert called Kulan, described as above. From Kulan to the village of Barki,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: which is lush, is four farsakhs. From Barki to Asbarah in a desert similar to the desert of Kulan is four farsakhs. From Asbarah to Nuzkat, a great village, is eight farsakhs. From Nuzkat to Kharanjuwan, which is a great village, is four farsakhs. From Kharanjuwan to Jul, which is a great village, is four farsakhs. From Jul to Saragh, which is a great village, is seven farsakhs. From Saragh to the village of the Turkish Khagan is four farsakhs. From the village of the Turkish Khagan to K?rm?raw is two farsakhs. From K?rm?raw to the city of Nawakat is two farsakhs. From the city of Nawakat to Panjikath, which is a great village, and beside it is a village, is two farsakhs. This Nawakat is a large city, and from it is a road to Nushajan called Barkab, one farsakh. From Panjikath to Suyab is two farsakhs. Suyab consists of two villages: one called Kabal and the other Saghur Kabal. From Saghur Kabal to Nushajan—the Upper one, which is the border of China—is fifteen days traveling with caravans amidst pasture and waters. For the Turkish post (Barid), it is a journey of three days. Then we return to Samarkand. We have mentioned that at three stages from it is the junction of two roads: one to Shash and the other to Fergana. We have completed the description of

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the road of Shash to the borders of China. Let us take the road of Fergana. The beginning of this road is Zamin in the desert of Samarkand to Fergana. From Zamin to Sabat, a great village from which there are two roads—one to Fergana—is two farsakhs. From Sabat to Karkat, a great village, is three farsakhs. From Karkat to Ghaluk Andaz, which is a village among great villages, is three farsakhs. From Ghaluk Andaz to Khujandah on the River of Shash is four farsakhs. From this city is the junction of two roads: one to Fergana and the other to Shash to the Silver Mine. The road of Fergana: From Khujandah to a village called Samghar, which is great, in a wilderness, is five farsakhs. From Samghar to Khajistan, which is the site of a garrison and contains a fortress; there is a large salt mine from which the salt of Shash, Khujandah, and others comes; and on one side of it is a mountain connecting to the mountain of the Silver Mine, four farsakhs. From Khajistan to a village called Tarmuqan is six farsakhs. From Tarmuqan to Bab, which is a great city among the cities of Fergana, is three farsakhs. From Bab to the city of Fergana, which is called Akhsikath, is four farsakhs. So, from Samarkand to Fergana is thirty-five farsakhs. Then we return to the junction of the two roads from Sabat. From Sabat to the city of Ushrusana is seven farsakhs. These farsakhs: two farsakhs are in the plain, then

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the valley, and the villages are above the back of the mountain to the right and left. The travel is facing the water flowing in the two roads, which comes from the city. Then we return to the junction of the two roads from Khujandah to take the road of the Silver Mine in Shash. From this city of Khujandah into the river, then travel to a ruin near which is a spring called the Place of the Observation Post. From the ruin to Qasr Muhinan at the mouth of the Valley of the Silver Mine is two farsakhs. Then let us return to the city of Shash to clarify the travel from it on the road to Fergana. From the city of Shash to the Silver Mine is seven farsakhs. From the Silver Mine to Khajistan is eight farsakhs. From Khajistan to Tarmuqan on the River of Shash near the villages. From Tarmuqan to Bab is three farsakhs. Bab is a great city among the cities of Fergana, abundant in goods, on the River of Shash. People used not to stay in Tarmuqan due to the intense fear of the Turks; they used to traverse these farsakhs in a day and a night, and others would stay there. From Bab to Akhsikath, the city of Fergana, is four farsakhs. From Fergana to Upper Nushajan: From the city of Fergana to Quba, which is a city, is ten farsakhs. From Quba to Osh, which is a great village, is seven farsakhs. From Osh to Uzgend, the city of Khurtakin the Dehghan, is seven farsakhs. From Uzgend to the Pass (Aqaba); the road to the Pass is between villages close to each other connected to Khurtakin the Dehghan. It is high and difficult; if snow falls, it cannot be traversed. It is a day's journey. From the Pass to Atbash is in mountains with ascents and descents. This Atbash is a city on a high pass, and it is between Tibet and Fergana.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Nushajan is a day's journey. From Atbash to Upper Nushajan: part of the road is in small mountains and part in pasture and springs with no villages. Whoever travels the road carries with him what he needs. Travelers use it, but rarely do they drag on for six stages. From Upper Nushajan to the place of the Toghuzghuz Khagan, King of the Toghuzghuz, is a journey of six days. We return to the road of Kimak from Taraz. One takes from Taraz to two villages in a place called Kawakit, inhabited and populous. Between this place to the place of the King of Kimak is a journey of eighty days for a speeding horseman, carrying with him only his food because his travel is in vast deserts with much pasture and springs; most of the pasture is clover (Qatt). Then we return to Merv to clarify the road from it to Tokharistan and its regions. From the city of Merv to a village called Faz is seven farsakhs. From Faz to Mahdi-abad on the desert road is six farsakhs. From Mahdi-abad to Yahya-abad, a station in the middle of the valley; in this station are caravanserais and a post station, seven farsakhs. From Yahya-abad to Al-Quraynayn; this village is in the desert on the bank of the valley on a large hill. Its people are Magians (Majus), and their earning is from renting out their donkeys, traveling upon them to the horizons. They are called Yarkun. Five farsakhs. From Al-Quraynayn to Asadabad is seven farsakhs. From Asadabad to Hawzan is five farsakhs. From Hawzan to Qasr al-Ahnaf, a village on the valley attributed to Al-Ahnaf bin Qais,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is four farsakhs. From Qasr al-Ahnaf to the city of Merv al-A'la (Upper Merv) is five farsakhs. Then you pass this city until you end up at a place called Qasr Amr in the mountain at the mouth of the gorge, about a farsakh. From the city of Merv al-Rudh to Araskin is five farsakhs. From Araskin to Al-Asrab (The Tunnels), which is small and its houses are tunnels in the mountain on the road in the gorge, is seven farsakhs. From Al-Asrab to Kunjabadh, which is a village of the districts of Taligan, is six farsakhs. From Kunjabadh to Taligan is six farsakhs. From Taligan to Kashan, a great village between two mountains, is five farsakhs. From Kashan to Arghin, an inhabited village in the valley of Merv, is a farsakh. Then into a dirt pass that is not difficult, and after that in the mountain; part of the road is stony. In the pass is a spring with stones. All of it is not difficult. Four farsakhs. From Arghin to Qasr Khut, an inhabited village in a populous plain, and it is the first district of Faryab, is five farsakhs. From Qasr Khut to the city of Faryab is about two farsakhs. Then to the desert called Mafazat al-Qa' (Desert of the Lowland), which is five farsakhs. From the city of Faryab to Al-Qa' in the desert is more than that, with ascents and descents. It is easy. The station has caravanserais and wells. It belongs to the authority of the district of Juzjan and is in a plain, nine farsakhs. From Al-Qa' to Shaburqan in the wilderness ... and it is populous with a pulpit (minbar), belonging to Juzjan, nine farsakhs. From Shaburqan to Al-Sidrah, which belongs to the district of Balkh, is six farsakhs. This station used to be the 'Daw' (desert/wilderness) and had nothing but a post station and caravanserais. When the year of the earthquake occurred in Khorasan in the regions of Merv and Tokharistan, which was the year

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: two hundred and three, the spring of Al-Sidrah burst forth from the earthquake and became a large spring. Its water flowed into the wilderness, which is a desert connected to Merv and Amul, dominated by sands and reed beds. The place of the tree became a village with many crops and trees. From Al-Sidrah to Al-Dastajirdah, a village with much water and people, is five farsakhs. From Al-Dastajirdah to Al-Ud, which is a great village, is four farsakhs. From Al-Ud to the city of Balkh, in inhabited land, is three farsakhs. From the city of Balkh to Siyajird, a great village, is five farsakhs. From Siyajird to the River of Balkh, Jayhun, in a desert is seven farsakhs. This river is at the base of the city of Termez, striking the wall, and it is upon a rock. From the city of Termez to Sarmanjan is six farsakhs. From Sarmanjan to Darzanki, an inhabited populous village, is six farsakhs. From Darzanki to a village called Barinji is seven farsakhs. From Barinji to Chaghaniyan, which is great and populous, is five farsakhs. From the city of Chaghaniyan on the road of Al-Rasht to Bundha, a great village, is three farsakhs. From Bundha to Hamwaran, a village, the travel to it is seven farsakhs. From Hamwaran to Aban Kaswan, an inhabited village, is eight farsakhs. From Aban Kaswan to Shuman is five farsakhs. From Shuman to Washjird, and the travel to it is in inhabited land, is four farsakhs.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From Washjird to Al-Rasht, which is between two mountains. Rasht is the furthest land of Khorasan from those regions, and it is adjacent to Fergana. From there is the entrance of the Turks for raiding, a journey of four days. Then let us return to the city of Balkh and the road from it to Upper Tokharistan. From the city of Balkh to Walari is five farsakhs. From Walari to Sawahi is three farsakhs. From Sawahi to the city of Khulm in a wilderness is three farsakhs. From the city of Khulm to Bahar, a station in the desert with no water except from a well descended into by a staircase, is seven farsakhs. From Bahar to Arka?awl, a station in a desert, is five farsakhs. From Arka?awl to Qarid Amir, which is between rocks from the river of Balkh at eighteen farsakhs, is seven farsakhs. Since we have completed mentioning the roads and routes to Mecca and what adjoins it from Yemen and elsewhere, and followed that with what follows it of roads to the eastern regions, let us follow that by mentioning the roads to the northern regions and what adjoins them. The first is the road turning to the district of Azerbaijan. From Sinn Sumayra to Dinawar is five farsakhs. From Dinawar to Al-Khurjan is nine farsakhs. From Al-Khurjan to Tal Wan is six farsakhs. From Tal Wan to Sisar is seven farsakhs. From Sisar are two roads: a road to Baylaqan, ten farsakhs; and from Baylaqan to Barza, eight farsakhs. As for the winter road: from Sisar to Andarab is four farsakhs. From Andarab to Baylaqan is five farsakhs. From Baylaqan to Barza is six farsakhs. From Barza to Sabarkhast is eight farsakhs. From Sabarkhast

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: to Maragha is seven farsakhs. From Maragha to Deh al-Kharraqan is eleven farsakhs. From Al-Kharraqan to Tabriz is nine farsakhs. From Tabriz to the city of Marand is ten farsakhs. From Maragha to Kulasrah is ten farsakhs. From Kulasrah to Sarah is ten farsakhs. From Sarah to Al-Nir is five farsakhs. From Al-Nir to Ardabil is five farsakhs. From Ardabil to Khan Babak is eight farsakhs. From Khan Babak to Barzand is six farsakhs. From Barzand to Bahlab is twelve farsakhs. From Ardabil to Mughan is four farsakhs. If one wants to go to Nariz from Barza: from there to Tiflis is two farsakhs. From Tiflis to Jabirwan is six farsakhs. From Jabirwan to Nariz is four farsakhs. From Nariz to Urmia is fourteen farsakhs. From Urmia to Salmas is six farsakhs. From Marand to Al-Jar is four farsakhs. From Al-Jar to Khoy is six farsakhs. Whoever wants Armenia from this road: from Marand to Al-Sari on the valley is ten farsakhs. From the Valley to Nashawa is ten farsakhs. From Nashawa to Dabil is twenty farsakhs. Whoever wants from Warthan to Bardha'a: from Warthan to Qumam is three farsakhs. Then to Baylaqan is seven farsakhs. Then to Bardha'a is three farsakhs. Then let us begin clarifying the road from the City of Peace (Baghdad) to the regions of

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the West (Al-Maghrib) and its regions. We begin with what concluded from the northern direction to connect between that and what we started with from the East to the northern regions. Let the first of that be towards Mosul. From the City of Peace to Al-Baradan is four farsakhs. From Al-Baradan to Ukbara is five farsakhs. From Ukbara to Bahmasa is three farsakhs. From Bahmasa to Al-Qadisiyah is seven farsakhs. From Al-Qadisiyah to Al-Karkh is five farsakhs. From Al-Karkh to Jabalta is seven farsakhs. From Jabalta to Al-Sudaqaniya is five farsakhs. From Al-Sudaqaniya to Barma is five farsakhs. From Barma to the city of Al-Sinn is five farsakhs. From Al-Sinn to Al-Haditha is a wilderness in the middle of which flows the Lesser Zab, twelve farsakhs. From Al-Haditha to Tahman is seven farsakhs. From Tahman to Mosul is seven farsakhs. From Mosul to Balad, which is a city, is seven farsakhs. From Balad to Ba'aynatha is seven farsakhs. From Ba'aynatha to Barqa'id is six farsakhs. From Barqa'id to Adhrama is six farsakhs. From Adhrama to Tal Farasha is three farsakhs. From Tal Farasha to Nusaybin is four farsakhs. From Nusaybin is the junction of two roads: one to the

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: right to the northern regions close to what we mentioned of roads from the East to them, and the other to the rest of the western regions. Let us begin with the road that takes the right from Nusaybin to Dara, five farsakhs. From Dara to Kafartutha is seven farsakhs. From Kafartutha to Qasr Bani Nazi' is seven farsakhs. From Qasr Bani Nazi' to Amid is seven farsakhs. From Amid to Mayyafariqin on the right is five farsakhs. From Mayyafariqin to Arzan, which is also a city bordering Armenia, is seven farsakhs. The road from Amid to Raqqa on the left: from it to Shimshat near the Roman frontiers is seven farsakhs. From Shimshat to Tal Jufar is five farsakhs. From Tal Jufar to Jarnan, a populous village with many markets, is six farsakhs. From Jarnan to Bamaqda, which has a market and few people, is five farsakhs. From Bamaqda to Jallab, a lush village on a river, is seven farsakhs. From Jallab to Al-Ruha (Edessa), a Roman city at the foot of a mountain, is four farsakhs. From Al-Ruha to Harran, which is a city, is four farsakhs. From Harran to Tal Mahra is four farsakhs. From Tal Mahra to Bajarwan is seven farsakhs. From Bajarwan to Raqqa is three farsakhs. As for the road from Nusaybin to Raqqa: from it to Dara, a city at the foot of a mountain, is five farsakhs. From Dara to Kafartutha is seven farsakhs. From Kafartutha to Al-Arrada, a station, is three farsakhs. From Al-Arrada to Ras Ayn, a city with springs, is four farsakhs. From Ras Ayn to Al-Jarud is five farsakhs. From Al-Jarud to Hisn Maslama, a village with a cistern, is six farsakhs. From the Fortress to Bajarwan is seven farsakhs. From Bajarwan to Raqqa is three farsakhs.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: As for the road from Balad on the left to Qarqisiya, Sinjar, and the Euphrates road: From Balad to Tal A'far, a large village, is five farsakhs. From Tal A'far to Sinjar, a Roman city, is five farsakhs. From Sinjar to Ayn al-Jibal is five farsakhs. From Ayn al-Jibal to Sukayr al-Abbas bin Muhammad, a city on the Khabur, is nine farsakhs. From Al-Sukayr to Al-Fadayn is five farsakhs. From Al-Fadayn to Maksin, a city on the Khabur, is six farsakhs. From Maksin to Qarqisiya, a city on the Euphrates and Khabur, is seven farsakhs. As for the road from Raqqa to the Thughur (Frontiers): From Raqqa to Ayn al-Rumiya is six farsakhs. From Ayn al-Rumiya to Tal Abda is seven farsakhs. From Tal Abda to Saruj is seven farsakhs. From Saruj to Al-Muzniya is six farsakhs. From Al-Muzniya to Sumaysat, a city on the Euphrates on the Syrian side, is six farsakhs. From Sumaysat to Hisn Mansur, a frontier fort with a stone wall, is six farsakhs. From Hisn Mansur to Malatya, through severe passes—and Malatya is also a frontier—is ten farsakhs. From Malatya to a city called Kamakh, which was a frontier and the enemy seized it, is four farsakhs. To the left to Hisn Zibatra, and the enemy seized it, is four farsakhs. From Zibatra to Al-Hadath, which is a frontier in the enemy's throat, is four farsakhs. From Al-Hadath to Mar'ash, a frontier with nothing behind it but enemy settlements, is five farsakhs. Let us return to the City of Peace to clarify the road from it to the western regions if taking the Euphrates road. From the City of Peace to Al-Saylahin is four farsakhs. From Al-Saylahin to Al-Anbar is eight farsakhs. From Al-Anbar is a road

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: that emerges from Al-Bajas in the desert and meets at Al-Rabb with the straight road from Al-Anbar. From Al-Anbar to Al-Rabb is seven farsakhs. From Al-Rabb to Hit is twelve farsakhs. From Hit to Al-Nawusa is seven farsakhs. From Al-Nawusa to Alusa is seven farsakhs. From Alusa to Al-Fahima is six farsakhs. From Al-Fahima to Al-Nahiya is twelve farsakhs in the desert; and on the Euphrates, which is the postal road, is six farsakhs. From Al-Nahiya to Al-Daziqi is six farsakhs. From Al-Daziqi to Al-Furda is six farsakhs. From Al-Furda the road splits into one in the desert and one on the Euphrates. As for the Euphrates: From Al-Furda to Wadi al-Siba is five farsakhs. From Wadi al-Siba to the Gulf of Ibn Jami' is five farsakhs. From the Gulf of Ibn Jami' to Al-Fash is six farsakhs. From Al-Fash to Qarqisiya and to the mouth of Nahr Sa'id is eight farsakhs. From the mouth of Nahr Sa'id to Al-Jardan is fourteen farsakhs. From Al-Jardan to Al-Mubarak is eleven farsakhs. From Al-Mubarak to Raqqa is eight farsakhs. So, from the City of Peace to Raqqa on the Euphrates is one hundred and twenty-six farsakhs. As for the desert road that splits at Al-Furda: From Al-Furda to Al-Qumarty is three farsakhs. From Al-Qumarty to Al-Awamil is nine farsakhs and a mile. From Al-Awamil to Al-Qasaba is eight farsakhs. From Al-Qasaba to Al-Arir is nine farsakhs. From Al-Arir to Al-Rusafa is eight farsakhs. From Al-Rusafa to Raqqa

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is eight. So that is from the City of Peace to Raqqa on the desert road without the Euphrates, one hundred and twenty-seven farsakhs and a mile. The Damascus Road from Al-Rusafa: From Raqqa to Al-Rusafa is eight farsakhs. From Al-Rusafa there are two roads: one to Damascus in the desert and another via Homs in inhabited land. As for the inhabited road: From Al-Rusafa to Al-Zara'a is forty miles. From Al-Zara'a to Qastal is thirty-six miles. From Qastal to Salamiyah is thirty miles. From Salamiyah to Homs is twenty-four miles. From Homs to Shamsin al-Sha'ar is eighteen miles. From Shamsin to Qara is twenty-two miles. From Qara to Al-Nabk is twelve miles. From Al-Nabk to Al-Qutayfah is twenty miles. From Al-Qutayfah to Damascus is twenty-four miles. As for the desert road from Al-Rusafa to Damascus: From Al-Rusafa to Al-Khirbah, named Batlamiya, is thirty-five miles. From Batlamiya to Al-Udhayb is twenty-four miles. From Al-Udhayb to Nahya is twenty miles. From Nahya to Al-Qaryatayn is twenty miles. From Al-Qaryatayn to Jarud is thirty-six miles. From Jarud to Damascus is thirty miles. From Salamiyah to Damascus on a road known as the Middle Road: From Salamiyah to Far'aya is eighteen miles. From Far'aya to Ma' Sharik is twenty miles. From Ma' Sharik to Sadad is eighteen miles. From Sadad to Al-Nabk is thirty-five miles.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From Homs also to Damascus on the road of Al-Biqa: From Homs to Jusiyah is thirteen miles. From Jusiyah to I'ath is twenty miles. From I'ath to Baalbek is three miles. From Baalbek, to the left on a mountain called Rami, is fifty miles. Whoever takes from Baalbek to Tiberias on the road of Al-Darraj: From Baalbek to Ayn al-Jarr is twenty miles. From Ayn al-Jarr to Al-Qar'un, a station in the belly of the valley, is fifteen. From Qar'un to a village called Al-Uyun, going to Kafarlayla, is twenty miles. From Kafarlayla to Tiberias is fifteen miles. In this road is the Well of Joseph, peace be upon him. If taking the road to the mountains of Jordan from Damascus, the straight road from Damascus to Al-Kiswah is twelve miles. From Al-Kiswah to Jasim is twenty-four miles. From Jasim to Afiq is twenty-four miles. From Afiq to Tiberias is six miles. Then from Tiberias, the road splits to Ramla into two branches. From Tiberias to Al-Lajjun on the straight road is twenty miles. The other road to Baysan is sixteen miles, then to Al-Lajjun eighteen miles. Then from Al-Lajjun to Qalansuwa on Wadi 'Ara, which has beasts, is twenty miles. From Qalansuwa to Ramla is twenty-four miles. From Ramla to Egypt: From Ramla to Azdud in villages and habitation is twelve miles. From Azdud in villages and habitation to Gaza is twenty miles. From Gaza to Rafah in orchards is ten miles, and six in much sand. From Rafah to Al-Arish in sand is twenty-four miles. From Al-Arish the road splits into the road of Al-Jifar, which is sand, and the coastal road on the sea. As for the road of Al-Jifar: From Al-Arish to Al-Warrada is eighteen miles. From Al-Warrada to Al-Baqqara

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is twenty miles. From Al-Baqqara to Al-Farama is twenty-four miles. As for the coastal road: From Al-Arish to Al-Makhlisa is twenty-one miles. From Al-Makhlisa to Al-Qasr (The Fortress), the fortress of the Christians, which has fresh water and palms, is twenty-four miles. From Al-Qasr to Al-Farama is twenty-four miles. From Al-Farama the road varies to Fustat, the capital of Egypt; there is a winter road and a summer road. The summer road: From Al-Farama to Jirjir is thirty miles. From Jirjir to Faqus Al-Ghadira is twenty-four miles. From Al-Ghadira to Masjid Quda'a is eighteen miles. From Masjid Quda'a to Bilbeis is twenty-one miles. From Bilbeis to Misr (Fustat) is twenty-four miles. The winter road: From Al-Farama to Al-Marsad. From Al-Marsad to Al-Ghadira is thirty-four miles after the meeting of two roads there. As for the road from Fustat to Barqa, Ifriqiya, and the entire West (Maghrib): From Fustat to Dhat al-Salasil is twenty-four miles. From Dhat al-Salasil to Tarnut is thirty miles. Then the road turns to Alexandria from this Tarnut. From Tarnut to Kom Sharik is twenty-two miles. From Kom Sharik to Al-Rafiqa, traveling with the Nile. From Al-Rafiqa turns the Canal of Alexandria, twenty-four miles. From Al-Rafiqa to Qartasa is thirty miles. From Qartasa to Karyun is twenty-four miles. From Karyun to Alexandria is twenty-four miles. From Alexandria to Abu Mina is twenty miles. From Abu Mina to Dhat al-Hamam is eighteen miles. Then we repeat the journey from Tarnut, which was the destination from Dhat al-Salasil. From Tarnut to

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Al-Minbar is thirty miles. From Al-Minbar to Masaris is twenty-four miles. From Masaris to Armasa is twelve miles. From Armasa to Dhat al-Hamam is twenty miles; there the two roads meet—the road of Alexandria and the road of Barqa—and the two roads become one road. You carry water from Dhat al-Hamam in the desert, traveling alongside the Roman Sea (Mediterranean) until you descend at Al-Haniyah—Haniyat al-Rum—which is a ruin on the road. From Dhat al-Hamam to Haniyat al-Rum is thirty-four miles. From Al-Haniyah to Qasr al-Ajuz, a village called Al-Tahunah, is thirty miles. From Al-Tahunah to Kana'is al-Jawn in inhabited land is twenty-four miles. From Kana'is al-Jawn to Jubb al-Awsaj is thirty miles. From Jubb al-Awsaj to Sikkat al-Hamam is thirty miles. From Sikkat al-Hamam to Qasr al-Shammas is twenty-five miles. From Qasr al-Shammas to Khirbat al-Qawm is fifteen miles. From Khirbat al-Qawm to Khara'ib Abi Halimah is thirty-five miles. From Khara'ib Abi Halimah to Al-Aqaba is twenty miles. From there to a village called Ma'd is thirty-five miles. From Ma'd to Rabus is thirty miles. From Rabus to Farmah, a city where workers stay, is six miles. From Farmah to a palace called Al-Shahidayn to Wadi al-Sudur, which has thick trees, is twenty miles. From Wadi al-Sudur to a village called Ba' is twenty-four miles. From Ba' to Al-Nadamah is twenty-four miles. From Al-Nadamah to Barqa is six miles.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: As for the desert road: From Qasr al-Rum to Marj al-Shaykh is twenty miles. From Marj al-Shaykh to Hayy Abdallah is thirty miles. From Hayy Abdallah to Jiyad al-Saghir is thirty miles. From Jiyad al-Saghir to Jibab al-Mayda'an is thirty-five miles. From Jibab al-Mayda'an to Wadi Makhil is thirty-five miles. From Wadi Makhil to Jubb Hulayman is thirty-five miles. From Jubb Hulayman to Wadi al-Maghar is thirty-five miles. From Wadi al-Maghar to Takinast, which is a village of Christians, is twenty-five miles. From Takinast to Al-Nadamah is twenty-five miles. From Al-Nadamah to Barqa, which is a city in a red desert like an unripe date, is fifteen miles, and the mountains are six miles from it. So that is from Alexandria to Barqa... And from Barqa to Malitiyah is fifteen miles. From Malitiyah to Qasr al-Asal is twenty-nine miles. From Qasr al-Asal to Awbran is twelve miles. From Awbran to Saluq is thirty miles. From Saluq the road splits into two branches: a branch on the Sikkah (Post Road) and a branch on the sea coast road. As for the coastal road: From Saluq to Barsamat is twenty-four miles. From Barsamat to Balbad is twenty miles. From Balbad to Ajdabiya is twenty-four miles. As for the Sikkah road: From Saluq to Al-Sikkah is thirty miles. From Al-Sikkah to Al-Zaytuna is twenty miles. From Al-Zaytuna to Ajdabiya is twenty-four

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: miles. Thus, the Sikkah road and the coastal road meet at Ajdabiya. Then we return to mention Malitiyah, from which Barqa is fifteen miles away. From there, on the land road from Malitiyah to Al-Anbar is twenty-four miles. From Al-Anbar to Wadi al-A'rab is thirty miles. Returning from the station of Shaqiq al-Fahmi to Saluq: From the station of Shaqiq al-Fahmi to Saluq is thirty-five miles. The two roads meet at Saluq, becoming one road to Ajdabiya. Let us return to mention Makhil, at which we said is the road to Ifriqiya on the left. From Makhil to Jubb Jarawah to Tamlis is twenty miles. From Tamlis to Wadi Masus is thirty-five miles. From Wadi Masus to... And from Har?ra?lwa to Ajdabiya is twenty-four miles. From Ajdabiya the road splits, becoming two roads: one to

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Ifriqiya and the other to Tripoli. Then from Ajdabiya to Hayy Najwah is twenty miles. From Hayy Najwah to Sabkhat Manhusa is thirty miles. From Sabkhat Manhusa to Qasr al-Atash is thirty-four miles. From Qasr al-Atash to Al-Yahudiyatayn, which are two villages on the sea shore, is twenty-four miles. From Al-Yahudiyatayn to Qabr al-Abbadi is thirty-four miles. From Qabr al-Abbadi to Sirte is thirty-four miles. From Sirte to Al-Qarnayn is eighteen miles. From Al-Qarnayn to Maghmadash is twenty miles. From Maghmadash to Qusur Hassan is thirty miles. From Qusur Hassan to Al-Munsaf is forty miles. From Al-Munsaf to Tawurgha is twenty-four miles. From Tawurgha to Raghugha is twenty miles. From Raghugha to Wardasa is eighteen miles. From Wardasa to Al-Muhtana is twenty-two miles. From Al-Muhtana to Wadi al-Raml is twenty miles. From Wadi al-Raml to Tripoli is twenty-four miles. From Tripoli to a city called Sabra (Sabratha), which is ruined, is twenty-four miles. From Sabra to Bi'r al-Jamalayn is twenty miles. From Bi'r al-Jamalayn to Qasr

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: al-Daraq is thirty miles. From Qasr al-Daraq to Badrakht is twenty-four miles. From Badrakht to Al-Fawwara is thirty miles. From Al-Fawwara to Gabes, which is a city, is thirty miles. From the city of Gabes to Bi'r al-Zaytuna is eighteen miles. From Bi'r al-Zaytuna to Kitana is twenty-four miles. From Kitana to Al-Yiss is thirty miles. From Al-Yiss to the gate of the city of Kairouan, which is the city of Ifriqiya, is twenty-four miles. Since we have mentioned the roads east, west, south, and north, there is no harm in mentioning the Stages (Sikak) where men are stationed to carry the mailbags and which are established as the official post. We begin from the City of Peace (Baghdad) and describe the road from it taken east and west. From the City of Peace to Al-Mada'in is three stages. From the stage of Al-Mada'in to Jarjaraya is eight stages. From Jarjaraya to the stage of Jabbal is five stages. From Jabbal to the city of Wasit—and its stage is the first district of the Kurah of Tigris—is eight stages. From the stage of Al-Marumah—which is the first of the Kurah of Tigris adjacent to Wasit—to the stage of Badhibin is three stages. From the stage of Badhibin to Dayr Ma Banah—the last district of the Kurah of Tigris adjacent to the district of Ahwaz—is thirteen stages. From Dayr Ma Banah to Nahr Tira is four stages. From Nahr Tira to Souq al-Ahwaz is three stages. From

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Souq al-Ahwaz to Al-Barjan, the last district of Ahwaz, is fourteen stages. From Al-Barjan to the stage of Arrajan is one stage. From the stage of Arrajan to Al-Nubandajan is seventeen stages. From Al-Nubandajan to the stage of Shiraz is twelve stages. From Shiraz to the stage of Istakhr is five stages. The Road turning from Badhibin to Basra has stationed couriers: From Badhibin to Abdus is five stages. From Abdus to the stage of Al-Madhar is eight stages. From Al-Madhar to Basra—where post animals used to be—is three stages. Stages of the East Road towards the Mountains (Jibal): From the City of Peace to Al-Daskara is ten stages. From Al-Daskara to Jalula al-Waqi'a is four stages. From Jalula al-Waqi'a to the city of Hulwan is ten stages. From Hulwan to Nasirabad, the last of its districts, is nine stages. From Nasirabad to Qarmasin is six stages. From Qarmasin to Khandadh, the last district of Dinawar, is ten stages. From Khandadh to the city of Hamadan is three stages. From the city of Hamadan to Mushkuyah, the last district of Hamadan adjacent to Rayy, is twenty-one stages. From Hulwan to Shahrazur is nine stages. From Hulwan to the city of Al-Sirwan is seven stages. From the city of Al-Sirwan to Sinn Sumayra is four stages. From Sinn Sumayra to Dinawar is two stages. From Dinawar to Yazdajird, the last district of Dinawar adjacent to Zanjan, is eighteen stages. From the stage of Yazdajird to Zanjan is eleven stages. From Zanjan to Maragha is eleven

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: stages. From Maragha to Miyanaj is two stages. From Miyanaj to Ardabil is eleven stages. From Ardabil to the stage of Warthan, which is the last stage of the district of Azerbaijan, is eleven stages. From the stage of Warthan to the city of Bardha'a is eight stages. From the stage of Bardha'a to Al-Mansurah is four stages. From Bardha'a to the City of Al-Mutawakkiliya is six stages. From the City of Al-Mutawakkiliya to Tiflis is ten stages. From Bardha'a to Al-Bab wal-Abwab is fifteen stages. From Bardha'a to Dabil is nine stages. Stages of the Road turning to Qom and Isfahan: From Al-Dur to Qom is three stages. From Qom to Isfahan is forty-seven farsakhs. From the city of Qom to the stage of Rud, its last district adjacent to Isfahan, is thirteen stages. The Road turning to Nahavand: From Madharan in the district of Dinawar to Nahavand is three stages. The Road turning from Rakad to Qazvin: From Rakad to Qazvin is one stage. The Road taking to the regions of the West: From Baghdad to Al-Baradan is two stages. From Baradan to Ukbara is four stages. From Ukbara to Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) is seven stages. From Surra Man Ra'a to Jabalta is seven stages. From Jabalta to Al-Sinn is ten stages. From Al-Sinn to Al-Haditha is nine stages. From Al-Haditha to Mosul is seven stages. From Mosul to the first district of Balad is one stage. From the last

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: district of Mosul to the stage of Balad is three stages. From Balad to Adhrama is nine stages. From Adhrama to Nusaybin is six stages. From Nusaybin to Kafartutha is three stages. From Kafartutha to Ra's al-Ayn is ten stages. From Ra's al-Ayn to Raqqa is fifteen stages. From Raqqa to Al-Naqira, the last district of Diyar Mudar, is ten stages. From Al-Naqira to Manbij is five stages. From Manbij to Aleppo is nine stages. From Aleppo to Qinnasrin is three stages. From Qinnasrin to the first district of Homs is one stage. From the stage of Al-Marj, which is the first stage adjacent to the district of Qinnasrin, to Sawran is seven stages. From Sawran to Hama is two stages. From Hama to Homs is four stages. From Homs to Al-Muhammadiyah is four stages. From Al-Muhammadiyah to Baalbek is five stages. From Baalbek to Damascus is nine stages. From Damascus to Dayr Ayyub, its last district, is seven stages. From Dayr Ayyub to Tiberias is six stages. From Tiberias, the capital of Jordan, to Al-Lajjun in the district of Jordan is four stages. From Al-Lajjun to Ramla, the capital of Palestine, is nine stages. From Ramla to the last district of Palestine, which is the stage of Al-Mu'aynah, is nine stages. From the stage of Al-Mu'aynah to the end of the Jifar road, which is the stage of Al-Darura, is seventeen stages. The Road turning from Nusaybin to Arzan and Khlat: From Nusaybin to

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: the city of Arzan is eleven stages. From Bitlis to Khlat is four stages. The Road turning from Kafartutha to Shimshat: From Kafartutha to Amid is seven stages. From Amid to Tal Jufar is two stages. From Tal Jufar to Shimshat is six stages. From Shimshat to Qaliqala is two stages. The Road turning from Al-Hisn to the Jaziran Frontiers via Harran and Al-Ruha (Edessa): From Al-Hisn to Harran is three stages. From Harran to Al-Ruha is two stages. From Al-Ruha to Sumaysat is three stages. From Sumaysat to Hisn Mansur is two stages. The Road turning from Diyar Mudar to the Euphrates road: From Raqqa to the stage of Dabba, the last district of Diyar Mudar, is nine stages. Stages of the Road turning from Manbij to the Syrian Frontiers: From Aleppo to Qinnasrin is nine stages. From Qinnasrin to Antioch is four stages. From Antioch to Iskenderun is four stages. From Iskenderun to Al-Massisa is seven stages. From Al-Massisa to Adana is three stages. From Adana to Tarsus is five stages. From Al-Massisa to Ayn Zarba is two stages. We return to the Road turning from Tiberias to Tyre: From Tiberias to Tyre is seven stages. The road from Fustat to Alexandria is thirteen stages. From Alexandria to Jubb al-Raml adjacent to Barqa is thirty stages. The stages of the regions we have not mentioned are sufficiently covered by what we have mentioned of the distances between them. But this is the last of what we shall mention in this Station (Part), God willing. The Fifth Station of the Book of Land Tax and the Craft of Writing is completed.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: From the Second Chapter (of the Sixth Station) regarding the Division of the Inhabited Earth... and a part attributed to the lands of Fars called the Land of the Two Mosques (Balad al-Jami'ayn), which is what is between the River of Balkh and the end of Azerbaijan and Armenia to the Euphrates and Al-Qadisiyah... This First Clime is called Marais, which is the city of Abyssinia. As for the Second Clime... its name is the Clime of Aswan, which is the city on the borders of the Beja and the land of Egypt. The Third Clime... is called the Clime of Egypt. The Fourth Clime... is called the Clime of Antarsus (Tortosa). The Fifth Clime... is called the Clime of Rudhash. The Sixth Clime... is called the Clime of Pontus because its line is across the middle of the Sea of Pontus. From the Third Chapter regarding the Placement of the Seas of the Inhabited Earth... And from this sea, a gulf exits from the land of Abyssinia and extends to the region of the Berbers, called the Gulf of Berbera. The length of its direction is five hundred miles, and the base from which it starts in the Great Sea is one hundred miles. Another gulf passes by the city called Ayla; its length from where it begins to where it ends is one thousand four hundred miles, and at its end in the west and the place connected to the Green Sea is two hundred miles. This Green Sea is known

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: as the Ocean (Al-Muhit), and in Greek 'Lucianus'. Nothing is known of its condition except what is adjacent to the western region in the furthest land of Abyssinia and what is adjacent to the northern region only. In it, from the western region, are the islands called the Fortunate Isles (Al-Khalidat), and another island called Ghadira opposite the land of Andalusia at a strait seven miles wide that exits from the Green Sea and passes between Andalusia and Tangier, called Ceuta (Sabta), and penetrates into the Sea of Rome. In it also, from the northern region, are twelve islands, which are the islands called the Isles of Britannia. As for beyond this sea called the Ocean, ships do not sail in it, and no human knows its condition. As for the Sea of Rome and Egypt... in it is a gulf exiting to the northern region near the land of Rome, five hundred miles long, called Idris. In it is another gulf exiting from the land known as Narbonne, two hundred miles long. In the Sea of Rome are one hundred and seventy-two islands; all were inhabited, but the Muslims ruined most of them through raids. Among them are five great ones: the Island of Cyprus... the Island of Crete... the Island of Sicily... the Island of Sardinia... and the Island of Yabis (Ibiza) opposite Andalusia... And a gulf flows from it at Constantinople until it pours into the Sea of Rome. Its length from its beginning at the city of Constantinople to where it pours is two hundred and sixty miles. It has ships. Its width varies; at Constantinople it is three miles, in another place six miles, and in another place a mile, more or less. Its width at its narrowest point is a bowshot. At that place is a rock with a tower built on it, containing someone from the Romans who inspects the ships. From the Fourth Chapter on Mountains:

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: As for the Fourth Clime, there are twenty-four mountains in it. Among them is the Mountain of Snow (Jabal al-Thalj) in Damascus, eighty-three miles long. And Mount Sanir in this region, forty-five miles long. And Mount Al-Lukam in this region, one hundred miles long. And a mountain connected to Hulwan, one hundred and fifteen miles long. And the mountain that passes by Isfahan and turns to the mountain of Nahavand, four hundred and thirty-five miles long. And the mountain connected to this round mountain between Isfahan and Ahwaz, two hundred and twenty-two miles long. And the mountain passing between Istakhr and Jur, two hundred and fifty miles long. And the mountain connected to Nahavand and the mountain of Tabaristan, eight hundred miles long. As for the Fifth Clime, there are twenty-nine mountains in it. Among them are Mount Harith and Huwayrith, thirty-three miles long. And the mountain between Mosul and Shahrazur, two hundred and forty-five miles long. And the mountain connected to this mountain and to Harith and Huwayrith until the mountain connects to Qazvin and approaches Ruyan, two hundred miles long. From the Fifth Chapter on Rivers, Springs, and Marshes: As for the Fifth Clime, there are twenty-five rivers in it. Among them is the Tigris (Dijlah). Its beginning is at longitude sixty-odd degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees. It flows south then veers west slightly. Its source is from a spring flowing between two mountains at the city of Amid. It passes by Basurin until it comes to the city of Balad and the city of Mosul. Between them, reaching Al-Haditha; when it reaches there, a river coming from the land of Shahrazur called the Zab pours into it. Then it extends passing between two mountains, one known as Barma and the other as Satidama, until it passes the city of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra). When it passes it slightly, a river falls into it called

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Al-Zayb, coming from the mountain. Another river coming from the mountain also falls into it. Then the Tigris passes through the middle of the city of Baghdad, then passes by Wasit until it pours into the Marshes (Al-Bata'ih). Its length is sixty-odd miles. Then it exits and splits into two branches: one branch goes to Basra and another branch goes to the region of Al-Madhar. Then the whole flows into the Sea of Fars. The distance of the Tigris from its beginning to its end is eight hundred and odd miles. As for the Sixth Clime, there are twenty-six rivers in it. Among them is the Euphrates. Its beginning is from a spring in the land of the Romans issuing from Mount Burujus. It flows westward in the land of the Romans until it touches a mountain called Masfina, then inclines until it travels about four hundred and fifty miles. Then it turns south, descending to the land of Islam between Sairt, Malatya, and Shimshat. It passes by the city of Hanzit, then turns west until it reaches the city of Sumaysat between its citadel. It passes westward until it reaches the city of Jisr Manbij, then bends seeking the south until it comes to Balis, then Raqqa, then Qarqisiya. It passes by Al-Rahba, then passes until it wraps around Ana, for it is in its middle. Then it extends on its course passing by Hit and Al-Anbar. Upon passing them, it divides into two parts: one part takes slightly towards the west, called Al-Alqami, until it reaches Kufa; and a straight part called Sura, until it passes by the city of Sura to the Nile and what connects to it,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: watering many of the districts of the Sawad. A river known as Al-Duqayl exits from it below Al-Anbar; the Isa River is carried from it, which takes to Baghdad and pours into the Tigris there. The totality of what remains of the Euphrates water, after it separates into the rivers to water the districts of the Sawad, passes to pour into the Tigris below Wasit. The length of the Euphrates from its appearance in the land of Islam until it comes to Baghdad is six hundred and twenty-three miles. The Sixth Chapter on the Kingdom of Islam, its Districts, and its Revenue: If East, West, North, or South are said, all these names are said relative to a specific thing. For example, Egypt, while we count it among the districts of the West, is East for one who is in the land of Andalusia. Likewise, Khorasan is East for us and West for the people of China. Similarly, all regions must have a capital from which its directions are indicated. We say that the capital of the Kingdom of Islam is the land of Iraq. Even though this is found to be so at this time, the Persians used to conduct it as such and called it Del Iranshahr (The Heart of Iranshahr). The Arabs only named Iraq by this name as an Arabization of what they found the Persians naming it, which is Iran. The meaning of Iran is attributed to Ir, who are the people chosen by Ir son of Afridun son of Wayun-Jahan son of Ushhanj son of Firuzan son of Siyamak son of Narsi son of Gayumarth. The interpretation of Gayumarth, according to what the Mobad informed me, is the Living, Speaking, Mortal. The Persians trace their origin and beginning to Gayumarth, and they call him the station of Adam, peace be upon him.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: The District (Kurah) of Hulwan and its Tassujs (sub-districts) are five Tassujs: Tassuj Shadh Firuz Qubadh, Tassuj Al-Jabal, Tassuj Erbil, Tassuj Tamarra, Tassuj Khanaqin. The Province (Istan) of Shadh Qubadh and its Tassujs are seven: Tassuj Buzurjasabur, Tassuj Nahr Buq, Tassuj Kalwadha, Tassuj Jazir, Tassuj Al-Madina Al-Atiqa, Tassuj Upper Radhan, Tassuj Lower Radhan. The Province of Khasra Shadh Hurmuz and its Tassujs are eight: Tassuj Rustaqbadh, Tassuj Mahrudh, Tassuj Salsal, Tassuj Jalula and Jalalta, Tassuj Al-Dhibin, Tassuj Al-Bandanijin, Tassuj Baraz al-Ruz, Tassuj Al-Daskara. The Province of Arandin Kard and its Tassujs are five: three are the Tassujs of the Nahrawans, and the Tassujs of Badaraya and Bakxaya. The Province of Khasra Sabur, which is the District of Kaskar, and its Tassujs are four: Tassuj Al-Zandaward, Tassuj Al-Bazbun, Tassuj Al-Istan, Tassuj Al-Jawazir. The Province of Khasra Shadh Bahman, which is the District of Tigris, and its Tassujs are four: Tassuj Bahman Ardashir, Tassuj Maysan, Tassuj Dastamaysan, Tassuj Abazqubadh. These are the Tassujs east of the Tigris. As for the western side of it, which is the irrigation of the Euphrates, among that is the Province of Al-Ali (Upper Province) and its Tassujs are four: Tassuj Firuz Sabur, Tassuj Maskin, Tassuj Qatrabbul, Tassuj Al-Anbar, Tassuj Baduraya.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: And the Province of Ardashir Babakan and its Tassujs are five: Tassuj Bahrasir, Tassuj Al-Rumaqan, Tassuj Kutha, Tassuj Darqit, Tassuj Nahr Jubar. And the Province of Rawin? As??ar, which is the Zabs (Al-Zawabi), and its Tassujs are three: The Upper Zab, The Middle Zab, The Lower Zab. And the Province of Upper Bihqubadh and its Tassujs are six: Tassuj Babel, Tassuj Khatarniyah, Tassuj Lower Fallujah, Tassuj Upper Fallujah, Tassuj Al-Nahrayn, Tassuj Ayn al-Tamr. And the Province of Middle Bihqubadh and its Tassujs are four: Tassuj Al-Jubba and Al-Budah, Tassuj Sura and Barbisma, Tassuj Barusma, Tassuj Nahr al-Malik. And the Province of Lower Bihqubadh and its Tassujs are five: Tassuj Badaqli, Tassuj Al-Saylahin, Tassuj Nistar, Tassuj Rudhmastan, Tassuj Hurmuzjird. Departing from the Tassujs of the Sawad—which were, as we mentioned, sixty Tassujs—twelve were subtracted: The District of Hulwan added to the District of Al-Jabal (five Tassujs); the District of Tigris added to the districts of Basra (four Tassujs); what entered the Marshes and water overcame it (one Tassuj); and what was counted in the Private Estates, two Tassujs from the districts of the Khorasan road, returned from the District of Lower Bihqubadh. So what is counted in the Sawad at this time is ten Districts (Kuras) and their Tassujs are forty-eight Tassujs. Let us begin by mentioning the revenue of the Sawad according to what it is at this time and based on the standard of the year 204, which is the first year whose calculation is found in the bureaus at the Capital,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: because the bureaus were burned in the sedition (Fitna) that occurred in the days of Al-Amin, known as Ibn Zubayda, which is the year 83 [sic; historically closer to 198 AH]. The sequence of that and the border of Iraq from the west side is on this detail: Regions / Wheat / Barley / Silver (Dirhams). Al-Anbar and the Known River / 11800 Kurr / 6400 Kurr / 400000 Dirhams. Tassuj Maskin / 3000 Kurr / 1000 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Tassuj Qatrabbul / 2000 Kurr / 1000 Kurr / 300000 Dirhams. Tassuj Baduraya / 3500 Kurr / 1000 Kurr / 1000000 Dirhams. Bahrasir / 1700 Kurr / 1700 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Al-Rumaqan / 3300 Kurr / 3300 Kurr / 250000 Dirhams. Kutha / 3000 Kurr / 2000 Kurr / 350000 Dirhams. Nahr Darqit / 2000 Kurr / 2000 Kurr / 200000 Dirhams. Nahr Jubar / 1500 Kurr / 6000 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Barusma and Nahr al-Malik / 3500 Kurr / 4000 Kurr / 122000 Dirhams. The Three Zabs / 1400 Kurr / 7200 Kurr / 250000 Dirhams. Babel and Khatarniyah / 3000 Kurr / 5000 Kurr / 350000 Dirhams. Upper Fallujah / 500 Kurr / 500 Kurr / 70000 Dirhams. Lower Fallujah / 2000 Kurr / 3000 Kurr / 280000 Dirhams. Tassuj Al-Nahrayn / 300 Kurr / 400 Kurr / 45000 Dirhams. Tassuj Ayn al-Tamr / 300 Kurr / 400 Kurr / 45000 Dirhams. Tassuj Al-Jubba and Al-Budah / 1500 Kurr / 1600 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Sura and Barbisma / 1500 Kurr / 4500 Kurr / 250000 Dirhams.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Regions / Wheat / Barley / Silver (Dirhams). Upper and Lower Burs / 500 Kurr / 5500 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Furat Badaqli / 2000 Kurr / 2500 Kurr / 62000 Dirhams. Tassuj Al-Saylahin / 1000 Kurr / 1500 Kurr / 140000 Dirhams. Rudhmastan and Hurmuzjird / 500 Kurr / 500 Kurr / 20000 Dirhams. Nistar / 2200 Kurr / 2000 Kurr / 300000 Dirhams. Ighar Yaqtin / 1200 Kurr / 2000 Kurr / 204800 Dirhams. Districts of Kaskar: it is said that its revenue in the old days was 90000 [sic; context suggests larger sum or different unit] Dirhams, and at this time is 30000 Kurr / 20000 Kurr / 270000 Dirhams. These are the districts of the Sawad on the western side of the Tigris. As for the eastern side, let us begin listing them in sequence also from the upper Tigris. Tassuj Buzurjasabur / 2500 Kurr / 2200 Kurr / 300000 Dirhams. Tassuj Al-Radhanayn / 4800 Kurr / 4800 Kurr / 120000 Dirhams. Tassuj Nahr Buq / 200 Kurr / 1000 Kurr / 100000 Dirhams. Kalwadha and Nahr Bin / 1600 Kurr / 1500 Kurr / 330000 Dirhams. Jazir and Al-Madina Al-Atiqa / 1000 Kurr / 1500 Kurr / 240000 Dirhams. Rustaqbadh / 1000 Kurr / 1400 Kurr / 246000 Dirhams. Salsal and Mahrudh / 2000 Kurr / 1500 Kurr / 150000 Dirhams. Jalula and Jalalta / 1000 Kurr / 1000 Kurr / 100000 Dirhams. Al-Dhibin / 1900 Kurr / 1300 Kurr / 40000 Dirhams. Al-Daskara / 1800 Kurr / 1400 Kurr / 60000 Dirhams. Al-Bandanijin / 600 Kurr / 500 Kurr / 35000 Dirhams.

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: Regions / Wheat / Barley / Silver (Dirhams). Tassuj Baraz al-Ruz / 3000 Kurr / 5100 Kurr / 120000 Dirhams. Upper Nahrawan / 1700 Kurr / 1800 Kurr / 350000 Dirhams. Middle Nahrawan / 1000 Kurr / 500 Kurr / 100000 Dirhams. Badaraya and Bakxaya / 4700 Kurr / 5000 Kurr / 330000 Dirhams. District of Tigris on the standard of the year 260 / 900 Kurr / 4000 Kurr / 430000 Dirhams. Nahr al-Silah on that standard / 1000 Kurr / 3121 Kurr / 59000 Dirhams. Lower Nahrawan / 1700 Kurr / 1300 Kurr / 53000 Dirhams. That is the revenue of the Sawad, excluding the alms of Basra: of wheat, one hundred and seventy-seven thousand two hundred Kurr; of barley, ninety-nine thousand seven hundred and twenty-one Kurr; and of silver, eight million ninety-five thousand eight hundred Dirhams. The price of the crops at average prices—calculating two combined Kurrs of wheat and barley at sixty dinars, converted to silver at an exchange of fifteen dirhams per dinar—is one hundred and thirty million one hundred and sixty-one thousand eight hundred and fifty Dirhams. The total of that added to the silver is one hundred and thirty-eight million four hundred and fifty-seven thousand six hundred and fifty Dirhams. The alms of Basra used to amount to six million Dirhams a year. So the total revenue of the Sawad, according to the pricing explained on the indicated standards,

book_title: Al-Masalik wal-Mamalik (The Book of Roads and Kingdoms)
text: is one hundred and fourteen million four hundred and fifty-seven thousand six hundred and fifty Dirhams [Note: math in text appears inconsistent with previous segment total, likely manuscript variants]. The cause of the marshes flooding in the land of the Sawad is that the water of the Tigris used to pour into the Tigris known as the Blind One (Al-Awra), which is below Basra, in a straight path with protected banks. When it was the reign of Qubadh Firuz, a great breach burst in lower Kaskar. He neglected its matter until its water overwhelmed and drowned many inhabited lands adjacent to it and near it. When his son Anushirvan ruled, he ordered concerning that water, so it was confined by dikes until some of those lands returned to cultivation. Then, when it was the year 6 of the Hijra—the year in which the Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Abdullah bin Hudhafah al-Sahmi to Kisra Parviz—the Euphrates increased greatly, and the Tigris also, the like of which had not been seen. Great breaches burst. Parviz struggled to dam them, even building forty dams in one day, and he ordered money to be thrown onto leather mats, but he could not manage the water. Then the Muslims arrived in Iraq, and the Persians were occupied with war. The breaches would burst and not be attended to, and the Dehghans were unable to block them. So its water became great, and the marsh widened and grew. When Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan ruled, he appointed Abdullah bin Darraj, his mawla, over the land tax of Iraq. He reclaimed from the land of the marshes what amounted to a yield of five million dirhams. Hassan al-Nabati, the mawla of Bani Dabbah and owner of the Pool of Hassan in Basra, the Canal of Hassan in the marshes, and the Village of Hassan in Wasit, when he managed that for Al-Walid then for Hisham bin Abd al-Malik, reclaimed much of the land of the marshes. And the reclamation...

in it is situated until this time, and they are the lands attributed to the solid grounds (Al-Jawamid). There was a river in Kasker called Al-Janb, and the postal route to Misan, Dastmisan, and Ahwaz was on its southern side. When the marshes (Al-Bata'ih) flooded, the part of the postal route that became submerged was named 'Al-Barid' (The Post), and the other part was named 'Al-Nabatiyyah Aghmarbati', the interpretation of which in Arabic is 'The Great Marshes'. It is said that the wells of the river might appear in what is extracted from the marshes at this time. The reason for the Two Saybs (Al-Saybayn): They were not mentioned in the days of the Persians, nor were they reclaimed during their era; rather, breaches burst open in the days of Al-Hajjaj and grew large and great. Al-Hajjaj wrote to Al-Walid about them, stating that he estimated the cost to dam them at three million dirhams.
