Al-Walid considered this too much, so Maslama bin Abd al-Malik said to him, "I will spend on damming them from my own money, on the condition that you give me the land tax (kharaj) of the lowlands where the water remains after the money is spent, at the hands of your trustworthy agents." He agreed to that. So, he acquired many lands and districts (Tassus), dug the two rivers named Al-Saybayn, gathered farmers and cultivators, and developed those lands. People also entrusted much of their adjacent lands to him seeking protection through him. When the Abbasid state rose and seized the wealth of the Banu Umayyah, all of Al-Saybayn was granted to Dawud bin Ali bin Abdullah bin al-Abbas. It was later purchased from his heirs, so it became part of the Sultan's estates. The reason for the Ighar of Yaqtin: It was not mentioned in the days of the Persians nor in what we named of the lands of the Sawad during their era. But Yaqtin, the propagandist (Sahib al-Da'wah), had estates from several districts made immune (Ighar) for him, then that passed to the Sultan and was attributed to the Ighar of Yaqtin. The River of the Gift (Nahr al-Silah): Al-Mahdi ordered it to be dug in the districts of Wasit, so it was dug and he revived what was...

...upon it of lands, and its yield was assigned for the gifts (Silat) of the people of the Two Sanctuaries (Mecca and Medina) and the expenses there. It is narrated that a condition was made for the cultivators gathered upon it that they would share crop on it for fifty years; when the fifty years ended, the condition stipulated for them was not continued. Since we have finished with the matter of the Sawad and its districts, we follow that with Ahwaz, as it adjoins the districts of the Sawad from the eastern side. We say that Ahwaz has seven districts (Kuwar). The first of them from the border of Basra is the district of Suq al-Ahwaz; and next to Al-Madhar is the district of Nahr Tira; then the district of Tustar, the district of Susa, the district of Jundishapur, the district of Ram Hormuz, and the district of Suq al-Atiq. The revenue (Irtifa') of these districts, on approximation and average in silver, is eighteen million dirhams. We follow Ahwaz with Fars, which has five districts. The first of them from the border of Ahwaz is the district of Arrajan, the district of Ardashir, the district of Darabjird, the district of Istakhr, and the district of Sabur. The coasts of Fars are Mahruban, Siniz, Jannaba, Tawwaj, and Siraf. The revenue of Fars alone in silver is twenty-four million dirhams. Then following Fars is Kerman; its cities are Al-Sirjan, Jiroft, and Bam, and its coasts are Hormuz. The revenue of its districts is six million dirhams. After it are the cities of Makran from the districts of Sind; there was a fixed contract on Makran annually for one million dirhams. Adjoining Fars from the north side is Isfahan, which is a district on its own, and its annual revenue is ten million and five hundred thousand dirhams. Adjoining Kerman from the east side is Sijistan, and its capital is known as Zaranj; its revenue by treaty is one million dirhams.

Then follow the districts of Khorasan. Connected to Sijistan among them are Bust, Rukhkhaj, and Kabul—and perhaps they were added to its districts due to their connection—and the district of Khorasan [includes] Bust, Rukhkhaj, Kabul, Zabulistan, Al-Tabas, Quhistan, Herat, Al-Taliqan, H??huma, Badghis, Bushanj, Tukharistan, Al-Tariqan, Balkh, Khulm, Marw al-Rudh, Al-Saghaniyan, Washjird, Bukhara, Tus, Al-Faryab, Abarshahr, Kar, Samarkand, Al-Shash, Ferghana, Ushrusana, Al-Sughd, Khujandah, Khwarazm, Isfijab, Al-Tirmidh, Nisa, Abivard, Marw, Kesh, Al-Nushajan, Al-Buttam, Akhrun, and Nasaf. The revenue of Khorasan, according to what Abdullah bin Tahir assessed for the year 221 [AH], along with the price of captives, sheep, and fabrics, was thirty-eight million dirhams. Since we have covered Khorasan from the east, in which are the frontiers of the Turks and the utmost limit of Islam from this direction, let us turn to the districts of the East that deviate towards the north. Let us begin them with the districts of Hulwan, the district of Hulwan. We have explained the situation that it was attached to the districts of Iraq, then added to the districts of Al-Jabal (The Mountains/Media) (1). They are the district of Mah al-Kufa, Mah al-Basra, Azerbaijan, Hamadhan, Al-Aygharayn, Qumm, Masabadhan, and Mihrajanqadhaq. These districts are attributed to Al-Jabal excluding others. Their revenue in detail: As for Mah al-Kufa and its two capitals—as for the capital of the upper rustaqs (sub-districts), it is Dinawar, and as for the capital...

...of the lower rustaqs, it is Qirmisin. The borders of Mah al-Kufa are: from the west, the districts of Hulwan; from the south, the districts of Masabadhan; from the east, the districts of Hamadhan; and from the north, the districts of Azerbaijan. Its revenue based on the average lesson is five million dirhams. Mah al-Basra, and its capitals are Nihawand and Burujird; its revenue based on the average lesson is four million and eight hundred thousand dirhams. Hamadhan, its revenue based on the average lesson is one million and seven hundred thousand dirhams. Masabadhan, and its cities are Al-Sirwan and Ariyjan; its revenue is one million and one hundred thousand dirhams. Mihrajanqadhaq, and its capital is Al-Saymarah; its revenue based on the average lesson is one million and one hundred thousand dirhams. Al-Aygharayn, which are estates from several districts, and its two capitals are Al-Karaj and Al-Marj; its revenue based on the average lesson is three million and one hundred thousand dirhams. Qumm and Qashan, their revenue based on the average lesson in silver is three million dirhams. Azerbaijan and its districts: Ardabil, Marand, Jabrawan, Warthan, and its capital is the city of Bardha'a; its revenue based on the average lesson is four million and five hundred thousand dirhams. The district of Rayy, which is assessed on its own, and it is in the east on the borders of Hamadhan, and Dunbawand is added to it; that revenue is twenty million and two hundred thousand dirhams. The district of Qazvin, its revenue based on the lesson of the year 237 is one million, six hundred and twenty-eight thousand dirhams. Qumis: this region is north of Rayy, and its cities are Damghan and Semnan; its revenue is one million, one hundred and fifty thousand dirhams. Jurjan, which is north of Qumis and towards the east of it, and Jurjan...

...is the capital; its revenue is four million dirhams. Tabaristan, which is the farthest towards the north, and its cities are Amul and Sari; its revenue based on the lesson of the year 234 is four million, one hundred and sixty-three thousand and seventy dirhams. Then adjacent to that from the east is the desert of the Turks, and from the north Al-Babr and Al-Taylasan. Since we have finished the districts of the East, let us return to the districts of the West. The first of them from the border of the Euphrates is Tikrit, Al-Tirhan, Al-Sinn, and Al-Bawazij; its revenue based on the average lesson is seven hundred thousand dirhams. Then adjacent to that is Mosul and its districts. Shahrazur, Al-Samaghan, and Darabadh were part of the district of Mosul until they were separated from it. As for Shahrazur, Al-Samaghan, and Darabadh from the districts of Mosul, their obligation was two million, seven hundred and fifty thousand dirhams. As for the revenue settled for the districts of Mosul, which are on the western side: the district of Al-Jazira, the district of Nineveh, the district of Al-Marj, and the province of Ba'adhra; and from the eastern side: Al-Haditha, Hazza, Bahadra, Al-Mughallah, Jabtun, Al-Hanayah, Al-Sa, Al-Daybur, and Dasin. The average revenue of these districts is six million and three hundred thousand dirhams. Adjacent to the districts of Mosul from the north are Qarda and Bazabda, wherein is Mount Judi upon which Noah's Ark rested; its two capitals are Al-Jazira, known as [Jazirat] Bani Omar, and Basurin, where the salt carried to Iraq in skiffs is produced. Its revenue based on the average lesson is three million and two hundred thousand dirhams. Then adjacent to that is Diyar Rabi'a, and its districts are Balad, Ba'arbaya, Nisibis, Dara, Mardin, Kafartutha, a hill called Sinjar, Ras al-Ayn, and Al-Khabur. The revenue of this...

...district with calculations is four million, six hundred and thirty-five thousand dirhams. Then adjoining Diyar Rabi'a from the north are the two districts of Arzan and Mayyafariqin; their revenue based on the average lesson is four million and one hundred thousand dirhams. Adjacent to it is the town of Tarun (Taron) from the districts of Armenia; the contract of its master per year is one hundred thousand dirhams. Beyond that from the north are the lands of Armenia, and its districts are Jurzan, Dabil, Barzand, Siraj Tayr, Bajnis, Arjish, Khilat, Al-Sisajan, Arran, the district of Qaliqala, Al-Busfarjan, and its capital is Nashawa. Its average revenue in silver is four million dirhams. Then the districts of Diyar Mudar in the west: Edessa (Al-Ruhā), Harran, Saruj, Al-Mudaybir, Al-Balikh, Tell Mawzan, Rabiyat Bani Tamim, Qurayyat al-Furat, the Bank of the Euphrates, Mazih, Umar. And from the western side of the Euphrates: Al-Hani and Al-Mari. The revenue of Diyar Mudar based on the average lesson is six million dirhams. When the districts of the West are arranged not from the north but specifically from the west side, the first of them is Hit, Ana, Al-Rahba, Qarqisiya, and so on until it connects to the districts of the land of Egypt; this is called the districts of the Euphrates Road, and its revenue is two million and nine hundred thousand dirhams. Then after Diyar Mudar towards the west are the districts of Jund Qinnasrin and Al-Awasim of the Levant (Sham). The cities of these districts are Aleppo, Antioch, Manbij; its revenue in gold is three hundred and sixty thousand dinars. Then follows that the districts of Homs of the Levant; its revenue is one hundred and eighteen...

...thousand dinars. Then follows that the districts of Jund Damascus of the Levant; its revenue is one hundred and ten thousand dinars. Then the districts of Jund al-Urdunn (Jordan) of the Levant; its revenue is one hundred and nine thousand dinars. Then the districts of Jund Filastin (Palestine) of the Levant, the city of Ramla, and Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem); its revenue in gold is one hundred and ninety-five thousand dinars. Then the districts of Egypt and Alexandria and their sub-districts (Kuwar). As for what is attributed to the land of Upper Egypt (Al-Sa'id): Al-Fayyum, Memphis (Manf), Wasim, Al-Sharqiyyah, Dalas, Busir, Kuridus, Al-Abbas, Al-Khalifah, Al-Bahnasa, Al-Qays, Taha, Al-Ashmunayn, Hayz Shanudah, Ansina, Suyut, Shutb, Qahquh, Akhmim, Al-Dayr, Ibshayah, Faw, Hu, Qina, Dendera, Qift, Luxor, Armant, Esna, Edfu, Aswan. And what is attributed to the Lower Land: San, Iblil, Natu, Atrabiyah, Al-Tur, Ayla, Faran, Rayat al-Hijaz, Al-Farama, Nusa, Damietta, Tinnis, Manuf, Tawah, Sakha, Tida, Al-Afrahun, Naqizah, Al-Arish, Disa, Al-Qass, Sa, Shabas, Al-Badaqun, Qartasa, Kharbata, Tarnut...

...Masil, Al-Malidus, Daqahla, Akhnu, Rashid (Rosetta), Bashrut. The revenue of these districts in gold is two million and five hundred thousand dinars. Beyond Barqa is Kairouan (Al-Qayrawan). There remain for us among the regions those we have not mentioned, the southern region, so let us return to it. We say that the southern tracts of Iraq are Najd, Hejaz, Mecca, Medina, and the districts of Yemen, then deviating towards the east are the districts of Oman, Yamama, and Bahrain. As for Najd, its beginning is the border of Iraq from the south side, which is, as we mentioned earlier, Al-Udhayb, extending straight to Al-Ghawr. In the west, it is the first boundaries of Al-Samawah, and it is more elevated than Yamama. Most of the districts of Najd have no habitation except a little. In Najd are the two mountains of Tayy, known as such, and their waters. Then follows Al-Ghawr, which is from the border of Najd to the last boundaries of Tihama. It has districts attributed to Mikhlifs (administrative divisions) and A'rad (valleys/villages), including Lina, Al-Umaq, Najran, Qarn al-Manazil, Ukaz, Ta'if, Bisha, Jurash, Tabala, Katna, Al-Sharah. The valleys (A'rad) of Medina, its districts, and its settlements are Taybah (Medina), Yathrib, Tayma, Dumat al-Jandal, Al-Fara', Dhu al-Marwah, Wadi al-Qura, Madyan, Khaybar, Fadak, Arab villages, Saya, Rahat, Al-Sayyalah, Al-Rahba, Ghurab, Al-Akhal. The revenue of all that, which is called the Two Sanctuaries (Al-Haramayn), is one hundred thousand dinars. From that in the south are the districts of Yemen and its Mikhlifs, which are: Mikhlaf Sana'a, Mikhlaf Sa'da, Mikhlaf Shakir, Hamdan, Suda, Ju'fi, Aden, Ma'rib, Hadramawt, Khawlan, Al-Mahjarah, Al-Salaf, Al-Ma'afir, Yuhasib, Zabid, Akk...

...Mahsari', Al-Amluk, Rayman, Mikhlaf Bani Amir, Jawf Murad, Jawf Hamdan, Al-Shihr. The revenue of Yemen in gold was six hundred thousand dinars. Bahrain: Al-Rumaylah, Juwatha, Al-Khatt, Al-Qatif, Al-Sabun, Sawm, Al-Mushaqqar, Al-Darin, Al-Ghaba. The revenue of Yamama and Bahrain, according to what was established in a record organized by Ibn al-Mudabbir for the revenue of the year 237 in gold, is five hundred and ten thousand dinars. The contract of Oman in gold is three hundred thousand dinars. These are the districts in the Kingdom of Islam. What we have explained regarding the amounts of revenues is based on the average. What some regions yield at this time or decrease in some parts, we do not pay attention to nor base upon, because it only occurred due to lack of control and loss of prudence; and the remainder withheld follows the same path. The total of that—we have repeated its mention in this place so it gathers together and becomes accessible to the contemplator—in gold is four million, nine hundred and twenty thousand dinars. The exchange of gold to silver, at an exchange of fifteen dirhams per dinar, is seventy-three million and eight hundred thousand [dirhams]. The detail of that in gold and silver: The Sawad / One hundred million, thirty million, and two hundred thousand dirhams [130,200,000]. Ahwaz / Twenty-three million dirhams. Fars / Twenty-four million dirhams.

Kerman / Six million dirhams. Makran / One million dirhams. Isfahan / Ten million and five hundred thousand dirhams. Sijistan / One million dirhams. Khorasan / Thirty-seven million dirhams. Hulwan / Nine hundred thousand dirhams. Mah al-Kufa / Five million dirhams. Mah al-Basra / Four million and eight hundred thousand dirhams. Hamadhan / One million and seven hundred thousand dirhams. Masabadhan / One million and two hundred thousand dirhams. Mihrajanqadhaq / One million and one hundred thousand dirhams. Al-Aygharayn / Three million and eight hundred thousand dirhams. Qumm and Qashan / Three million dirhams. Azerbaijan / Four million and five hundred thousand dirhams. Rayy and Damavand / Twenty million and eighty thousand dirhams. Qazvin, Zanjan, and Abhar / One million, eight hundred and twenty-eight thousand dirhams. Qumis / One million, one hundred and fifty thousand dirhams. Jurjan / Four million dirhams. Tabaristan / Four million, two hundred and eighty thousand, and seven hundred dirhams. Tikrit and Al-Tirhan / Nine hundred thousand dirhams. Al-Sinn and Al-Bawazij...

...Shahrazur and Al-Samaghan / Two million, seven hundred and fifty thousand dirhams. District of Mosul / Six million and three hundred thousand dirhams. Qarda and Bazabda / Three million and two hundred thousand dirhams. Diyar Rabi'a / Nine million, six hundred and thirty-five thousand dirhams. Arzan and Mayyafariqin / Four million and two hundred thousand dirhams. Contract of Taron / One hundred thousand dirhams. Armenia / Four million dirhams. Amid / Two million dirhams. Diyar Mudar / Six million dirhams. Districts of the Euphrates Road / Two million and nine hundred thousand dirhams. Qinnasrin and Al-Awasim / Three hundred and sixty thousand dinars. Jund Homs / Two hundred and eighteen thousand dinars. Jund Damascus / One hundred and ten thousand dinars. Jund al-Urdunn / One hundred and nine thousand dinars. Jund Filastin / Two hundred and fifty-nine thousand dinars. Egypt and Alexandria / Two million and five hundred thousand dinars. The Two Sanctuaries / One hundred thousand dinars. Yemen / Six hundred thousand dinars. Yamama and Bahrain / Five hundred and ten thousand dinars. Oman / Three hundred thousand dinars. Included in some of the revenue is the poll tax (Jizya) of the heads of the People of the Pact (Dhimma) in the capital, the City of Peace (Baghdad), which is two hundred thousand dirhams.

It is said that Khosrow Parviz counted the collection of his kingdom in the eighteenth year of his reign, and he only held what we mentioned and named of the districts of the Sawad and other regions, excluding the districts of the West, for his border was up to Hit. What we named of the West was in the hands of the Romans. [His revenue] in gold was seven hundred and twenty thousand mithqals, which is six hundred million dirhams [sic] in silver. Qudama said: The regions, in my opinion, are in the same state they were at that time; their lands have not perished nor have their inhabitants vanished. What is required is that their administrator have fear of Allah first, then knowledge, justice, and integrity, so that affairs are set straight, management is organized, and wealth comes in such amounts that the wonderer would wonder at it. Chapter Seven: Mentioning the Frontiers (Thughur) of Islam and the Nations and Peoples Surrounding Them. The nations and generations opposing Islam surround it from all its sides and the ends of its districts. Some of them are close to the abode of its kingdom, and some are distant from it. The Kings of the Sects (Muluk al-Tawa'if), whom Dhu al-Qarnayn appointed as kings, used to pay tribute to the King of the Romans for five hundred and eleven years, until Ardashir bin Babak gathered the kingdom after hardship and long struggle. He then withheld the tribute that the Persians used to pay to the Romans after hardship. It is appropriate that the Muslims should not be more cautious of any of their varieties of enemies than they are of the Romans. Verses have come regarding that, through which the truth of what I said appears, and Allah is the Grantor of success for the best interest by His power. Since the Romans are as I described, it is necessary that we present the discussion of the frontiers facing their land over...

...the discussion of others. We say that these frontiers: some are on land, met by the land of the enemy and approaching it by land; and some are maritime, met and faced by it from the sea; and some where both matters combine, and expeditions by its people occur by land and sea. The maritime frontiers in general are all the coasts of the Levant and Egypt. The place where both matters combine, land and sea raids, are the frontiers known as the Syrian (Shami) ones. Let us begin by mentioning them: They are Tarsus, Adana, Al-Massisah, Ayn Zarba, Al-Kanisah, Al-Haruniyyah, Bayas, and Niqabulus. Their revenue is about one hundred thousand dinars, spent on their interests and other aspects of their affairs, namely the watchtowers, guards, scouts, couriers, those entrusted with the mountain passes and fords, fortresses, and other similar matters and conditions. It requires for its garrison of soldiers and vagabonds (Sa'alik - volunteers), and the salaries for its expeditions—summer and winter raids by land and sea—annually on approximation two hundred thousand dinars, and on ample estimation, meaning for it to be spacious, three hundred thousand dinars. What meets it of the enemy's land and connects to it: from the land side is Cappadocia (Al-Qabadiq), and near it is the Anatolic [Theme] (Al-Nataliq); and from the sea side is Seleucia. The Awasim (Protecting Strongholds) of these frontiers and what is behind them towards us are the lands of Islam. Each one of them was named 'Asim' (Protector) because it protects the frontier and reinforces it in times of mobilization. Then the people of Antioch, Al-Jumah, and Al-Quris mobilize to it. Then adjacent to these frontiers on their right and the north side are the frontiers known as the Jaziran (Mesopotamian) ones. The first of the Syrian frontiers it borders is Marash, followed by the frontier of Al-Hadath. Zabatrah used to follow this, but it was destroyed in the days of Al-Mu'tasim. He had, when rising to the land of the enemy until he conquered Amorium, the famous story. When he reached the site of Zabatrah, he built fortresses in its place and near it to stand in its stead: the fortress known as Tabarji, the fortress known as Al-Husayniyyah, the fortress known as Bani al-Mu'min, and the fortress known as Ibn Rahwan. Then follows these fortresses the frontier of Kaysum, then the frontier of Hisn Mansur, then...

...the frontier of Shamshat, then the frontier of Malatya, which is the one protruding into the enemy's land from all these fortresses. Between each one of them and the enemy's land is a mountain pass and an obstacle, but the frontier of Malatya is with the enemy's land in one plot and ground. Facing these frontiers and opposite them from the land of the Romans was Charsianon (Kharshana) and the district of Chaldia (Al-Khalidiyyah). In this time, there occurred between them and the Romans and the Armenians who are with Mleh the Armenian, in a land inhabited by a people called 'Al-?? Al-Qah' [Paulicians?], who are from the Romans except that they differ from them in many of their religious beliefs. These people were with the Muslims, aiding them in their raids, and the assistance through them was abundant for the Muslims, until they departed all at once from this place due to the mistreatment by the people of the frontiers in associating with them and the lack of oversight by the administrators regarding their affair. So they dispersed in the lands, and these Armenians dwelled in their place, built impregnable fortresses, and then acquired a dense troop and severe harm [to others]. The revenue of these frontiers with Malatya is seventy thousand dinars, of which forty thousand dinars is spent on their interests, leaving thirty thousand dinars. It requires for the expense of the allies and vagabonds (volunteers) on a partitioned basis one hundred and twenty thousand dinars added to the remainder; and on an ample basis one hundred and seventy thousand dinars added to it to complete two hundred thousand dinars, excluding the expenses of raids at their times. These frontiers are the middle ones, and from them raids used to occur; if a raid was needed from them, the expense was according to the raiders. The Awasim (Protecting Strongholds) of these frontiers are Duluk, Ra'ban, and Manbij. Adjacent to these frontiers on the right also, and in the north direction, are the frontiers named Al-Bakriyyah, which are Sumaysat, Hani, Malkin, and fortresses including Jumah, Hawran, Al-Kils, and others. Then the frontier of Qaliqala is in the north direction from these frontiers as an addition, except that it is...

...like an isolated one because of the far distance between it and them. What faces these frontiers from the districts of the Romans is the Armeniac district and some of the district of Chaldia, and near it is the district of Paphlagonia connected to the lands of the Khazars. The revenue of these frontiers per year is one million and three hundred thousand dirhams. Its expenses for its interests, fortresses, and the salaries of its garrisons require this amount plus an increase of one million and seven hundred thousand dirhams, completing three million dirhams. As for the maritime frontiers, they are the coasts of Jund Homs: Antartus, Balaniyas, Latakia, Jableh, and Al-hariyadha; and the coasts of Jund Damascus: Arqa, Tripoli, Jubayl, Beirut, Sidon, Hisn al-Sarafand, and Adnun; and the coasts of Jund al-Urdunn: Tyre and Acre—and in Tyre is the shipbuilding industry; and the coasts of Jund Filastin: Caesarea, Arsuf, Jaffa, Ashkelon, and Gaza; and the coasts of Egypt: Rafah, Al-Farama, and Al-Arish. The amount that raids in the expedition from the ships of the Syrian frontiers, including what gathers to them from the ships of the Levant and Egypt, is from eighty to one hundred [ships]. If they resolve on a raid in the sea, the masters of Egypt and the Levant correspond to work on that and prepare for it. They gather at the island of Cyprus. What gathers of them is called the Fleet (Al-Ustul), just as what gathers of the army on land is called the Camp (Al-Mu'askar). The manager of all maritime affairs of the Levant and Egypt is the Master of the Syrian Frontiers. The amount of expense on the ships if they raid from Egypt and the Levant is about one hundred thousand dinars. Since we have mentioned the matter of the Roman frontiers and their causes, there is no harm in mentioning the conditions of the Romans that are useful to know. The first is the arrangement of their armies: The Patrician (Bitriq) is a chief over ten thousand. With every Patrician is a Turmarch (Tumarkhan). Every Turmarch is over five thousand. With every Turmarch are five Drungaries (Taranjarin); every...

...Drungary is over a thousand. With every Drungary are five Comites (Qamamisa); every Comes (Qumis) is over two hundred. With every Comes are five Kentarchs (Qamatarkhin); every Kentarch is over forty. With every Kentarch are four Dekarchs (Daqarkhin); every Dekarch is over ten. As for the number of their armies, in Constantinople, which is the presence of the King, there are twenty-four thousand. Of them, the knights are sixteen thousand and the infantry are eight thousand. The knights are divided into four divisions. The first of them is the Scholae (Al-Askhalariyyah), and their master is the Domestic of the Schools (Al-Damastiq al-Kabir), who is the master of the muster of musters and the chief over the group; their number is four thousand knights. The second class is the Excubitors (Al-Hasaf?); they are four thousand knights. The third class is the Watch (Au?us / Vigla?), and they are for the guard; their master is a Drungary, and their number is four thousand. The fourth class is ??Darit??n [Federates / Hikanatoi?], and they go out with the King if he goes out on travel; their number is four thousand. The infantry is divided into two divisions. The first of them is called A?l?msa [Numera?], and their number is four thousand infantry. The rest are called Mu?rah [Walls?], and their number is four thousand. As for the other districts, they are...

...fourteen districts. Among them, behind the Gulf cutting through the land of the Romans which pours towards the Levant and has been mentioned before, are three districts. One of them is Ta'ila [Thrace?], which is the land containing Constantinople. Its border from the east is the aforementioned Gulf; from the south, the Sea of Sham (Mediterranean); from the north, the Sea of the Khazars (Black Sea); and from the west, a wall extending from the Sea of Sham to the Sea of the Khazars, its length is a journey of four days, and it is two stages from Constantinople. The one following it is known as Thrace (Traqiyah). Its border from the east is the aforementioned wall; from the south, the district of Macedonia; from the west, the lands of the Bulgarians (Burjan); and from the north, the Sea of the Khazars. Its length is a journey of eleven days, and its width from the Sea of the Khazars to the district of Macedonia is a journey of three days. The governor over it is known as the Strategos, and his army is five thousand men. Before the Gulf are eleven districts. One of them is the district of Paphlagonia, and its army is ten thousand men. Then following it towards the west is the district of the Optimatoi (Al-Abtabat), and the interpretation of this word in Arabic is the Ear and the Eye, because this district is the navel of the lands of the Romans, and its people are not men of war because the raids of the Muslims do not reach them nor others. Its western border is the Gulf; the northern is the Sea of the Khazars; the eastern is the district of Paphlagonia; and the southern is the district of Opsikion (Al-Absiq). Its army is four thousand men. Then following Al-Abtabat is the district of Opsikion (Al-Absiq). Its western border is the Gulf; the northern is Al-Abtabat; the southern is the district of the Anatolic; and the eastern is the district of the Thracesion. Its army is six thousand men. Then...

...following Opsikion is the district of Thracesion (Al-Tarqasis). Its border from the west is the Gulf; from the north, Opsikion; from the east, the Anatolic; and from the south, the Sea of Sham. Its army is six thousand men. Then follows it the district of the Anatolic (Al-Nataliq), the interpretation of which is 'The Eastern'. It is the largest of the Roman districts. It has a border to Opsikion in the west; from the southern side, Seleucia at the Sea of Sham; from the east side, the district of Cappadocia; and from the north, the Bucellarian (Al-Baqlar). Its army is fifteen thousand men. In it is the city of Amorium which Al-Mu'tasim conquered. Following it is the district of Seleucia in the direction of the Sea of Sham. One of its borders from the west is the Anatolic; from the south, the Sea; from the north, Thracesion; and from the east, a pass to Tarsus in the direction of Qalamiyah and Al-Lamis. Its army is five thousand men. Then follows it the district of Cappadocia (Al-Qabadiq). Its border from the south is the mountain of Tarsus, Adana, and Al-Massisah; from the west, the districts of Seleucia; from the north, the Anatolic; and from the east, the districts of Charsianon. Its army is four thousand men. Then follows that the district of Charsianon (Kharshana). One of its borders, the southern, is to Cappadocia; a border to the passes of Malatya, which is the eastern; a border to the district of the Armeniac, which is the northern; and a border to the district of the Bucellarian, which is the western. Its army is four thousand men. Then follows it the district of the Bucellarian (Al-Baqlar). A border of it is the district of the Anatolic and Optimatoi; the second is Cappadocia; the third is Charsianon; and the fourth is the Armeniac. Its army is eight thousand men. The district of the Armeniac (Al-Arminyaq): a border of it is to Paphlagonia; the second is the district of the Bucellarian; the third is the district of Charsianon; and the fourth is the district of Chaldia and the Sea of the Khazars. Its army is four thousand men. Then the district of Chaldia (Al-Khalidiyyah): a border of it is the lands of Armenia; the second is the Sea of the Khazars; the third is the Armeniac; and the fourth is also from the district of the Armeniac. Its army is four thousand men. So the entire army of the eleven districts which are...

...facing us, excluding those who are not relied upon but rather those who mobilize as knight and foot soldier, is seventy thousand men. Then we follow that with a description of one of the days of raids so that the knowledge of that is acquired and preserved. We say that the most strenuous of them, according to what the experienced people of the frontiers know, is for the raid called 'The Spring Raid' to occur when ten days have passed from Iyyar (May), after the people have grazed their beasts on spring grass and the conditions of their horses have improved. They stay for thirty days, which is the remainder of Iyyar and ten of Haziran (June), for they find the pasture in the land of the Romans possible, as if their beasts are grazing a second spring. Then they return and stay until twenty-five days, which is the remainder of Haziran and five of Tammuz (July), until the mounts become strong and fat and the people gather for the Summer Raid. Then they raid when ten days have passed from Tammuz, staying until the time of their return, sixty days. As for the Winter Raids, I have seen them all say: if it is inevitable, let it be one where one does not go far nor penetrate deeply, and let its march be twenty nights, the amount that a man carries for his horse sufficient on its back. Let that be at the end of Shubat (February), so the raiders stay until days pass from Adhar (March), for they find the enemy at that time to be weakest in spirit and beasts, and they find their livestock plentiful. Then they return and graze their beasts on spring grass, racing each other. Let us begin by mentioning what adjoins it from the north, taking the right until we come to the edges of the kingdom and beyond the frontiers, until we return to the borders of the Romans from the west side. We say that the border of the Khazars is from Armenia to Khwarazm of Khorasan. Anushirvan bin Qabad, when he reigned, built the city of Al-Shabaran, the city of Masqat, and the city of Al-Bab wa Al-Abwab (The Gate of Gates / Derbent) in Armenia. They were named 'Gates' because they were built on roads in the mountain. He settled in what he built of his soldiers a people he named...

...the Siyasijiyyin. Then, when he feared the aggression of the Khazars, he wrote to their king asking him for truce and peace, and that their matter should be one, and he asked for his daughter's hand to reassure him with that, showing him desire for marriage alliance. He sent him a daughter who was in his palace, whom one of his women had adopted, and mentioned to him that she was his daughter. The Khazar [king] gifted his daughter to him, then came to him. They met at a place known as Barshaliyah and drank together for days. Each of them became familiar with his companion and showed his kindness and honor. Then Anushirvan advanced to a group of his trustworthy and special men [ordering them] to raid a side of the Khazar's camp and set fire to it. When morning came, he complained of that to Anushirvan, who denied knowing anything about it. When nights passed for him, Anushirvan ordered his companions to repeat what they had done. When they did, the Khazar clamored from their deed until Anushirvan was gentle with him and apologized to him, so he accepted and calmed down. Then Anushirvan ordered fire to be thrown in a side of his [own] camp, and it fell upon the huts made of grass and tree branches. When morning came, Anushirvan clamored to the Khazar, saying, 'Your companions almost took away my camp and destroyed it! You have repaid me with suspicion.' He swore to him that he did not know of what happened. Anushirvan said to him, 'O my brother, my soldiers and your soldiers have hated our peace because of the cessation of what ceased for them of marching in raids that used to be between us. I do not feel safe that they might cause events that spoil our hearts after our purity and sincerity, so that we return to enmity after marriage and affection. The right thing is that you permit me to build a wall that will be between me and you, and we make a gate for it so that no one enters us from your side except whom we want.' He agreed to that. The Khazar returned, and Anushirvan stayed to build the wall. He built it, making it from the sea side with rock and lead, and made its width three hundred cubits until he joined it to the mountains. He ordered stones to be carried in ships and...

...thrown into the sea until, when they appeared on the surface of the water, he built upon them. He extended the wall into the sea for three miles. When he finished building it, he hung iron gates on the entrance and entrusted it to one hundred knights to guard the place, after having needed fifty thousand soldiers. He placed a tank (dabbabah) on it. It was said to the Khazar after that, 'He tricked you, married you to other than his daughter, and fortified himself against you.' He could find no stratagem against him. Since that time, the Khazar raids have been on the outskirts of Armenia after they had previously devastated it. Then follows this place also on the right the frontiers of Daylam, Gilan, Al-Babr, and Al-Taylasan. The fortress of Qazvin was called in Persian 'Kashwin', the interpretation of which is 'The Watched Border'. Between it and Daylam is a mountain. Persian fighters from the Asawirah (Cavalry) ceased not to be stationed in it, repelling the Daylam if there was no truce between them, and guarding that direction from their bandits. Dashtabi was divided between Rayy and Hamadhan; a part was called Razi and a part called Hamadhani. The raids of the Muslims in the beginning of Islam were in Dashtabi and Abhar, which is a fortress claimed to have been built by some of the Khosrows over springs. The conditions of the Daylam ceased not to be fluctuating because they have no established law nor stable obedience, for after their conquest they broke [treaties] and disbelieved more than once. In this time, there occurred from them matters deemed atrocious regarding the killing of children, debauchery in mosques, and abandoning prayer and the obligations of Islam. Among the great frontiers is the frontier of the Turks. They have a desert adjacent to the land of Jurjan from which they emerge. Its people had built a wall of baked brick upon it as fortification against...

...their raids, until the Turks overcame them and a king from them called Sul ruled its land. Then the Muslims conquered it. Most of the Turks are in the frontier that is in Khorasan; it is called Nushajan, and it is beyond Samarkand in the east by about sixty farsakhs towards Shash and Ferghana. It is the beginning of the garrisons of the Karluks (Kharlukhiyya) up to the border of Kimak. From this frontier to the city of the Taghazghuz (Toquz Oghuz) is a journey of forty-five days in deserts containing springs and pasture for twenty days, then large villages for twenty-five days. Most of the people of those villages are Magians (Majus), and among them are Manichaeans (Zanadiqa). Near the city of the Taghazghuz is a lake around which are villages and connected buildings. It has twelve gates of iron, and Turks guard it. They are all Manichaeans. Between Upper Nushajan and the land of Shash is forty stages for caravans, and for the fast traveler thirty days. Upper Nushajan has four large cities and five small ones. The fighters of Nushajan are in one city on the shore of a lake; they are twenty thousand men on the registry. There is no one among the Turks fiercer than them; they count ten against a hundred of the Karluks. The neighborhood upon which is the city of the Taghazghuz is surrounded by mountains from a distance. As for the lands of Kimak, they are from the direction of the city of Lower Nushajan, which we said is beyond Samarkand by sixty-five farsakhs, to the left of it and in the north direction. Between it and Taraz is a journey of eighty days in deserts and vast wildernesses with much pasture and springs. The Muslims hardly raid the Turks because of the saying of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, 'Leave the Turks alone as long as they leave you alone.' We only...

...mentioned their land and conditions because of what we presented of our condition to mention the nations surrounding the lands of Islam and the nations opposing them. As for Tibet, it is to the right of the lands of the Taghazghuz in the south direction. Dhu al-Qarnayn (Alexander), when he triumphed over Fur (Porus), the King of India, and killed him, stayed in the land of India for seven months and sent armies from it to Tibet and China. Some of those whom he sent came to him and informed him that all the kings of the East had agreed to enter into obedience and pay him tribute when they knew of his victory over Darius and Porus, the kings of the Persians and India, and his justice and good conduct. He left behind in the land of India those he trusted with thirty thousand [men] and marched until he came to the lands of Tibet. Their king came out to him with his Tarkhans (nobles), surrendering to him, and said to him, 'There has reached me about you, O King, of justice and fulfillment along with victory over those who opposed you, that by which I knew that your entire affair is from Allah. I liked to place my hand in your hand, and I do not desire to repel you from anything you want nor fight you, for he who fights you and contends with you only contends with the command of Allah, and he who contends with the command of Allah is defeated. I, my people, and the kingdom in my hand are yours, so command in all of that whatever you wish.' Alexander replied to him graciously and said to him, 'Whoever knows the right of Allah, his right becomes incumbent upon us. I hope you find with us the justice and fulfillment that satisfies you.' He asked him for guidance to the Turks of the deserts because the Turks of the cities had entered into his obedience. He walked before him and presented him with gifts, which he refused. He ceased not to repeat [the offer] until he agreed to accept them. He carried to him four thousand donkey loads of gold and the like of musk. He gave a tenth of the musk to Roshanak (Roxane), daughter of Darius, King of the Persians, his wife, and distributed the rest to his companions, and placed the gold in his treasury. The King of Tibet spoke to him about advancing him in his armies to China. The King ordered him to appoint his son as successor over his kingdom, so he appointed his son Madabik as successor in his land after him. Alexander joined to him a companion of his with ten thousand [men] and marched to...

...China in his vanguard, and Alexander with the main body of the camp followed him. The Master of China came out to him with ten armies, in each army one hundred thousand. He sent to Alexander mentioning to him what had reached him about his fulfillment and noble action, and that he could not fight him given this situation, though if he wanted that, he would not be incapable of it. He asked him to command what he wanted so he could comply. Alexander answered him and ordered him to carry the tithe (tenth) of his land according to what he did in others of the rest of the countries, and that if he did not do so, he would seek Allah's help against him, and his large number did not frighten him because Allah is capable of granting victory to the few over the many. He sent this answer to him with a group of Persians and Indians and ordered them to inform him of his justice in their lands, his beautiful action among them, and his good deed to them. The King of China returned the answer with obedience, asking that he accept from him in what he pays of the tithe of his lands and his peace treaty: silk, firinda (silk fabric), and other tools. Alexander was satisfied with that and accepted it from him. What he settled with him was one million firindas, one million bundles of silk, five hundred thousand kimkhawah (damask silk), and ten thousand saddles with their stirrups, bridles, straps, and all their tools, and one million manas of silver. He paid that. Alexander stayed in his land until he built a city he named the Tower of Stone (Burj al-Hijara) and placed in it a garrison of five thousand Persians, appointing over them a companion of his known as Nicoclides. He marched from China taking the north direction, and the Master of China was with him, until he ended at the land of Shul. He conquered it and built two cities there, one Shul and the other Khamdan. He ordered the Master of China to inhabit Khamdan with his soldiers and to place a garrison of his companions in Shul. Then he marched heading to the Turks of the Desert until he conquered them and subdued them. It reached him about a people with a large number of these Turks in the eastern side from the north direction that they were corrupters in the land. He consulted the Master of China about them. He informed him that they had no booty other than livestock and iron, and that the Green Sea, which has no passage...

...for anyone, surrounds them from the north side. From the west and south are mountains reaching into the sky that cannot be attempted, and no one has a path over them. There is no outlet for these Turks except from one narrow pass like a shoelace. They are in a corner of the earth; if this outlet were blocked against them, they would remain in it, the people would be sufficed from their evil, and corruption would cease from the earth. Alexander knew the face of correctness in what the Master of China advised, so he blocked that valley, which is the Dam (Al-Sadd) that Allah described and narrated its news in the Quran. Then Dhu al-Qarnayn returned to the land of the Turks of the Cities and the people of idols until he ended at the land of Sogdia (Al-Sughd), so he built Samarkand and the city known as Dabbusiya and Alexandria the Farthest (Eschate). Then he came to the land of Bukhara and built the city of Bukhara. Then he marched to the land of Merv and built its city. He built the two cities of Herat and Zaranj, exited to Jurjan, and ordered the building of Rayy, Isfahan, and Hamadhan, until he returned to the land of Babylon, where he stayed for years. Since we have finished mentioning the frontiers of the East, let us return to the south side. In it is the frontier of the Beja and Nubia; they are reconciled upon a tax called the Baqt, and there is no war or investigation between them and the Muslims. The matter of their peace will be in the Seventh Stage, which follows this chapter, if Allah wills, and in Him is strength. Then we mention after that the frontiers of the West. We say that the first of them is Ifriqiya, which is named Kairouan (Al-Qayrawan). Since it was opened, it ceased not to be managed on behalf of the King of Iraq after the rule of the Banu Marwan, until the Master of the Maghreb overcame it in this time, seized it, and exceeded it to Barqa, so he overcame it as an addition. As for beyond Ifriqiya, it is the lands of Tahert; between it and Ifriqiya is a journey of thirty days. It is in the hand of the Master of the Ibadiyyah, and they are a type of Kharijites. Beyond Tahert by a journey of twenty-four days is the country of the Mu'tazila; over them is a just chief, his justice is overflowing, his conduct is praiseworthy, and his abode is Tangier and its surroundings.
